task_name: House Cleaning Service Booking and Inquiry System
initial_requirements: I need a house cleaning service website where I can learn about available cleaning services, book a cleaning appointment, check the status of my bookings, and contact customer support for service inquiries
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse the house cleaning service website, so that I can access information about the cleaning services.
As a user, I want to understand the details of the cleaning services on the website, so that I know what services are provided.
As a user, I want to book cleaning services through the website, so that I can schedule a cleaning service.
As a user, I want to check the status of my booked cleaning services on the website, so that I can know the current state or progress of my service.
As a user, I want to contact customer service staff via a phone number provided on the website, so that I can speak with someone about the cleaning services.
As a user, I want to contact customer service staff via an email address provided on the website, so that I can communicate in writing about the cleaning services.
As a user, I want the website background to be azure mist, so that the visual appearance matches that specified color.
As a user, I want the website components to use dark slate blue, so that the components match that specified color.

conversation.interviewer: When users book or manage a cleaning appointment, what exact actions should they be able to perform on the website (e.g., create a new booking, reschedule, cancel, repeat a past booking, change service details), and are there any rules or limits you want for these actions (such as cancellation deadlines or reschedule limits)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed rules or limits like cancellation deadlines or reschedule caps right now. I just want users to be able to create a booking, reschedule or cancel it, and view/update basic details like date, time, address, and service type.

conversation.interviewer: Should each cleaning booking go through specific status stages (for example: requested, confirmed, in-progress, completed, cancelled), and if so, which exact statuses do you want and when should each status change occur?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed status workflow right now. Just something simple like pending/confirmed, completed, and cancelled is fine, and the staff can update it as needed.

conversation.interviewer: When a user books a cleaning appointment, do you want the flow to be a simple direct booking form (choose service, date/time, address, then confirm) without any cart or multi-item checkout, or do you envision something closer to a cart where they can add multiple services/visits before confirming?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a cart or multi-item checkout right now. A simple direct booking form is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction requirements right now. Just make it clean and easy to navigate, especially the booking form.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level navigation pages/sections do you want on the site (e.g., Home, Services, Book Now, My Bookings/Status, Contact Support), and how should they be grouped in the menu?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact menu grouping. Just have the basics: Home, Services, Book Now, My Bookings (status/details), and Contact Support—maybe an About page if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the site should be accessible without logging in, and which parts (e.g., creating a booking, viewing/updating “My Bookings,” contacting support) should require a user account and sign-in?

conversation.interviewer: Within each of your main pages (Home, Services, Book Now, My Bookings, Contact Support, and possibly About), how would you like the content to be structured in terms of key sections or subsections—for example, what main sections should appear on the Home page and what subsections (if any) should live under Services?
conversation.user: Home: a quick overview/hero with a clear “Book Now” button, a short “How it works,” a few featured services with links, reviews/testimonials, and service area/hours. Services: a list/grid of services that click into detail pages or expand to show what’s included, typical duration, pricing/starting price, add-ons, and FAQs. Book Now: simple form (service type, date/time, address, notes) plus confirmation; My Bookings: list of bookings with status and a details page to reschedule/cancel/update basics; Contact: quick form + phone/email + hours; About can be a short company blurb and trust info (insured, background-checked, etc.).

conversation.interviewer: On an individual service detail page, in what order do you want the information to appear—for example, should it start with the service name and price, then a short overview, then “what’s included,” duration, add-ons, and finally FAQs, or do you prefer a different sequence?

conversation.interviewer: On the Services page, how should the services be grouped for browsing—by cleaning type (e.g., standard/deep/move-in), by room/area, by frequency (one-time vs recurring), or another single grouping scheme you prefer?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now—what we covered is enough. Let’s move on to other topics.

initial_requirements: I need a website where I can browse phone service plans, view and manage my account and personal details, and access online customer support for help with my services.

As a user, I want to view service plan details, so that I can understand the specifics of each plan.
As a user, I want to get help, so that my issues or questions about the service can be addressed.
As a user, I want to manage my account information, so that I can keep my account details up to date.
As a user, I want to access my personal details, so that I can view the information associated with my account.
As a user, I want the body backgrounds of the website to use light goldenrod, so that the overall page background is consistently styled.
As a user, I want the main components of the website to use olive drab, so that the primary interface elements have a consistent color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What user roles should exist (e.g., guest vs logged-in customer vs admin/support agent), and what actions should each role be allowed to do?

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific ways you want the content to be grouped or labeled—for example, how plans should be categorized (by price, data amount, contract length, etc.) or how account- and support-related sections should be organized—so users can quickly find what they need?

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the site should be accessible without logging in (e.g., plan browsing/details, FAQs, contact/support pages), and which should require a logged-in customer account (e.g., account details, plan changes, support tickets/chat history)?

conversation.interviewer: Could you outline the desired page/section hierarchy—top-level hubs and their key child pages (e.g., Plans → Plan list → Plan details; My Account → Personal details/Billing/Usage; Support → FAQs/Contact/Tickets)?

conversation.interviewer: How should phone service plans be categorized for browsing (e.g., by price tiers, data amounts, contract length, or plan type like prepaid vs postpaid)?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: Besides service plans and customer accounts, what other core entities must the system model (e.g., invoices/billing transactions, payments, usage records, devices/SIMs, support tickets, chat transcripts)?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components like buttons and links (for example, a particular color family such as blue, green, or red), or should we choose one that fits a modern telecom look and meets accessibility contrast standards?
conversation.user: Yes—please use an olive drab as the main accent color for buttons and links. Just make sure it still meets accessibility contrast standards.

conversation.interviewer: What minimum color-contrast standard should the UI meet (e.g., WCAG 2.2 AA with 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text), or do you have a different target?

conversation.interviewer: When elements need a secondary highlight (e.g., active/selected states, badges, or focus outlines), should those use the same olive drab accent or a different specific color?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined, consistent color set for component states like hover, active, disabled, success, and error, and should those state colors be derived from the olive drab accent or can they be independent?

conversation.interviewer: What base color should be used for the primary fills/backgrounds of key UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar (e.g., white, light gray, dark)?

conversation.interviewer: For the overall page and layout background (outside of cards, panels, and the nav bar), do you want a specific color—such as plain white, a very light variant of the goldenrod, or something else—and should that same background be used across all pages?

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual aspects you want explicitly standardized across all pages and devices—for example, always using the same button style and olive-drab accent, the same heading/body fonts, and consistent spacing—or should we simply define a general design system and apply it uniformly without you specifying details?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specifying those details. Just define a simple design system and apply it consistently everywhere, keeping the olive-drab accent and light goldenrod components readable and accessible.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional brand/theme elements beyond the olive-drab accent and light goldenrod components—such as subtle patterns, gradients, or telecom-themed icons/illustrations—to reinforce a specific brand feel, or should we keep it strictly minimal and flat?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra brand/theme elements. Keep it pretty minimal and flat, and only add icons/illustrations if they help usability without hurting readability or load speed.

initial_requirements: I need a website for The All-In Bourbon Bar where I can browse menus, learn about the membership-only private poker room, see current events and promotions, and make reservations or purchases online.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse the website for The All-In Bourbon Bar, so that I can explore its products and services.
As a user, I want to view the menus on the website, so that I can see the food and drink offerings.
As a user, I want to learn about the membership-only private poker room on the website, so that I can understand what it is and what it offers.
As a user, I want to view events and promotions on the website, so that I can stay informed about what is happening at The All-In Bourbon Bar.
As a user, I want to make online reservations through the website, so that I can reserve a spot at The All-In Bourbon Bar.
As a user, I want to make online purchases through the website, so that I can buy offerings from The All-In Bourbon Bar.
As a user, I want the container backgrounds on the website to use peach puff, so that the visual styling matches the specified design.
As a user, I want the component visuals on the website to use indian red, so that the visual styling matches the specified design.

conversation.interviewer: What steps should the reservation/purchase flow include—from selecting a date/time or items, through payment/deposit (if any), to confirmation and any cancellation or modification rules?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact step-by-step flow details right now—just make it simple for people to reserve or buy, pay if needed, and get a confirmation. Cancellation/modification rules can be standard and easy to find.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages and top-level navigation items do you want in the menu (for example: Home, Menus, Private Poker Room, Events & Promotions, Reservations, Shop), and how should they be organized in the site’s header?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact header organization. Just make sure it’s easy to find Menus, Private Poker Room info, Events/Promos, and Reservations/Shop.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction requirements. Just make it feel modern and fast on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: How should the content be grouped into sections and subpages—for example, do you want separate top-level pages for Menus, Poker Room, Events/Promos, and Reservations/Shop, or any of these combined under a single “Experience” or “Visit” section?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how you group it, as long as it’s obvious where to find Menus, the Private Poker Room info, Events/Promos, and Reservations/Shop. Do whatever keeps it simplest and easiest to navigate.

conversation.interviewer: For the membership-only private poker room and any other members-only offerings, what specific information or features (e.g., detailed rules, event schedule, pricing, booking, photos) should be restricted to logged-in members versus visible to the general public?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on what’s gated right now. In general, keep a public overview (what it is, how to apply, basic vibe), and put pricing, detailed rules, member event calendar, and booking behind member login.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the gated poker-room details you mentioned, do you want any other parts of the site’s structure or content (e.g., navigation labels, homepage highlights, or certain sections) to differ for members vs. general visitors, or should everyone see the same overall pages with only a few member-only details hidden?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about different site structures for members vs. the public. Same overall pages for everyone is fine—just hide the member-only poker room stuff behind login.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to use a simple flat structure with separate top-level pages (Menus, Private Poker Room, Events/Promos, Reservations/Shop), or a hub-and-spoke structure where these live under one parent page like “Visit” or “Experience”?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which structure you use. Just pick whatever makes it simplest for people to quickly find Menus, Poker Room info, Events/Promos, and Reservations/Shop.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content requirements right now. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color would you like used for key components such as buttons, links, and highlights throughout the site (for example, a specific shade of red, gold, or another color that fits The All-In Bourbon Bar)?
conversation.user: Let’s use an indian red as the primary accent color for buttons, links, and highlights—something warm that fits the bourbon vibe.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site’s colors (including the indian red accent) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG 2.1 AA for text and interactive elements?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific standard like WCAG 2.1 AA. Just make sure the text and buttons are easy to read and usable on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the indian red accent, are there any other specific colors, patterns, or visual motifs (e.g., dark wood, gold foil, playing-card or poker imagery) you want used across components to reinforce The All-In Bourbon Bar’s brand and theme?

conversation.interviewer: What base colors (beyond the indian red accent) would you like for key components such as card/panel backgrounds and the main navigation bar—e.g., very dark wood-brown, charcoal, or another tone to support the warm bourbon vibe?

conversation.interviewer: For the overall page and layout background (outside of cards/panels), do you prefer a specific color or gradient—such as a very dark wood-brown, charcoal, or something lighter—and should that same background be used sitewide or vary between sections (e.g., different background for the homepage vs. inner pages)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact background color or whether it varies by section. Just keep it consistent and classy—something dark that fits the wood/bourbon vibe and makes the peach panels and indian red accents stand out.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color set for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your indian red accent and warm bourbon palette?

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should we standardize sitewide for consistency—e.g., typography (font sizes/weights), button styles, form fields, card/panel styling, and spacing?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about standardizing specific UI elements in detail. Just make it consistent across the site—clean typography, clear button styles, and forms that are easy to use on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to browse The All-In Bourbon Bar menus online so I can decide what to order.

Feature3: As a member, I want to log in so I can access members-only poker room information.
Feature4: As a member, I want to view poker room pricing so I can understand member costs.
Feature5: As a member, I want to view detailed poker room rules so I can follow room policies.
Feature6: As a member, I want to view a members-only event calendar for the poker room so I can plan visits.
Feature7: As a member, I want to book poker room offerings (TBD: what can be booked) so I can reserve member experiences.
Feature8: As a user, I want to view current events and promotions so I can decide when to visit.
Feature9: As a user, I want a simple reservations flow so I can reserve a visit quickly.
Feature10: As a user, I want to make purchases online (TBD: what items are sold) so I can buy without visiting in person.
Feature11: As a user, I want to pay online when required for reservations or purchases so I can complete the transaction.
Feature12: As a user, I want to receive a confirmation after a reservation or purchase so I know it was successful.
Feature13: As a user, I want to easily find cancellation/modification rules so I can understand how changes work.
Feature14: As a user, I want navigation that makes Menus, Private Poker Room, Events/Promos, and Reservations/Shop easy to find so I can get to key content quickly.
Feature15: As a user, I want the site to feel modern and load fast on mobile and desktop so I can use it comfortably on any device.
Feature16: As a user, I want a consistent visual design across pages (typography, buttons, forms, panels) so the site feels cohesive and easy to use.
Feature17: As a user, I want the site’s text and buttons to be easy to read and interact with on mobile and desktop so I can use it without strain.
Feature18: As a user, I want the site’s visual theme to use an indian red accent with warm bourbon/amber tones, dark wood/charcoal backgrounds, and peach puff panels so the brand feels warm and classy.
Feature19: As a user, I want subtle and consistent hover/active states, clearly disabled controls, and obvious success/error feedback so interactions are clear without clashing with the warm palette.

initial_requirements: I want a customer service system where I can manage customer information, log customer service calls, look back at call histories, and control what different users are allowed to do.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use a customer service call logging system to record and manage customer service calls, so that I can track interactions with customers.
As a user, I want to identify clients within the system, so that I can associate each call with the correct client.
As a user, I want to select the call type, so that I can categorize each customer service call appropriately.
As a user, I want to record information about the call, so that the details of the interaction are stored.
As a user, I want to record action steps taken during or after the call, so that the activities performed are documented.
As a user, I want to record follow-up steps, so that planned future actions related to the call are tracked.
As a user, I want to record additional information about the call, so that any extra relevant details are captured.
As a user, I want to create new call logs, so that I can register new customer service calls in the system.
As a user, I want to view open calls, so that I can see calls that are not yet closed.
As a user, I want to generate call log reports, so that I can review and analyze call data.
As a user, I want to modify client information, so that client records can be kept up to date.
As a user, I want the page background to be set to light pink, so that the system appears with that specific background color.
As a user, I want all components to be colored medium violet red, so that the system’s components appear with that specific color.

conversation.interviewer: What user roles do you need (e.g., admin, supervisor, agent), and which key actions should each role be allowed to perform in the system?
conversation.user: I don’t really care what you call the roles as long as permissions are configurable. We’ll probably need an admin who can manage users/permissions, and regular agents who can view/update customer info and log calls.

conversation.interviewer: How granular should configurable permissions be—for example, do you need separate allow/deny controls per feature (manage customers, log calls, view histories, manage users) and per data scope (all customers vs only assigned customers)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about super granular permissions. Basic feature-level permissions are enough, and maybe just one simple scope option like “all customers” vs “assigned customers” if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: What login and authentication methods do you want supported for your users (for example, email/password only, single sign-on with your company accounts, or multi-factor authentication options)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about fancy auth. Email/password is fine, and if it’s easy to add basic MFA later that’d be nice, but not a must-have.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I’d like the main dashboard to default to showing open calls first, with a quick search/filter so agents can find an open case fast.

conversation.interviewer: Should the dashboard’s search/filter remember an agent’s last-used filters (e.g., status=open) when they return later, or should it reset to defaults each time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If it’s simple, remembering the last-used filters is nice, but resetting to a sensible default is totally fine too.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like a simple reports screen where we can generate and export call log reports (CSV is fine), like by date range, agent, and call outcome.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main sections of the system to be organized and navigated—for example, what core pages (such as Dashboard, Customers, Call Logs, Reports, User/Admin settings) should exist and how should agents move between them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact navigation as long as it’s straightforward. Just make the core pages easy to reach—Dashboard, Customers, Calls/Call Logs, Reports, and an Admin/Settings area for user management.

conversation.interviewer: How should users navigate between the core pages—do you prefer a left sidebar menu, a top navigation bar, or another navigation pattern?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—left sidebar or top nav are both fine as long as it’s clear and quick to get to Dashboard, Customers, Calls, Reports, and Admin.

conversation.interviewer: When agents are entering or updating customer and call information, are there any specific workflow or data-entry needs you want to support—for example, required fields, step-by-step call logging, or the ability to quickly update multiple open calls in one go?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about anything fancy there. Just make the basics easy—maybe a few required fields like customer name/contact and call outcome, and a quick way to save/log a call without too many steps.

conversation.interviewer: Besides customer name/contact and call outcome, are there any other specific data fields you want on the customer and call logging forms, and which of those should be required?
conversation.user: On the customer form, I’d want an email/phone, company (if applicable), and maybe a notes field—required should just be name plus at least one contact method. For call logs, required: date/time, agent, call type (inbound/outbound), short summary, and status (open/closed), with optional tags and follow-up date/next action.

conversation.interviewer: For customers and call logs, beyond basic single-record add/edit/delete, do you want any bulk operations in the interface (such as bulk closing calls, bulk assigning calls to an agent, or bulk updating customer fields), and if so which specific bulk actions matter to you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about bulk operations right now. If you can do a simple multi-select to bulk close or bulk assign calls, that’s a nice-to-have, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: When an agent saves or updates a customer or call record and something goes wrong (validation error, system error, etc.), what specific follow-up options do you want them to have—such as fixing the fields on the same screen and resubmitting, discarding changes, or something else?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about anything special there—just show a clear error message and let them fix it on the same screen and resubmit. Having a cancel/discard changes option is fine.

conversation.interviewer: For actions like generating reports or sending follow-up reminders based on call logs, should these run automatically on a schedule or event (e.g., after a call is closed), or only when an agent/admin manually triggers them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about automation right now—manual is fine. If scheduling is easy to add later, that’s a nice-to-have, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: When an admin changes settings or permissions in the system, should those changes apply immediately as soon as they’re saved, or would you prefer a more controlled flow (like a “review/confirm” step before they take effect)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having a review/confirm flow. Applying changes immediately when saved is fine, as long as it’s clear what changed.

conversation.interviewer: When an agent is working in one area (like viewing a customer) and needs to switch to another area (like the related call logs or reports), how would you prefer that switch to happen in the interface—for example, via in-page tabs within a customer view, or by opening those other areas in separate full pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—tabs or separate pages are both fine. Just make it quick and obvious to jump between a customer and their related call logs.

conversation.interviewer: When an agent clicks a customer (or a call) in a list, should it open a dedicated detail page/view for that single record, or should details open inline (e.g., a side panel/modal) from the list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either a dedicated detail page or an inline side panel is fine. Just keep it fast and make it easy to get back to the list.

conversation.interviewer: When agents are looking for a specific customer or call without using search, how would you prefer they browse and discover records—primarily through simple sortable/filterable lists, or would you like any additional structured views (such as grouped by status, date, or assigned agent)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra structured views. Simple sortable/filterable lists are enough—maybe basic filters like status and assigned agent.

conversation.interviewer: When an admin manages users and permissions, what specific screens or flows would you like them to have (for example, a single “User Management” page with search/filter, separate edit screens per user, or something else)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact screens or flow. A straightforward User Management page with a list/search and a simple edit screen for a user’s role/permissions is enough.

conversation.interviewer: What should the user session timeout behavior be—after how many minutes of inactivity should the system automatically log a user out?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact timeout. Just pick a reasonable default, and if it’s easy, let an admin adjust it later.

conversation.interviewer: Which platforms and entry points do you need to support for accessing the system (e.g., desktop web browser only, mobile web, native iOS/Android app, kiosk/large-screen), and should the navigation differ for any of them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting a bunch of platforms—desktop web browser is enough for us. If it’s reasonably usable on mobile web too, that’s a nice bonus, but no need for separate navigation patterns.

initial_requirements: I need a customer relationship management website that lets me manage and organize sales leads, send messages, adjust configuration options, and view reports, while also providing guidance on best practices and integrations.
user_stories: As a user, I want a customer relationship management (CRM) website for managing sales leads and reporting, so that I can handle my sales lead workflow in one place.
As a user, I want automated message sending functionality, so that messages related to leads can be sent without manual effort.
As a user, I want to browse and manage sales leads, so that I can review, edit, and control my lead records.
As a user, I want to update settings and dropdown menus, so that I can configure the CRM options and selectable values as needed.
As a user, I want reporting functionality, so that I can generate and view reports about my sales leads.
As a user, I want to view reports, so that I can understand performance and outcomes related to my leads.
As a user, I want to receive best practice and integration advice, so that I can use the system effectively and connect it with other tools.
As a user, I want the website background defined as papaya whip, so that the overall page background has that specific color.
As a user, I want the components defined with dark orange, so that the interface elements use that specific color.

conversation.interviewer: What communication and messaging capabilities do you need in the CRM (e.g., in-app chat, email sending/receiving, SMS/WhatsApp), and should messages be moderated or approved before sending?
conversation.user: I mainly need email sending (and ideally receiving/threads) plus SMS/WhatsApp support. Messages should be able to trigger automatically based on lead events (new lead, status change, no response after X days), using templates. Automated messages should require approval before first use per template, but not per-send.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific lead events should trigger automated notifications/reminders, and who should receive them (e.g., assigned sales rep only, team lead, or the lead/customer)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on that right now—just the basic triggers like new lead, status change, and no response after X days are fine. Default recipients should be the assigned sales rep, with an option to also notify a team lead if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What do you want to be configurable in your email/SMS/WhatsApp templates (for example, which lead fields can be merged in, support for multiple languages, and whether to include or quote the previous message)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about going deep on template configurability right now. Basic merge fields (name, company, last contact date, status) and simple editing is enough; multilingual and message-quoting can be nice-to-have later.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I want lead records to be quick to browse and edit—click into a lead, update status/notes, and save without page reloads or losing my place in the list. Basically a fast, responsive UI with smooth navigation between the lead list and individual lead pages.

conversation.interviewer: After a template has been approved, do you still need any per-message controls—such as pausing/canceling scheduled sends, restricting who can send to certain leads, editing or deleting sent messages, or hiding/deleting inbound replies?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about most of that right now. Pausing/canceling scheduled sends would be useful, but I don’t need editing/deleting sent messages or hiding inbound replies as a requirement.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want to control the timing and frequency of automated notifications and reminders—for example, should they be sent immediately on each trigger, only during certain hours/days, and with limits on how often a given lead or rep can receive them in a day or week?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting too detailed on timing/frequency right now. Default to sending immediately, and maybe add a simple “business hours only” toggle later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Aside from email, SMS, and WhatsApp, do you want notifications and reminders to also appear inside the CRM itself (in-app notifications) or via any other channels like mobile push?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more channels right now. Email/SMS/WhatsApp are the priority; in-app notifications could be a nice-to-have later.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like configuration to be really straightforward: an admin settings area where I can directly edit dropdown options and other settings (add/rename/reorder values) and have changes apply immediately, without needing dev work.

conversation.interviewer: What real-time and reliability behavior do you need for email/SMS/WhatsApp messaging—for example, should conversation threads update live, should outbound messages queue and retry if a provider is down, and do you need delivery/read status indicators?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting into real-time/reliability details right now. Basic queued sending with retry if a provider is down would be good, but live thread updates and delivery/read indicators aren’t required at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any real‑time chat or internal messaging between team members inside the CRM, or should communication features be limited to email/SMS/WhatsApp with leads and customers only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about internal team chat right now. Let’s keep it limited to email/SMS/WhatsApp with leads and customers for the first version.

conversation.interviewer: What primary pages should the CRM have in its main navigation (e.g., Leads list, Lead detail, Messaging/Inbox, Reports, Settings), and in what order should they appear?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact nav order right now. The basics I’ll need are Leads, Messaging/Inbox, Reports, and Settings.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any bulk operations for leads (e.g., bulk change status/owner, add tags, or send a template message to multiple selected leads), and if so, which ones are required for the first version?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about bulk ops for the first version. If anything, a simple bulk status change could be handy later, but it’s not required right now.

conversation.interviewer: In the admin settings area, who should be allowed to edit and publish configuration changes (e.g., only admins, or also team leads), and do you need an approval step before changes go live?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting into roles/approvals right now. Just assume only admins can edit/publish and changes go live immediately.

conversation.interviewer: Within those main sections (Leads, Messaging/Inbox, Reports, Settings), how would you like navigation between them to work—for example, a persistent top or side menu always visible, or something more like tabs within a single workspace?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation pattern right now. As long as it’s always visible and fast to switch between sections, either a side menu or top bar is fine.

conversation.interviewer: When moving from the leads list into an individual lead’s detail view, what specific related views or panels do you want directly accessible there (for example, activity timeline, message thread, configuration/settings for that lead, or reports related to that lead)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting too specific on panels right now. At minimum I’d want notes/status up top and a simple activity/message history I can glance at, but the exact layout isn’t a priority.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific admin or management workflows you want supported beyond basic settings edits—for example, a dedicated admin dashboard for monitoring system health/usage, or is a simple settings area without extra admin overviews sufficient for your needs?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about an admin dashboard or system health monitoring right now. A simple settings area is sufficient for the first version.

conversation.interviewer: What single UI control should users use to switch between the main modules (Leads, Messaging/Inbox, Reports, Settings)—for example, a left sidebar menu or a top navigation bar?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a left sidebar or a top nav bar. Just make it always visible and fast to switch between sections.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to browse and discover leads and related content—primarily through a single sortable/filterable list, or do you also want additional views such as saved segments, categorized views (e.g., by status or owner), or other specialized lead collections?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about multiple specialized views right now. A single sortable/filterable leads list is enough for the first version, and we can add saved segments or categorized views later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users to be able to create and reorder custom pages/views (e.g., saved lead list views or report pages), and if so should these be flat lists or organized into folders/groups?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about custom pages/views or folders for the first version. A basic leads list and the standard reports are fine to start with.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the CRM to support switching between multiple accounts or company workspaces within one logged‑in session, and if so, what kinds of contexts would you want to switch between (e.g., different client accounts or business units)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about multi-account or multiple workspaces for the first version. Just a single company/account per login is fine.

initial_requirements: I need a customer support chatbot on the website that can provide customer support and handle customer interactions.
user_stories: As a user, I want to access a customer support chatbot on the website, so that I can receive customer support and handle my interactions directly online.
As a user, I want the chatbot to answer frequently asked questions, so that I can quickly find answers without needing human assistance.
As a user, I want the chatbot to provide product information, so that I can learn more about products I am interested in.
As a user, I want the chatbot to assist me in completing orders, so that I can successfully place my orders with its help.
As a user, I want the website’s background styling to use a snow color, so that the visual appearance matches that specified style.
As a user, I want the website’s components to use a dim gray styling, so that the components visually match that specified style.

conversation.interviewer: Should the chatbot be able to send or trigger emails or other notifications (e.g., to your support team or to customers), and if so, in which situations and through which channels (email, SMS, Slack, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about email or notification triggers right now. The main thing is it can answer questions and handle chats on the website.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to move between different parts of the chatbot experience—for example, should there be clearly labeled “topics” or “menu options” (like Billing, Orders, Technical Issues) that users can click, or do you prefer only free‑form typing with minimal navigation elements?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having topic menus or fancy navigation. I’m fine with users just typing their questions free‑form, as long as the bot can handle it well.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the chatbot to be available to all visitors anonymously, or should some features (like viewing order details or account-specific information) require users to log in, and if so, what types of user roles or access levels do you envision?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about login or user roles right now. Let’s just make it available to all visitors anonymously for basic support chat.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any specific interaction requirements right now. As long as it feels reasonably fast and the chat is easy to use, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities do you need the chatbot to reference or store for support (e.g., FAQs/articles, products/services, orders, tickets, customer profiles), and are there any required fields for those entities?
conversation.user: At minimum it should reference our FAQs/help articles (title, content, category/tags, last updated). If it needs to store anything, just chat transcripts (timestamp, session ID) and maybe basic contact info only if the user chooses to share it.

conversation.interviewer: For the chat transcripts and optional contact info you mentioned, could you specify the exact fields you want stored for each (e.g., for transcripts: message text, sender type, etc.; for contact info: name, email, phone)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact field list right now. Just store the transcript messages with timestamps and whether it was the user or bot, plus a session ID; for contact info, only whatever the user provides (like name and email).

conversation.interviewer: What relationships (if any) should the system model between the core entities—for example, should each chat transcript be linked to a specific FAQ/article used and/or to the optional contact info when provided?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about modeling detailed relationships right now. If anything, just link a transcript to the session ID and to the contact info if the user provided it; no need to tie it to specific FAQs.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like your FAQs/help articles to be organized—do you want a specific category hierarchy or tagging scheme (e.g., by product, topic, difficulty level), and if so, how should those categories or tags be structured?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a strict hierarchy or specific tagging scheme right now. We can keep whatever simple categories/tags we already have and let the bot search across them.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific sources should the chatbot be allowed to access for answering questions—only your FAQ/help articles, or also other datasets like a knowledge base, ticketing system, or product/order information?
conversation.user: Ideally it should use our FAQ/help articles plus our product catalog data so it can answer detailed product questions. I don’t need it pulling from tickets or order/account info yet.

conversation.interviewer: When the chatbot responds with product information from your catalog, which specific product fields should it display to users (e.g., name, price, description, SKU, availability)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific field list right now. Just show the product name and a short description, and include price if it’s available.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific requirements for how long chat transcripts and any stored contact info should be retained (and whether old records should be archived, anonymized, or deleted after a certain period)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about retention rules right now. Just keep transcripts for internal review for a reasonable period and we can revisit anonymizing/deleting later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the basic fields you’ve mentioned (like FAQ title/content/tags and product name/description/price), are there any domain-specific metadata or parameters you want the system to store—for example, things like product specs (size, material, model number), support priority levels, or other specialized attributes that matter in your business?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about storing extra domain-specific metadata right now. Let’s keep it simple with the basic product info and FAQs, and we can add specs or other attributes later if it becomes necessary.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements right now. The main thing is it can guide customers through completing an order successfully using our FAQs and product info; we can add more content fields later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What color would you like for the chatbot widget’s buttons and other accent elements (e.g., send button, links, highlights)?
conversation.user: Let’s style the chatbot widget accents in dim gray to match the rest of the site—buttons, links, and highlights. A slightly darker dim gray for hover/active states would be fine too.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the chatbot colors (for example, meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and buttons), or should we just ensure they are reasonably readable without targeting a formal standard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about hitting a formal WCAG AA/AAA standard right now. Just make sure the text and buttons are clearly readable with good contrast on our site backgrounds.

conversation.interviewer: For the main body of the chatbot widget (like the chat message bubbles and the panel/background behind the conversation), what base colors would you like us to use?
conversation.user: Let’s use a snow-colored base for the main panel/background. For the message bubbles, keep them very light (near-snow) with the dim gray accents, and maybe a slightly darker light-gray for the user bubbles so they’re easy to distinguish.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your dim gray accents or be separate fixed colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a fully defined state color palette right now. Just derive hover/active from the dim gray accents, and use simple, standard colors for success/error if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the chatbot widget to strictly match your existing site theme with only the snow + dim gray palette, or should we introduce any additional brand colors/patterns (e.g., a logo mark or subtle decorative accents) to align more strongly with your brand?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding extra brand colors or patterns right now. Let’s keep it simple and stick to the snow + dim gray palette, and we can always add logo/branding later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: For the overall website layout behind the chatbot (outside the widget itself), do you want us to assume your existing site background color(s) as-is, or are there specific background colors or sections (e.g., header, footer, main content area) you want defined for pages where the chatbot appears?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about changing the overall site layout/background for this—assume our existing site styles as-is. The chatbot just needs to sit on top without clashing.

conversation.interviewer: Which widget style elements should we standardize across all pages and devices (e.g., typography, spacing, border radius, shadow), beyond the snow + dim gray colors you specified?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about standardizing those style details right now. Just keep it consistent with our existing site typography and make it feel clean and modern across desktop and mobile.

task_name: Insurance Business Management and Reporting System
initial_requirements: I need a web application to help me manage insurance business operations, including managing various information and generating analytical results.
user_stories: As a user, I want a web application to help me manage insurance business operations, so that I can manage customers, policies, and claims, and generate analytical reports and charts.
As a user, I want the system to provide customer management functionality, so that I can manage insurance customers.
As a user, I want the system to provide policy management functionality, so that I can manage insurance policies.
As a user, I want the system to provide claims management functionality, so that I can manage insurance claims.
As a user, I want to browse customer information, so that I can view details about insurance customers.
As a user, I want to browse policy information, so that I can view details about insurance policies.
As a user, I want to browse claims information, so that I can view details about insurance claims.
As a user, I want to perform corresponding operations on customer information, so that I can manage customer-related data and actions.
As a user, I want to perform corresponding operations on policy information, so that I can manage policy-related data and actions.
As a user, I want to perform corresponding operations on claims information, so that I can manage claim-related data and actions.
As a user, I want the system to provide data analysis capabilities, so that I can analyze insurance business data.
As a user, I want the system to generate various reports, so that I can review summarized insurance business information.
As a user, I want the web application to use whitesmoke as the background color, so that the overall interface follows the specified visual style.
As a user, I want the web application to use dark cyan for interface elements, so that the components follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main workflows users will perform in the app (e.g., creating/editing policies, clients, and claims), and do you need any bulk actions like importing/exporting or mass updates?
conversation.user: Main workflows are CRUD on customers/clients, policies, and claims, plus linking them together (assign a policy to a client, attach claims to a policy). We also need reporting/analytics dashboards off that data. Bulk actions: yes—CSV import/export for clients/policies/claims and simple mass updates like status changes or agent reassignment.

conversation.interviewer: For the client, policy, and claim create/edit forms, what specific fields must be captured, and which fields are required versus optional for each?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact field-level details yet—those can follow standard insurance templates. For now I just need the forms to be flexible so we can configure required vs optional fields later without a big rebuild.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond CSV import/export and mass status/agent reassignment, do you need any other bulk operations in the UI (e.g., bulk delete, bulk duplicate, bulk assign/unassign links) for clients, policies, or claims?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about additional bulk operations right now. If it’s easy to include, bulk link/unlink would be nice, but it’s not a must-have for the first version.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like a fast, search-first navigation: a global search box that instantly finds clients/policies/claims (with filters) and lets me open a read-only detail view first, then click Edit from there.

conversation.interviewer: When using the global search, should filters (e.g., type=client/policy/claim, status, date range, agent) persist across pages and sessions, or reset each time you navigate/search?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of behavior right now. Defaulting to “remember my last filters for this session” is fine, and you can add cross-session persistence later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I think we already covered the main interaction thing I care about—the fast, search-first navigation. Other UI behavior details aren’t a big concern for me right now.

conversation.interviewer: Besides clients, policies, and claims, what other core business entities do you need the system to model (e.g., agents/brokers, carriers, premiums/payments, renewals, commissions), if any?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about modeling extra entities in the first version. If you want to include something minimal, agents/brokers and carriers are the only ones that might be useful later, but not required now.

conversation.interviewer: What key metrics and breakdowns should the analytics dashboards show (e.g., claim volume and payout, loss ratio, policy counts/premiums), and at what granularity (daily/weekly/monthly) and filters (date range, agent, carrier, status) do you need them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact dashboard metrics and breakdowns yet. For the first version, just give me a few basics like policy counts, claim counts, and claim amounts with simple date range and agent/status filters, monthly is fine.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements right now. As long as clients, policies, and claims are clearly separate records with clean links between them (and those links show up on the detail views), we’re good—let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main navigation and content structure organized—for example, should there be separate top-level sections for Clients, Policies, and Claims (with their own subpages like lists, detail views, and reports), or do you prefer a different hierarchy or grouping?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation hierarchy right now. A simple left nav with top-level sections for Clients, Policies, Claims, and Reports is fine as long as global search is prominent and fast.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any more content requirements right now—let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the core UI component colors (such as buttons, tabs, and input fields)—for example, a primary accent color you want used for actions and highlights, or any brand colors that should drive the theme?
conversation.user: Yes—please use dark cyan as the primary accent color for buttons and key highlights. Everything else can stay pretty neutral/clean.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme—for example, meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements, or is basic good readability sufficient for now?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about formal WCAG AA/AAA targets right now—just make sure it’s generally readable and usable. If you can meet WCAG AA without much extra effort, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual elements you want explicitly standardized across all screens—such as button style, table layout, or form field appearance—or is basic reuse of the same component library across the app sufficient for you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about explicitly standardizing those visual elements right now. Basic reuse of the same component library across the app is totally fine.

conversation.interviewer: What base fill color should the main navigation bar use (e.g., white, light gray, dark/near-black, or a specific hex value)?
conversation.user: Let’s use whitesmoke as the base fill for the main navigation bar too (something like #F5F5F5). The dark cyan can stay as the accent for active states and key highlights.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for UI states (hover, active, disabled, success, warning, error), and should those state colors be derived from your dark cyan accent or use separate fixed colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a fully defined state color system right now. Just use sensible standard success/warning/error colors and keep hover/active derived from the dark cyan accent.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the main page background use (e.g., white, #F5F5F5, or another specific hex value)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact background color—just keep it light and clean. Using white or something like #F5F5F5 is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any additional brand or thematic elements (such as secondary colors, subtle patterns, or logo-based motifs) that you want reflected in the UI beyond the dark cyan accent and light, neutral backgrounds?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about additional brand/theme elements right now. Let’s just keep it clean and neutral with the dark cyan accent—no patterns or motifs needed.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other style requirements from me—let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to create, view, edit, and delete client records.  
Feature2: As a user, I want to create, view, edit, and delete policy records.  
Feature3: As a user, I want to create, view, edit, and delete claim records.  
Feature4: As a user, I want to link/unlink policies to clients so I can see who owns which policies.  
Feature5: As a user, I want to link/unlink claims to policies so I can see all claims associated with a policy.  
Feature6: As a user, I want detail pages for clients/policies/claims that clearly show their linked records (e.g., a client shows policies; a policy shows client and claims).  
Feature7: As a user, I want a global, search-first navigation that instantly searches clients/policies/claims with filters so I can find records quickly.  
Feature8: As a user, I want global search results to open a read-only detail view first and allow me to click Edit from that view.  
Feature9: As a user, I want global search filters to persist for my current session so I don’t have to reapply them repeatedly.  
Feature10: As a user, I want to import clients, policies, and claims via CSV so I can bulk-load data.  
Feature11: As a user, I want to export clients, policies, and claims to CSV so I can use the data outside the app.  
Feature12: As a user, I want to perform simple mass updates (status changes and agent reassignment) on clients/policies/claims so I can update many records efficiently.  
Feature13: As a user, I want optional bulk link/unlink actions across records (clients/policies/claims) to speed up association changes (TBD).  
Feature14: As a user, I want configurable create/edit forms where required vs optional fields can be adjusted later without a major rebuild (TBD: configuration mechanism/roles).  
Feature15: As a user, I want a Reports section with basic analytics dashboards showing policy counts, claim counts, and claim amounts.  
Feature16: As a user, I want analytics filtered by date range, agent, and status, with monthly granularity.  
Feature17: As a user, I want a simple left navigation with top-level sections for Clients, Policies, Claims, and Reports, with global search prominent.  
Feature18: As a user, I want the UI to use dark cyan as the primary accent color for key actions/highlights and a light, clean theme with a whitesmoke (#F5F5F5) navigation bar.  
Feature19: As a user, I want standard success/warning/error state colors and hover/active states derived from the dark cyan accent.  
Feature20: As a user, I want the UI to be generally readable and usable, meeting WCAG AA where feasible without significant extra effort (TBD).

initial_requirements: I need a poll website for users to cast their votes.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse different voting options on the website, so that I can choose which option to vote for.
As a user, I want to vote for a selected option, so that my choice is recorded in the poll.
As a user, I want to view the voting results, so that I can see the outcome of the poll.
As a user, I want the website background to be colored white, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the component styles to be navy, so that the visual appearance of components matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: When creating a poll, what fields and workflow should the poll creator go through (e.g., question text, list of options, end date/time, single vs multiple choice), and should they be able to edit or delete the poll after it’s published?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact poll-creation workflow details right now. As long as creators can add a question, options, and an end time, and can edit or delete if needed, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to vote and view poll results without logging in, or do you require accounts/login (and if so, what roles like admin/creator/voter do you need)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about login/accounts right now. If it’s simpler, let people vote and view results without logging in.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like a simple browse page where people can quickly scan all active polls (with a search box and maybe basic filters like “ending soon”) before they decide which one to vote on.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the simple browse page for active polls, what other core pages or navigation elements do you want (e.g., a home page, a page for closed polls, a way to get from a poll’s detail page back to the list), and how should users move between them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact site map. Just make sure it’s easy to go from the active polls list to a poll detail page and back, and maybe have a simple section for closed polls/results.

conversation.interviewer: When a user is on the active-polls list and clicks a specific poll, what exactly should happen—should it open a dedicated poll detail page (with question, options, and results), and from that page what is the main way you want them to return to the list (e.g., a “Back to polls” link, browser back only, breadcrumb)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact behavior there. A dedicated poll detail page is fine, and just include a clear “Back to polls” link so it’s easy to return.

conversation.interviewer: On the active polls browse page, do you want polls shown as a simple chronological list (e.g., newest first) or primarily sorted by “ending soon” by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the default sort. If you need to pick one, “ending soon” by default is fine, as long as users can switch to newest.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any more interaction details right now. Just keep it simple and easy to use.

conversation.interviewer: What core entities do you need the system to store besides Poll, Option, and Vote (e.g., Poll category/tag, creator name, comments), or are those three sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra entities right now—Poll, Option, and Vote are probably enough to start. Maybe add an optional category/tag later if it’s easy, but it’s not required.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like polls to be grouped on the browse page—just “Active” vs “Closed,” or do you want categories/tags as the primary grouping from the start?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about grouping beyond a simple “Active” vs “Closed” split for now. Categories/tags can wait until later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I think we’re good on content for now: poll question, options, end time, and results display are the main things. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color should the site use for interactive components like buttons and links?
conversation.user: Let’s use a navy accent color for buttons and links.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme (for example, meeting WCAG AA for text and buttons), or is “reasonably easy to read for most users” sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific accessibility standards right now. Just make it reasonably easy to read for most users.

conversation.interviewer: What overall page background color would you like (e.g., white, light gray), and should that same background be used across all pages and sections of the site?
conversation.user: Let’s go with a clean white background overall, and yeah—use the same background across all pages for consistency.

conversation.interviewer: What base color should key UI components like cards/panels and the top navigation bar use (e.g., white, very light gray, or navy)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of styling detail. If you need a default, use very light gray for cards/panels and keep the top nav white with navy accents.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond using the same white page background, do you want button and link styles (color, hover/active states, and corner radius) to remain identical across all pages and both desktop and mobile?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about those detailed button/link style rules. Just keep them consistent across pages and have reasonable hover states, desktop and mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for UI states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those be derived from the navy accent color or chosen independently?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a full UI state color system right now. If you need something, just derive hover/active from the navy and use standard success/error colors.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any more style details right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a poll creator, I want to create a poll with a question, multiple options, and an end date/time so people can vote before it closes.  
Feature2: As a poll creator, I want to edit an existing poll after publishing so I can correct or update it.  
Feature3: As a poll creator, I want to delete a poll so I can remove it if needed.  
Feature4: As a voter, I want to browse all active polls in a simple list so I can quickly find something to vote on.  
Feature5: As a voter, I want to search active polls by text so I can quickly locate a specific poll.  
Feature6: As a voter, I want to filter/sort active polls (including an “ending soon” view and a “newest” view) so I can prioritize what to vote on.  
Feature7: As a voter, I want to open a dedicated poll detail page from the active polls list so I can read the question and see the options.  
Feature8: As a voter, I want to cast a vote on a poll without logging in so voting is simple. (TBD: vote limits/anti-duplicate voting)  
Feature9: As a voter, I want to view poll results so I can see how votes are distributed. (TBD: whether results are shown before poll end)  
Feature10: As a user, I want a clear “Back to polls” link on the poll detail page so I can easily return to the list.  
Feature11: As a user, I want to browse closed polls/results in a simple section separate from active polls so I can find completed poll outcomes.  
Feature12: As a user, I want a clean, consistent UI with a white page background, navy accents for buttons/links, and very light gray cards/panels so the site feels simple and consistent.

initial_requirements: I need a community website that provides access to promotions and discounts, while also supporting administrative management.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse promotions, so that I can see the available promotions and discounts.
As a user, I want to share promotions, so that I can contribute promotions and discounts to the community.
As a user, I want to search for promotions, so that I can find promotions of interest.
As an administrator, I want a management backend for managing users, so that I can administer user-related aspects of the website.
As an administrator, I want a management backend for managing promotions, so that I can administer promotion-related content on the website.
As an administrator, I want a management backend for managing website settings, so that I can configure the website.
As a user, I want the website’s outer layout to use an ivory color, so that the overall layout follows the specified appearance.
As a user, I want the UI blocks to use a forest green color, so that the interface elements follow the specified appearance.

conversation.interviewer: What specific admin management workflows do you need (e.g., creating/editing promotions, approving community-submitted deals, managing users/roles, handling reports), and who should be able to perform each?
conversation.user: Admins should be able to create/edit/schedule promotions, set eligibility/usage limits, and feature or expire deals. I also need a moderation queue where admins (and moderators) can approve/reject community-submitted deals and handle reports/flagged content. Only admins should manage users/roles and site-wide settings; moderators can review submissions/reports but not change settings or roles.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond promotions and user accounts, which other entities (e.g., merchants/brands, categories/tags, promo codes, locations) need their own create/edit/delete/archive or activate/deactivate operations, and what specific operations should be supported for each?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about managing a bunch of other entities right now. Maybe just basic categories/tags and merchants so deals can be organized, but it can be simple create/edit/disable—nothing too elaborate.

conversation.interviewer: What admin oversight/audit controls do you need—for example, should the system keep an immutable audit log of admin/moderator actions (who did what and when), and do you want confirmation/approval steps for high-risk actions like role changes or bulk deal expirations?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about heavy audit/approval workflows right now. A basic activity log of admin/mod actions (who/what/when) would be nice, but I don’t need immutable logs or multi-step approvals at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—search should be fast and forgiving: a single search bar that supports typo-tolerant keywords and auto-suggest, with quick filters for category/tag, merchant, and “active only,” and results updating instantly as you type.

conversation.interviewer: When a user applies filters (like category, merchant, “active only”), should those filters persist across page refreshes and navigation (e.g., remembered for that user/session), or reset back to defaults each time they return to search?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. Defaulting back to a clean search is fine for now.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—make submitting a deal really quick: a simple form with merchant, title, discount details, link/photo, and optional tags, with auto-fill suggestions and a clear “pending approval” status after I post it.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of community interaction features do you want around deals—such as comments, upvotes/downvotes, “like/save” actions, reporting/flagging by users, or following merchants/tags—and which of these, if any, are must‑haves for the first version?
conversation.user: I don’t care about a bunch of community features for v1. Must-haves are just save/bookmark deals and a simple report/flag button; comments/voting/following can wait.

conversation.interviewer: When submitting a deal, which fields should be required versus optional (merchant, title, discount details, link, photo, tags)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about strict required vs optional fields right now. If you need defaults: require merchant, title, and discount details; make link/photo/tags optional.

conversation.interviewer: For deals and promotions, which items should move through an explicit multi-step status workflow (e.g., draft → scheduled → active → expired for promos; submitted → pending review → approved/rejected → published for community deals), and what exact statuses do you want?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super detailed multi-step workflow right now. For promos, draft/scheduled/active/expired is enough; for community deals, submitted (pending review) → approved/published or rejected works for me.
