initial_requirements: I need a cryptocurrency escrow system that lets me safely buy and sell cryptocurrencies.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use a cryptocurrency escrow system for secure cryptocurrency transactions, so that my cryptocurrency trades are protected.
As a buyer, I want to browse sellers’ cryptocurrency products, so that I can see what is available for purchase.
As a buyer, I want to conduct transactions for selected cryptocurrency products, so that I can purchase them through the system.
As a buyer, I want to deposit cryptocurrencies into an escrow account, so that the funds are held securely during the transaction.
As a seller, I want to view my cryptocurrency products, so that I can see what I am offering for sale.
As a seller, I want to manage my cryptocurrency products, so that I can maintain and update my offerings.
As a seller, I want to view my transaction records, so that I can track my past and current transactions.
As a seller, I want to manage my transaction records, so that I can organize and handle my transaction history.
As a user, I want the system to provide transaction confirmation functionality, so that I can know the status of my transactions.
As a user, I want the system to provide cryptocurrency release functionality, so that cryptocurrencies can be released from escrow when appropriate.
As a user, I want the system to provide dispute resolution functionality, so that any issues with transactions can be addressed.
As a user, I want the system’s background color to be initialized with light gray, so that the interface follows the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the system’s component color to be initialized with dark red, so that the interface components follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want users to place, track, modify, and complete escrow orders—for example, should they be able to create multiple open escrows, cancel or edit terms before funding, and see a status timeline (pending, funded, in dispute, released, expired)?
conversation.user: Users should be able to create multiple open escrows and track them in a dashboard with a clear status timeline (created/pending, funded, released, disputed, canceled/expired). They can edit terms or cancel only before the buyer funds the escrow; once funded, changes require both parties to approve. Completion should be explicit: seller marks delivered, buyer releases (or auto-release after a set window), with a dispute button available after funding.

conversation.interviewer: Which stages and transitions should exist in the lifecycle of an order or booking (e.g. draft, pending, confirmed, completed, cancelled)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a generic “booking” lifecycle—what matters is the escrow lifecycle we already described (created/pending, funded, released, disputed, canceled/expired). As long as it follows that flow, the naming of other stages isn’t important to me.

conversation.interviewer: What payment methods and on-chain flows do you want to support for funding and releasing escrows (e.g., which blockchains/tokens, direct wallet-to-escrow smart contract payments, time limits/expiry for funding, and whether partial or top-up payments are allowed)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specific blockchains/tokens or the exact on-chain flow right now—just make it flexible enough to add chains later. The key for me is that funding and release are secure and traceable, with a reasonable funding expiry and no partial payments unless it’s necessary.

conversation.interviewer: What authentication and user role setup do you want—for example, should users sign up with email/phone/crypto wallet, must they pass KYC or real-name checks before using escrow, and do you need distinct roles like buyer, seller, moderator/arbitrator, and admin with different permissions?
conversation.user: I’d like users to be able to sign up with email plus connect a crypto wallet. KYC should be required before they can fund or withdraw from an escrow (browsing/creating can be allowed without it). Roles: buyer/seller (same user can be both), plus an arbitrator/moderator role for disputes and a separate admin role for system settings/audit.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic KYC, do you want any stronger identity verification such as real-name confirmation with government ID matching, liveness or selfie checks, and if so, for which actions (e.g., opening disputes, high-value escrows, or withdrawals above a threshold)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding stronger ID checks beyond basic KYC right now. If we do it later, it should be optional or only kick in for high-value withdrawals, but it’s not a priority for me.

conversation.interviewer: During initial sign‑up (before KYC and funding), what exact steps and information do you want to require from a new user—such as email verification, password setup, wallet connection, acceptance of terms, or any manual approval—before they can access the platform dashboard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact sign-up steps as long as it’s simple—email verification, password, accept terms, and optionally connect a wallet sounds fine. No manual approval needed just to access the dashboard.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific interaction detail like search or button behavior right now. Just keep the UI simple and responsive enough to use on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the system to explicitly model and store (for example, escrow contracts, users, wallets/addresses, disputes, messages, KYC records), and how should these be logically grouped or related to each other in your data model?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model details. As long as you store users (with linked wallets and KYC status), escrows with their status/history, and disputes/messages for auditability, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What specific audit trail and history details do you want to keep for each escrow and dispute (e.g., every status change, who performed it, timestamps, IP/device), and who should be able to see that history (all parties, admins only, arbitrators, or some combination)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about super granular audit details like IP/device right now. Just log every status change and key action with who did it and timestamps, and let both parties see the escrow history while admins/arbitrators can see everything (including dispute notes).

conversation.interviewer: Should escrow history and dispute history be viewable directly in the UI only, or do you also need export/download access (e.g., CSV/PDF) for users, admins, and arbitrators?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about export/download right now—viewing the history in the UI is enough. If it’s easy to add later, maybe admins could export, but it’s not a priority.

conversation.interviewer: For each individual escrow record shown in the dashboard, what exact fields do you want visible at a glance (for example, asset and amount, counterparties, current status, key timestamps like created/funded/released, and any reference labels or notes)?
conversation.user: At a glance I want: escrow ID/reference label, asset + amount, buyer and seller usernames (and short wallet/address snippet), current status, and key timestamps (created, funded, released/expired). Also show dispute flag/indicator, who has the next action (e.g., “awaiting buyer release”), and a clickable tx hash/confirmation link for funding/release so I can verify on-chain.

conversation.interviewer: Besides users, escrows, disputes, and their message histories, are there any other types of records you explicitly want the system to store and track over time (for example, system-wide financial summaries, fee/commission records, or policy/terms changes)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about tracking extra record types like global financial summaries or policy versioning right now. If you’re already storing per-escrow fees and payout transactions for audit, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond individual escrows and disputes, do you also want an audit trail for system‑level configuration and data changes (e.g., fee settings, role/permission changes, manual balance adjustments), and if so, what specific details about each change (who changed what and when) must be stored and reviewable?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a full system-level audit trail right now. If you already log who changed fee settings/roles and when (basic admin change log), that’s fine, but it’s not a priority.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content requirement: I want detailed seller listings attached to an escrow offer—coin/token, network, price/rate, min/max, payment/settlement terms, required confirmations, and seller notes. Also show seller reputation basics (completed trades, dispute rate) on the listing.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the app’s main navigation/page hierarchy organized—for example, which top-level sections should exist (e.g., Dashboard, Browse Offers, Create Offer, Messages/Disputes, Wallet/KYC, Settings/Admin), and which items should be grouped together?
conversation.user: Top-level: Dashboard (my escrows + status), Browse Offers (search/filter), My Offers (create/manage listings), Messages/Disputes (chat + open disputes), Wallet & KYC (connect wallet, verification, deposits/withdrawals), and Settings. Admins/arbitrators should see an extra Admin/Arbitration section for dispute queue, user/KYC review, and basic config like fees/roles.

conversation.interviewer: For each main area (e.g., Browse Offers, seller listings, basic seller reputation, individual escrow details, dispute threads), what should be publicly viewable without login, what should be visible only to logged-in users, and what—if anything—should be restricted further to just the parties involved or admins/arbitrators?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on public vs logged-in visibility right now. Just use common sense: browsing offers can be public, but escrow details, messages, and disputes should be private to the parties, with admins/arbitrators able to see disputes as needed.

conversation.interviewer: Should the information architecture use separate dedicated sections/pages for each role (e.g., a distinct Arbitrator/Admin area), or should everyone use the same pages with role-based controls and visibility within them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. Just make sure admins/arbitrators have a clearly separated area for their tools so regular users don’t see clutter or sensitive controls.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any more content/display requirements right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on key components like primary buttons, links, and status highlights (for example, a particular color family or brand color you want us to follow)?
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like the primary accent to be a dark red/burgundy across primary buttons, links, and status highlights. Keep it consistent and make sure contrast/accessibility is solid on both light and dark backgrounds.

conversation.interviewer: What specific accessibility standard or target contrast ratio (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA with 4.5:1 for normal text) should the burgundy accent and related UI colors meet across light and dark themes?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific standard or exact contrast ratio. Just make it comfortably readable in both light and dark themes and follow common accessibility best practices.

initial_requirements: I need a website that helps me compare product prices across different states and find the best deals.
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to automatically search product prices across different states, so that I can view price information from multiple regions in one place.
As a user, I want the website to compare product prices across different states, so that I can understand how prices differ between locations.
As a user, I want the website to find the lowest-priced products across different states, so that I can identify the cheapest options available.
As a user, I want to select specific product categories on the website, so that I can narrow down the products I am searching and comparing.
As a user, I want to select specific product parameters on the website, so that I can refine the search results according to my needs.
As a user, I want the website to provide detailed product information including price, so that I can understand how much each product costs.
As a user, I want the website to provide detailed product information including quantity, so that I can know how much product is being offered at the given price.
As a user, I want the website to provide detailed product information including supplier information, so that I can know who is offering the product.
As a user, I want the website’s canvas background to use a seashell color, so that the background appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want all visible components on the website to use a crimson color, so that the components’ appearance matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: What filters should users be able to apply when searching prices across states (e.g., state/zip radius, store, product variant, price range, shipping cost, in-stock only), and should those filters persist between searches?
conversation.user: Filters should include state, zip/radius, store/retailer, product variant (size/color/model), price range, shipping/taxes, and an in-stock only toggle. I’d also like category + brand filters and the ability to sort by total delivered price. Yes, filters should persist between searches, at least for the session, with an option to reset.

conversation.interviewer: Should filter changes auto-apply immediately to update results, or should users make selections and then click an Apply/Update Results button?
conversation.user: I’d prefer auto-apply for most filters so results update right away, but for heavier ones like zip/radius or multiple store selections, an Apply button (or an “Update results” prompt) would be better. A small debounce/loading indicator would be nice so it doesn’t feel jumpy.

conversation.interviewer: Besides sorting by total delivered price, what other sort options should be available for results (e.g., base price only, distance, rating, store name), and should users be able to sort each of these both ascending and descending?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much beyond sorting by total delivered price. If you include a couple basics like base price and maybe distance, that’s enough—ascending/descending isn’t critical to me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the price comparison results displayed—e.g., a table with key columns per retailer, or a list of product cards—and do you prefer infinite scroll or paginated pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact layout—table or cards is fine. Same with infinite scroll vs pagination; just make it easy to scan and compare total delivered price quickly.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a keyword/text search box, and if so which fields should it search (e.g., product name, SKU/UPC, brand, model number)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a keyword search box. If it’s easy to add, just have it search product name and UPC/SKU, but it’s not a must-have for me.

conversation.interviewer: Should the keyword search (if included) always search only product name and UPC/SKU, or should users be able to choose additional fields (e.g., brand, model) from a “search in” selector?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a “search in” selector. If you include search, just keep it simple—product name + UPC/SKU is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any extra interaction requirements. Just keep it snappy and don’t make me click a bunch of extra steps to see the updated prices.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to move between the main parts of the site—for example, from a “home/search” view to results and then to a specific retailer’s offer—and are there any core pages or navigation elements (like a persistent top nav, sidebar, or breadcrumbs) you definitely want or don’t want?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation as long as it’s straightforward. A simple top nav (Home/Search, Results, maybe Saved/Watchlist) is fine, and clicking an offer should take me to the retailer in a new tab so I don’t lose my results.

conversation.interviewer: What are the must-have core pages/sections for end users (e.g., Home/Search, Results, Product detail, Saved/Watchlist), and which one should be the default landing page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about specific pages. At minimum I want a Home/Search and a Results page, and maybe a Saved/Watchlist if it’s easy. Default landing page should just be Home/Search.

conversation.interviewer: When a user is viewing a list of product offers, do you want clicking a specific product or offer to open a dedicated detail view within your site (showing richer info, price history, alerts, etc.) before sending them to the retailer, or should it always go directly from the list to the retailer’s site?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple detail view in our site first so I can see key info like quantity/size, supplier/retailer details, and the total delivered price clearly. Then have a prominent “Go to retailer” link that opens in a new tab.

conversation.interviewer: How should users browse and discover products—do you want a category/brand directory to browse (e.g., electronics → TVs), or should discovery be primarily search/filter-driven with optional “popular deals”/featured lists?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a full browse directory. I’ll mostly use search/filters, and if it’s easy, a simple “popular deals” or featured list on the home page would be nice.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to switch between the main modules (Home/Search, Results, Saved/Watchlist)—for example, using top navigation tabs, a sidebar, or a dropdown?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—top nav tabs are fine as long as it’s obvious and quick to switch between Home/Search, Results, and Saved/Watchlist.

conversation.interviewer: Will this product be web-only, or do you also anticipate mobile apps or other entry points (like embedded views, mini-apps, or kiosk/large-screen modes), and if so, should navigation behave consistently across them or be optimized differently per platform?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about mobile apps or other entry points right now—web-only is fine. Just make the site mobile-responsive so it works well on a phone browser.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any extra interaction requirements beyond keeping it fast and not making me click through a bunch of steps to see updated prices.

conversation.interviewer: Will any users need to switch between different contexts—like multiple user accounts, organizations, or data sets (e.g., personal vs business profiles)—within a single session, and if so, what kinds of contexts should they be able to switch between from the navigation?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about switching between accounts or organizations—this is just for a single personal use case. No need for multi-context switching in the navigation.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users to be able to create and organize multiple custom views or “saved setups” of filters/results (e.g., different state/store combos), with the ability to reorder or group them, or is a single view per session sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about multiple custom views or saved setups. A single view per session is fine, and maybe a simple Saved/Watchlist later if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users to log in or create accounts at all, or should the site work fully anonymously—and if accounts are needed, what basic roles or permissions (if any) should exist beyond a standard individual user?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about logins or roles. I’d prefer it works anonymously by default, and if you add accounts later it can just be a basic single user—no special permissions needed.

conversation.interviewer: When a user saves an item to the Saved/Watchlist, what fields should they be able to enter or edit (e.g., desired price/threshold, preferred state/zip/store, notes), and should they be able to add/remove multiple items in bulk?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about editable fields in a watchlist. If you include it, just let me save/remove items and maybe add an optional target price and a short note—bulk add/remove isn’t important.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to send any emails or notifications at all (for example, alerts when a watched item drops below your target price), and if so, what specific types of price or deal alerts should it support?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about emails/notifications right now. If it’s easy later, a simple alert when a watched item drops below my target price would be the only one I’d use.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any configurable business rules for how prices are evaluated or highlighted (for example, letting you define your own rule like “treat shipping over $X as a penalty” or “only show offers where tax is below Y%”), or should all comparison logic be fixed and the same for every user?
conversation.user: I don’t really need configurable business rules—fixed comparison logic is fine. Just make sure it clearly highlights the lowest total delivered price (including shipping/taxes), and maybe a simple toggle to exclude crazy-high shipping if that’s easy.

task_name: Custom Shirt E-Commerce Design and Ordering System
initial_requirements: I need an online shirt customization feature where I can customize a shirt, preview and confirm the design, and then place and pay for my order.
user_stories: As a user, I want to customize shirts in an e-commerce integration feature, so that I can personalize the shirts I purchase.
As a user, I want to input the shirt model, so that my selected model is used for my customized shirt.
As a user, I want to input the shirt fabric, so that my selected fabric is used for my customized shirt.
As a user, I want to input my measurements, so that the shirt is tailored to my size.
As a user, I want the system to generate a corresponding shirt design based on my input, so that I can see how my customized shirt will look.
As a user, I want to preview the generated shirt design, so that I can review it before confirming my order.
As a user, I want to confirm the generated shirt design, so that the final shirt matches my approved design.
As a user, I want the system to handle my orders, so that I can place and manage purchases for customized shirts.
As a user, I want the system to handle payments, so that I can pay for my customized shirt orders.
As a user, I want the global background color of the interface to be floral white, so that the visual appearance matches the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want all UI pieces to use dark goldenrod, so that the interface elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What order lifecycle do you want users to follow after confirming the shirt design (e.g., add to cart → checkout → payment → order confirmation), and should they be able to manage orders afterward (view status, edit/cancel, reorder)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a complex order lifecycle—just a straightforward checkout after they confirm the design, then payment and an order confirmation. Basic order status tracking is nice, but editing/canceling/reordering isn’t important to me right now.

conversation.interviewer: When customizing a shirt, what specific editing and preview capabilities do you want—for example, should users be able to zoom, rotate the shirt, switch between front/back/sleeves, adjust or move text/images, and see a real-time preview that updates with every change?
conversation.user: I want real-time preview updates as they change things, with the ability to rotate/zoom and switch between front and back (sleeves optional). Editing-wise, they should be able to pick the shirt model, fabric, and enter personal measurements, plus basic placement/resize for text or an uploaded image/logo.

conversation.interviewer: For the text and image/logo on the shirt, what specific editing tools and granularity do you want users to have (e.g., precise drag-and-drop positioning, rotation, layer ordering, color and font selection, alignment guides, undo/redo)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about super-granular editing tools right now. Basic drag-and-drop positioning, resize, and simple font/color selection is enough—undo/redo and alignment guides aren’t important to me.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the live shirt view during customization, in which other contexts (e.g., a final “review order” screen, downloadable proof, or email preview) should users be able to see a full preview of their customized shirt before they finalize payment?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra preview contexts like downloadable proofs or email previews. Just showing the final design on a simple “review order” screen right before payment is enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details like navigation or button behavior right now—just make it feel reasonably fast and responsive during customization.

conversation.interviewer: From where should users be able to add images/logos into the shirt customizer (e.g., upload from their device, from a gallery you provide), and do you want any built-in option to share or export their customized design (e.g., download image, share link), or none at all?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sharing/exporting right now. Just let users upload an image/logo from their device; a provided gallery would be nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One interaction thing I’d like: after I pick the model/fabric/measurements and add my text or logo, the system should auto-generate a clean default layout/design for me to start from, and then I can make small tweaks.

conversation.interviewer: When users enter their measurements and customization options, do you want this to be a single, streamlined form with minimal required fields, or a step-by-step workflow (e.g., pick model → choose fabric → enter measurements → add text/logo), and are there any specific fields or steps that are mandatory for you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s one form or step-by-step, as long as it’s quick and not tedious. The only stuff that needs to be mandatory is choosing the shirt model and size/measurements; everything else can be optional.

conversation.interviewer: Besides selecting the shirt model and entering size/measurements, what other data fields (if any) should the customizer collect—e.g., fabric choice, color, quantity, custom notes—and which of those should be optional versus required?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about collecting a bunch of extra fields right now. If anything, fabric and color can be optional, quantity can default to 1 (optional to change), and an optional notes field is fine.

conversation.interviewer: When should the system auto-generate the default layout—immediately after the user finishes adding model/size (and any text/logo), or only when they click a “Generate layout” button?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much, but I’d prefer it auto-generates immediately once they’ve picked the model/size and added text or a logo—no extra button needed. A “Regenerate” button could be nice if they want a different starting layout.

conversation.interviewer: When users upload their logo/image for the shirt, how should the system handle those files—should uploads be stored for later reuse in their account, cached only for the current session, and/or be available for them to download/export as a rendered mockup image, and do you have any limits or rules in mind (e.g., max file size, allowed formats)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about storing uploads for later reuse or letting users download/export mockups right now. Just handle uploads for the current session, and maybe support common formats like PNG/JPG with a reasonable size limit (like ~5–10MB).

conversation.interviewer: Besides PNG and JPG images for logos, are there any other specific file types or sources you want supported for shirt customization (e.g., SVG for vector logos, PDF, or pulling images from cloud storage like Google Drive), or should it be limited strictly to PNG/JPG uploads from the user’s device?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting extra file types or cloud sources right now. Keeping it to PNG/JPG uploads from the user’s device is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the ~5–10MB limit you mentioned, do you want to restrict users to uploading only one logo/image per shirt at a time, or should they be able to upload multiple files in a single operation, and if so, how many?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of restriction right now. If it’s simpler, just allow one image upload per shirt for now.

conversation.interviewer: After users submit their custom shirt order, if something goes wrong (e.g., payment fails or validation errors on measurements), what follow-up options should they have on that screen—such as simply fixing the highlighted fields and resubmitting, retrying payment, or contacting support from there?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy follow-up flows right now. Just let them fix any highlighted errors and retry payment; contact support from that screen isn’t important to me.

conversation.interviewer: When users change configuration-related options (like default fabric, color, or quantity), do you want those changes applied instantly as they click/select them, or should there be a separate “Save/Apply settings” step before the changes take effect?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If you need a default, just apply changes instantly as they select them so it feels fast.

conversation.interviewer: After the user confirms the shirt design, do you want the checkout to be a defined multi-step flow with explicit stages (e.g., shipping info → payment → confirmation), or a single combined checkout page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s multi-step or a single page. Just keep it straightforward and quick—shipping info, payment, then confirmation.

conversation.interviewer: For shirt designs and orders, which specific create/read/update/delete actions do you want users to perform (e.g., save a design, duplicate a design, delete a design or order, bulk select and delete multiple designs/orders at once), and which of these are actually needed in the first version?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about CRUD-style actions for designs/orders in the first version. For now, just let users create a design during checkout, place the order, and maybe view the order status afterward—no save/duplicate/delete or bulk actions needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any business rules or constraints for customization options (e.g., limiting certain fabrics/colors to specific shirt models, restricting logo placement/size, or enforcing measurement ranges), and if so, what are they?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed business rules for the first version. Just have some basic sanity checks, like reasonable measurement ranges and preventing the logo from being scaled so big it goes off the shirt.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main pages and navigation of the shirt customizer to be organized—for example, do you want separate pages like “Choose Shirt,” “Customize,” “Review Order,” and “Checkout” linked by a simple top/bottom progress bar, or a single customizer page with smaller sub-sections or tabs?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how you organize the pages or navigation right now. Just keep it simple and quick—choose shirt, customize, review, checkout—whatever structure makes that flow smooth.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users to be able to customize and purchase shirts as guests without creating an account, or should they be required to register/log in (and if so, do you need any specific roles like admin/production staff with different permissions)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about accounts or roles right now. Guest checkout is fine, and we can add logins/admin roles later if needed.

initial_requirements: I need a website that helps me find and book short-term rental apartments.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse different types of apartments, so that I can see the available options for short-term rentals.
As a user, I want to search for apartments, so that I can quickly find apartments that match my needs.
As a user, I want to filter apartments based on my criteria, so that I can narrow down the list to suitable options.
As a user, I want to book selected apartments, so that I can reserve an apartment for my short-term stay.
As a user, I want to view my booking records, so that I can review my current and past apartment bookings.
As a user, I want the website to use a linen screen background, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want component highlights on the website to be maroon, so that the highlighted elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the booking flow and management to work—from selecting dates and confirming a reservation to modifying/canceling bookings and receiving status updates (e.g., instant booking vs. host approval, cancellation rules, and notifications)?
conversation.user: I want a simple flow: pick dates, see total price and rules upfront, then confirm and pay. Ideally most listings are instant book, but if host approval is needed I should see the pending status and get email/SMS + in-app notifications for any changes. I also need an account page with full booking history (past and upcoming), and the ability to modify/cancel within the stated cancellation policy with automatic refunds where applicable.

conversation.interviewer: Which payment methods do you want to support at checkout (e.g., credit/debit cards, Apple Pay/Google Pay, PayPal, bank transfer)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which methods you support as long as I can pay easily—credit/debit cards and Apple Pay/Google Pay would be enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the basic cancellation policy, are there any specific business rules you want for bookings—such as minimum/maximum stay length, cutoff time before check‑in for making or modifying a booking, or limits on how far in advance users can book?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific business rules like min/max nights or cutoff times—those can just follow whatever each listing sets. As long as the rules are shown clearly before I book, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like browsing by apartment type to be front and center (like Studios, 1BR, 2BR, etc.), so I can tap a type and immediately see available places for my dates without digging through filters.

conversation.interviewer: When a user books an apartment, do you want them to go straight from selecting a listing to confirming and paying (no cart or bundling multiple stays), or should there be any kind of cart/multi-booking flow?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a cart or multi-booking flow. Going straight from a listing to confirm-and-pay is totally fine for me.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I’d like a prominent search bar that lets me quickly search by city/neighborhood/address, with date + guest count right there, and shows results fast as I type.

conversation.interviewer: When users adjust search filters (e.g., apartment type, price, amenities), should those filter selections persist as they browse listings and come back to results, or reset each time they start a new search?
conversation.user: I’d like filters to persist while I’m browsing and when I go back to the results, so I don’t lose my setup. If I start a totally new search (new city/dates), you can reset them but maybe keep my last-used filters as a quick option.

conversation.interviewer: Should filter changes auto-apply to the results immediately, or should users set filters and then tap an “Apply” button to update results?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either is fine. If you pick one, I’d lean toward auto-apply as long as it feels fast and doesn’t jump around too much.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond searching by location, dates, and guest count, what specific keywords or fields should users be able to search on (for example, apartment name, host name, amenities, landmarks, or free-text keywords in the description)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about advanced keyword search. Location + dates + guests plus filters for type/price/amenities is enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific filters should users have available on search results (e.g., price range, amenities, rating, instant book only, cancellation flexibility)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care exactly which filters you include, as long as the basics are there—price range, apartment type, amenities, and maybe an “instant book only” toggle.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the search results themselves to be presented and organized—for example, a scrollable list, a list plus map, or another layout, and should key details like price per night and total stay cost be visible at a glance in each result?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact layout. As long as I can scroll results easily and see the nightly price, total cost for my dates, apartment type, and whether it’s instant book at a glance, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: What primary navigation structure do you want across the site (e.g., top nav or bottom tabs), and which core pages should it include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a top nav or tabs. Just make it easy to get to Search/Browse, Favorites, My Trips/Bookings, Messages/Notifications, and Account.

conversation.interviewer: Should there be a separate Host/Admin section, and if so what are the main pages it needs (e.g., listing management, booking approvals, payouts, messaging, support)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a Host/Admin section for my needs—I’m just booking as a guest. If you do include it, keep it basic for hosts: manage listings, approve bookings if needed, and messaging.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond apartment-type shortcuts (Studios, 1BR, 2BR, etc.), how would you like the overall browsing experience to be structured—should users mainly explore through categorized sections (e.g., “City areas,” “Popular neighborhoods,” “Top picks”), a single scrolling results list, or some other discovery view?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact discovery structure. As long as I can quickly search by location/dates and browse by apartment type without extra steps, whatever layout you choose is fine.

conversation.interviewer: When a user taps a listing in the search/browse results, what exactly should the detail page let them do beyond viewing photos and description—for example, should it provide direct access to booking, messaging the host, and viewing the location on a map from that detail view?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about all the extras on the detail page. As long as I can see the price/total for my dates, the rules, and book right from there, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want an in-app messaging/chat feature between guests and hosts (with message history), or should communication be limited to booking-related notifications only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about in-app chat. Booking-related notifications are enough for me, and if you add messaging it can be pretty basic.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to sort the search results, and if so which sort options should be available (e.g., lowest total price, highest rating, distance, newest)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sorting options that much. If you include it, lowest total price and highest rating would be the only ones I’d actually use.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to limit or expand the scope of a search (for example, searching only within their saved favorites vs. searching all listings), or should all searches always run across all available listings by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that. Defaulting searches to all listings is fine, and if you add a favorites-only toggle that’s nice but not something I need.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between the main sections (Search/Browse, Favorites, My Trips/Bookings, Notifications, Account)—for example via persistent tabs, a top navigation bar, or a hamburger/side menu?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how you do it—tabs, top nav, or a menu are all fine. Just make it obvious and quick to get to those main sections.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like authentication and user accounts to work—do you want simple email/password login only, or options like Google/Apple login, and do you need any identity verification (e.g., verified ID) or role distinctions beyond “regular guest user”?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the auth details. Email/password is fine, and if you add Google/Apple login that’s a nice bonus; I don’t need ID verification or extra roles beyond a regular guest.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me search and lease domain names, keep track of the domains I’ve leased, and handle payments and account management in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to search for domain names, so that I can find domains available for leasing.
As a user, I want to lease domain names, so that I can temporarily use domains I select.
As a user, I want to renew leased domain names, so that I can extend the leasing period of my domains.
As a user, I want to transfer domain names, so that I can move domains between accounts or owners as needed.
As a user, I want to view domain information, so that I can understand the details of each domain.
As a user, I want to view my domain leasing records, so that I can track my past and current domain leases.
As a user, I want user management functionality to be available, so that user accounts and related information can be managed.
As a user, I want payment management functionality to be available, so that payments related to domain leasing can be managed.
As a user, I want the website layout background to use old lace, so that the visual background appearance matches that style.
As a user, I want component details to use rosy brown, so that the visual appearance of components matches that style.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the ordering and leasing flow to work from the user’s perspective—for example, steps from selecting a domain, reserving it, confirming the lease duration, to managing, renewing, or canceling existing leases?
conversation.user: I’d like it to feel like a simple checkout: search/select a domain, see availability and price tiers, pick lease length and options (auto-renew on/off), then pay and get a clear confirmation. After that, a dashboard should show each leased domain with explicit buttons to renew, extend, upgrade/downgrade term, transfer, or cancel, plus reminders before expiration.

conversation.interviewer: Which payment methods and payment flow do you want to support—for example, saved cards, digital wallets (Apple Pay/Google Pay), invoicing, recurring charges for auto‑renewals, and any rules like charging immediately vs. only after domain availability is confirmed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specific payment methods as long as it’s easy and secure. A standard card checkout with the option to save a card and handle auto‑renew recurring charges is enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to complete a lease as a guest, or do you want to require account creation/sign-in before checkout?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If you have to pick, I’d prefer requiring an account before checkout so leases and renewals are tied to the right user.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details like button behavior or animations—just keep it straightforward and not confusing.

conversation.interviewer: What specific data fields should the system store and display for each domain lease (e.g., domain name, registrar, lease start/end dates, renewal setting, price/tier, status, DNS/transfer info)?
conversation.user: For each lease, store/show: domain name, current status (active/expiring/cancelled), lease start date, end/next renewal date, price and tier/term length, auto‑renew on/off, payment method on file (masked) and last/next charge, and basic DNS info (nameservers) plus transfer/authorization status if applicable. Also include reminders/notifications settings and a simple notes field would be nice.

conversation.interviewer: For each core entity besides a domain lease (e.g., user account, payment method, transaction/invoice, notification/reminder, support request), what key fields must the system store?
conversation.user: User account: name, email, password/auth method, billing address/country, timezone, and notification prefs. Payment method: type (card), brand/last4/exp, billing address, and default on/off. Transaction/invoice: invoice ID, date, amount/currency, domain(s) and lease term, status (paid/failed/refunded), and receipt link. Notification/reminder: type, channel (email/SMS), schedule/lead time, and sent/delivery status. Support request: ticket ID, subject/category, related domain/lease, messages/attachments, status, and timestamps.

conversation.interviewer: For the domain lease detail page, which of the stored fields should be displayed to the user (and should any be hidden or admin-only)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about admin-only distinctions. Just show the key stuff to the user: status, start/end/next renewal date, price/tier, auto-renew, last/next charge (masked card), nameservers, and transfer/auth status; hide any sensitive payment details beyond last4.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like leased domains to be grouped or categorized in the dashboard (e.g., by status, tags/labels you define, folders/projects), if at all?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy grouping. Just give me simple filters/sorting by status (active/expiring/canceled) and maybe a basic search box; optional tags are fine but not required.

conversation.interviewer: What domain-availability, pricing, and lease/transfer status data sources should the system use (e.g., your own domain inventory database vs third‑party registrar/WHOIS APIs), and which specific provider(s) are allowed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which specific data sources or providers you use, as long as availability/pricing/status are accurate and update quickly. Just pick something reliable and secure.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any more content requirements beyond what I already listed. Happy to move on.

conversation.interviewer: What accent color should the site use for primary actions and highlights (e.g., the main “Lease now”/“Pay” buttons and selected states)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a rosy brown accent color for primary actions and highlights—things like the main “Lease now” and “Pay” buttons and selected states.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme (for example, meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and buttons), or should we just follow standard WCAG AA best practices by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific accessibility/contrast targets—just follow standard WCAG AA best practices by default.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for component states (hover, active/pressed, disabled, success, error), and if so, should those state colors be lighter/darker variations of your rosy brown accent or use distinct colors (e.g., green for success, red for errors)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a defined color system beyond the basics. Just use standard distinct colors for success/error (green/red) and simple lighter/darker variations for hover/active/disabled so it’s clear.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific interface elements you want explicitly standardized across the whole site (for example, all primary buttons, form fields, alerts, and table headers sharing the same styles), or should we just apply a single global design system consistently everywhere by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific elements to standardize—just apply one consistent global design system across the site by default.

conversation.interviewer: What base color should be used for the navigation bar background (the main header area across the site)?
conversation.user: Let’s use an old lace base color for the navigation bar background so it stays light and neutral against the rosy brown accents.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the main page background be across the site (outside the navigation bar)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact page background color. Just keep it light/neutral so the rosy brown accents and content have good contrast.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the visual theme to evoke any specific brand personality (e.g., modern/tech, premium/luxury, friendly/approachable), or should we keep it neutral and purely functional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific brand personality—just keep it neutral and purely functional, clean and easy to use.

initial_requirements: I want a consulting business website to share my leadership and business training services, where people can learn about what I offer, explore different types of content, and purchase services if they’re interested.
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to provide information about leadership and business training services, so that I can understand the consulting business offerings.
As a user, I want the website to have an e-commerce component, so that I can purchase services directly from the site.
As a user, I want the website to offer workshops, so that I can participate in structured training sessions.
As a user, I want the website to offer online classes, so that I can access training remotely.
As a user, I want the website to provide podcasts, so that I can consume audio content related to leadership and business training.
As a user, I want the website to host blogs, so that I can read written content related to leadership and business training.
As a user, I want to be able to browse the available services on the website, so that I can see what is offered before making a purchase.
As a user, I want all pages of the website to have a light cyan background, so that the overall visual style is consistent across the site.
As a user, I want the website’s components to use cadet blue, so that the interface maintains a unified and consistent appearance.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like visitors to book and purchase your services on the site—for example, should they be able to select a service, choose a time slot, pay online, and receive automatic confirmations and reminders, or do you prefer a simpler “contact request”/invoice-based process?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact booking flow right now. I’m fine starting with a simple contact request and invoice process, and we can add online scheduling and payments later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages and navigation items do you want in your site’s top menu (for example: Home, About, Services, Blog/Resources, Contact), and how would you like them organized?
conversation.user: Top menu: Home, About, Services, Resources, and Contact. Under Services I’d like dropdowns for Workshops, Online Classes, and 1:1 Coaching, and under Resources a Blog plus downloadable guides/case studies.

conversation.interviewer: Within sections like Services and Resources, how would you like visitors to browse and discover content—primarily through simple lists, category filters (e.g., by topic or audience), or something like a chronological feed or featured/highlighted items at the top?
conversation.user: I’d like featured/highlighted items at the top, then simple lists with a few category filters. For Services, filters like type (Workshop/Class/Coaching) and topic; for Resources, topic + format (blog vs guide/case study), with blog posts also viewable chronologically.

conversation.interviewer: When a visitor clicks on a specific service or resource in a list or featured section, what would you like the detail page to offer in terms of next steps—for example, links to related services/resources, a prominent contact/“book now” action, or navigation back to the relevant list or category view?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact detail-page next steps right now. As long as there’s a clear “Contact me” button and an easy way to go back to the list, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the main top-level pages and dropdowns you’ve described, do you envision needing any additional internal pages that you’ll want to group into sections and reorder within the site’s hierarchy (for example, subpages under specific workshops or resource categories), or should the structure stay as a fixed set of pages as we’ve outlined?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding extra internal pages or a more complex hierarchy right now. Let’s keep it to the fixed set of pages we outlined, and we can expand later if it becomes necessary.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details right now. Just make it feel fast and responsive, especially on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: For the overall structure of the site, how would you like key content to be grouped and surfaced—are there any specific “hub” or overview pages (for example, a single Services overview or Resources overview) you want that summarize and link into the detailed pages, or should visitors mainly discover content directly from the top menu dropdowns and lists?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific hub/overview pages right now. I’m fine with basic Services and Resources pages that list and link out to the details, and people can also use the dropdowns.

conversation.interviewer: What specific file/media types do you want to host and offer on the site (e.g., PDFs for guides/case studies, videos, slide decks, audio), and should any of them be gated behind an email signup?
conversation.user: Mostly PDFs for downloadable guides/case studies, plus blog posts and the ability to embed video (YouTube/Vimeo). I’d like the PDFs gated behind an email signup, but the blog should stay ungated.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the gated PDF guides/case studies, are there any other files or media you want visitors to be able to directly download or export (for example, slide decks, worksheets, or bundled resource packs)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about other downloadable formats right now. If it’s easy, maybe add simple PDF worksheets later, but it’s not a requirement.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like your PDFs and embedded videos to be presented on the pages—for example, as a simple text list of links, as visual cards/thumbnails, or embedded directly within articles/resources?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact presentation right now. If you pick a clean default—like visual cards/thumbnails on listing pages and embed videos within the article/resource page—that’s fine with me.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent/highlight color would you like the site to use for key components like buttons and links (e.g., navy, teal, gold, etc.)?
conversation.user: Let’s use cadet blue as the primary accent/highlight color for buttons and links so everything feels consistent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors (including the cadet-blue accents) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG AA for normal text?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific standard like WCAG AA right now. Just make sure the text and buttons are easy to read and the contrast looks good.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the cadet-blue accents, what base colors would you like for main UI components—for example, should buttons have a white or dark fill, and should cards/panels and the navigation bar be light (e.g., white/light gray) or darker tones?
conversation.user: I’d like the whole site to use a light cyan background for consistency. Keep most UI elements like nav, cards, and panels in white/light gray with cadet-blue accents, and use dark text; buttons can be cadet-blue filled with white text.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual style rules you want consistently applied across the whole site (for example, one standard button style, one heading font/size hierarchy, and uniform spacing between sections), or should the designer just define a single, consistent system for you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific visual style rules—I just want it to feel clean and consistent. Go ahead and define a single system (buttons, typography, spacing) and keep it uniform across the site.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any additional colors, patterns, or subtle decorative elements (beyond the light cyan, white/gray, and cadet blue) that you want included to better reflect your leadership/consulting brand or thematic style?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding extra colors or patterns right now. I’d prefer keeping it clean and minimal—maybe just subtle, simple accents if you think it helps, but nothing busy.

conversation.interviewer: For things like button hovers, disabled states, and success/error messages, do you want us to define a simple state color system (e.g., darker cadet blue on hover, gray for disabled, green for success, red for errors) based on your existing palette, or is it fine to choose these state colors freely as long as they stay subtle and consistent?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact state color system. Just pick subtle, consistent hover/disabled/success/error colors that fit the overall palette and stay easy to read.
