Feature22: As a user, I want resources (PDFs and videos) to be presented as clean visual cards or thumbnails on listing pages so I can scan and choose what to open.

Feature23: As a user, I want the site to feel fast and responsive, especially on mobile devices, so I can browse services and resources without delays or layout issues.

Feature24: As a user, I want the site layout to be mobile-friendly so I can easily navigate and read content on my phone or tablet.

Feature25: As a user, I want a clean, minimal visual design so I can focus on the content without distraction.

Feature26: As a user, I want the site to use a light cyan background with white/light gray panels and cards so the interface feels cohesive and easy to read.

Feature27: As a user, I want cadet blue to be used as the primary accent color for key elements like buttons and links so interactive items are visually consistent.

Feature28: As a user, I want primary buttons to be filled with cadet blue and display white text so the main actions stand out clearly.

Feature29: As a user, I want text and buttons to have good visual contrast so content is easy to read.

Feature30: As a user, I want a single, consistent design system for typography, buttons, and spacing so the site feels cohesive and professional.

Feature31: As a user, I want hover, disabled, success, and error states for controls and messages to use subtle, consistent colors aligned with the palette so I can clearly understand interaction feedback.

initial_requirements: I want an online trading website where I can browse trading opportunities, trade, manage my account, and check my past transactions.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use an online trading website for bidding and trading, so that I can participate in trading activities.
As a user, I want to have functionalities for bidding, so that I can place bids on trading opportunities.
As a user, I want to have functionalities for trading, so that I can execute trades on the platform.
As a user, I want to browse trading opportunities, so that I can see what items or instruments are available for bidding and trading.
As a user, I want to place orders, so that I can participate in trades according to my decisions.
As a user, I want to manage my trading account, so that I can maintain and control my trading-related information and settings.
As a user, I want to view my trading history, so that I can review my past trades and bidding activities.
As a user, I want the website background color to be lemon chiffon, so that the visual appearance matches that specified style.
As a user, I want the component color to be chocolate, so that the visual appearance of components matches that specified style.

conversation.interviewer: How should the trade order lifecycle work on the site—from placing an order to execution—specifically do you need support for market/limit/stop orders and the ability to modify or cancel open orders before they execute?
conversation.user: I need support for market and limit orders at minimum, and stop-loss/stop-limit would be great. Users should be able to review an order, submit it, see status updates (pending/partially filled/filled/canceled), and modify or cancel any open/unfilled order before it executes.

conversation.interviewer: Which stages and transitions should exist in the lifecycle of an order or booking (e.g. draft, pending, confirmed, completed, cancelled)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact internal stages as long as I can see clear statuses like pending, partially filled, filled, canceled, and rejected, and I can edit/cancel while it’s still open.

conversation.interviewer: When users place trades on the site, should they submit each order directly from the trade screen, or do you want a “cart”-style flow where they can stage multiple orders and submit them together?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a cart-style flow—submitting each order directly from the trade screen is fine. If it’s easy, staging multiple orders could be a nice-to-have, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: After a trade order is filled, should access to the purchased asset (e.g., updated holdings, available balance for selling/withdrawing) be reflected and usable automatically in real time, or do you expect any manual approval steps or delays before the user can act on those assets?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about manual approval steps—ideally it should update automatically and be usable right away after a fill. If there has to be a short processing delay sometimes, that’s fine as long as it’s clearly shown.

conversation.interviewer: What prerequisites or constraints should apply before an order can be placed or modified (e.g., account verification/KYC, sufficient available balance/margin, market-hours restrictions, minimum order size)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact prerequisites or rules, as long as the site prevents invalid orders and clearly tells me what’s wrong (like insufficient funds or market closed). Basic checks like balance and minimum size are fine.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to browse trading opportunities without logging in, or require login before any access to the site?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If possible, letting people browse opportunities without logging in is nice, but require login for placing trades and viewing account details.

conversation.interviewer: What specific parts of the site do you want guests (not logged in) to be able to use—for example, just viewing market prices and basic instrument details, or also things like watchlists, charts, or news?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the guest feature set. At minimum, guests can view market prices and basic instrument details (maybe simple charts/news), but anything like watchlists or placing trades should require login.

conversation.interviewer: Which login methods should the site support (e.g., email+password only, or also Google/Apple social sign-in, and optional two-factor authentication)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific login methods. Email + password is fine, and adding Google/Apple sign-in and optional 2FA would be a nice bonus but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any role- or subscription-based restrictions (e.g., basic vs premium, admin/support roles) that limit which trading/account features a logged-in user can access, or should all logged-in users have the same feature access by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about role or subscription tiers right now—just assume all logged-in users get the same features. You can still have an admin/support role internally for managing the system.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details right now—just make it feel fast and responsive, especially when placing orders and checking status updates.

conversation.interviewer: When placing an order, which specific form fields must be present on the trade screen (e.g., quantity, order type, limit price, time-in-force, stop/stop-limit parameters), and are any of these required vs optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact field list. Just make sure the essentials are there (symbol, buy/sell, quantity, order type, and limit price when it’s a limit), and only require what’s needed for the chosen order type.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra interaction specifics right now—just keep it fast and responsive, especially on order placement and status updates.

conversation.interviewer: During user registration, what specific information do you want new users to provide (e.g., name, email, phone, address, KYC details), and should any manual approval or verification step be required before they can start trading?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact registration info or verification steps. Just keep sign-up simple (email/password) and only ask for extra details if it’s required before trading, and clearly tell users what they need to do.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the main navigation (e.g., Markets/Browse, Instrument Detail, Trade, Portfolio/Holdings, Orders/History, Account/Settings), and what should the primary navigation style be (top bar vs side menu)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact nav style. Core pages should be Markets/Browse, an instrument detail page, Trade, Portfolio/Holdings, Orders & History, and Account/Settings; a simple top bar is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific session and security rules you want for logged-in users, such as how long an inactive session should stay logged in before auto-logout, whether “remember me” (persistent login) is allowed, or if multiple simultaneous logins from different devices should be limited?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact session/security rules. Just do something standard and secure—auto-logout after inactivity is fine, and “remember me” is okay as long as it’s safe.

conversation.interviewer: What notification channels should the site use to communicate key events like order fills/cancellations and security alerts—email only, or also in-app notifications and/or SMS/push?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact channels. Email plus in-app notifications would be plenty; SMS/push is just a nice-to-have for security alerts.

conversation.interviewer: When browsing Markets/Browse, what filters should users be able to apply and persist (e.g., asset class, exchange, price/volume range), and should those filters remain applied when they navigate away and return?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific market filters or persistence rules. Basic filters like asset class and price/volume are fine, and if you can remember my last-used filters when I come back, that’s nice but not critical.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any real-identity verification (e.g., legal name/ID checks or selfie verification) before users can place trades or withdraw funds, or is email/password sign-up enough?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact identity verification flow. If it’s required for trading or withdrawals, just keep it straightforward and tell users clearly what they need to complete.

conversation.interviewer: When users deposit or withdraw funds to support their trading, which payment methods and flows do you want to support (for example, bank transfer, credit/debit card, or third‑party wallets), and should those payments be processed instantly on the site or via external payment links/pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specific deposit/withdrawal methods or exact flow. Just support something common like bank transfer and cards, and make it clear if it’s instant or takes some time.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any fine-grained permission differences between non-admin users (for example, separating “trader” vs “read‑only viewer” accounts), or should every normal logged‑in user always have identical access to all trading and account features?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fine-grained permissions between normal users right now. Just give all logged-in users the same access, and keep admin/support as a separate role.

initial_requirements: I want an email platform that allows me to write and send emails, and manage my email-related information in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to be able to compose emails, so that I can create the content of the messages I want to send.
As a user, I want to be able to select recipients for my emails, so that I can choose who will receive my messages.
As a user, I want to be able to send emails, so that my composed messages are delivered to the selected recipients.
As a user, I want to be able to manage my sent emails, so that I can view, organize, or handle messages I have already sent.
As a user, I want to have access to email templates, so that I can use predefined structures or content when composing emails.
As a user, I want to be able to upload attachments to my emails, so that I can include additional files with my messages.
As a user, I want to manage recipients, so that I can organize and maintain the list of people or addresses I send emails to.
As a user, I want the platform’s background to use the cornsilk color, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the platform’s components to use the peru color, so that the visual elements match the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond writing and sending emails, are there any specific communication features you want built in—such as read receipts, scheduled sending, follow-up reminders, or automatic notifications to other channels (e.g., mobile push or SMS)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about those extras right now. I mainly just need a solid place to compose, send, and organize emails in one spot.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re composing or organizing emails, what kinds of data-entry and workflow actions do you want supported—for example, saving drafts automatically, templates/snippets, bulk moving/deleting emails, or custom fields/labels you can quickly apply?
conversation.user: I’d like it to support predefined templates/snippets so I can compose emails faster instead of starting from scratch every time. Auto-saving drafts would be helpful too, but templates are the main thing.

conversation.interviewer: When should the system auto-save drafts—continuously as you type, at fixed intervals (e.g., every 30 seconds), or only when you click Save?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact auto-save timing—whatever is standard is fine. As long as it reliably saves drafts so I don’t lose work.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re composing or organizing emails, beyond the standard fields like To, CC, Subject, and Body, are there any specific additional fields or form inputs you want to be able to enter or edit (for example, custom tags, categories, reference IDs, or notes), and which of those should be required versus optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra custom fields right now—basic email fields plus templates is enough. If there are tags/labels, they should be optional, not required.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details right now. Just keep it straightforward and not sluggish.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of email templates/snippets do you need (e.g., a few fixed starter templates, or customizable templates with variables like {{name}} or {{company}} that you can fill in when sending)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy variables right now—just a set of customizable templates/snippets I can edit and reuse. If variables like {{name}} are easy to use, that’s nice, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the platform to come with any pre-made email templates/snippets out of the box (e.g., welcome email, follow-up, meeting request), or will you create all templates yourself?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. A few basic starter templates would be nice, but I’m fine creating my own.

conversation.interviewer: When you use templates, do you want them to support dynamic placeholders that auto-fill from data (like recipient name or company), or are simple static templates you manually edit each time sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about dynamic placeholders right now. Simple static templates I can tweak manually are fine.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else on content—just make sure it keeps a clear record of sent emails (including recipients, subject, timestamp, and the final body) so I can review and organize them later. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What core entities do you want the platform to store and relate besides emails themselves (e.g., contacts/people, organizations, threads/conversations, folders/labels, attachments)?
conversation.user: Besides emails, I’d want it to store contacts/people (name + email at least) and keep emails grouped into threads/conversations. Labels/folders and attachments should be supported too, but nothing fancy beyond that.

conversation.interviewer: For each entity you mentioned (contacts, threads/conversations, labels/folders, and attachments), what specific attributes/fields must be stored for it (e.g., for a contact: name, primary email, phone, notes)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on fields. For contacts just name + email is enough; threads just need to group related emails; labels/folders just a name; attachments just filename and the file itself.

conversation.interviewer: For contact summary and detail views, which fields should be displayed to users (e.g., just name and email, or anything else)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about contact views beyond the basics. Just show name and email, and that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements from my side. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components like buttons and links (for example, a particular color or general tone such as blue, green, or something else)?
conversation.user: Yeah—I’d prefer a peru color for the main accent on buttons and links. If you need a close alternative, something in that warm tan/brown range is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme—such as meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios so text and buttons remain easily readable for all users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific accessibility standards right now. Just make sure the text and buttons are easy to read and not low-contrast.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background fill color should key UI components like cards/panels and the navigation bar use (e.g., white, light beige, dark, etc.)?
conversation.user: I’d like a cornsilk-colored background for the main UI—cards/panels and the overall app background. The nav bar can be the same cornsilk or a slightly darker beige/tan so it still feels distinct.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should be required to use the same standardized styling across the app (e.g., buttons, form inputs, navigation, cards, typography), to keep the look consistent on every page and device?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting that specific on standardized styling. Just keep the overall look consistent so it feels like one app—especially buttons and basic form inputs.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined, consistent set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your peru accent color or specified separately?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining all the state colors right now. Just use sensible defaults that look consistent with the peru accent and stay readable (especially for disabled/error).

conversation.interviewer: Is there any specific brand or thematic concept (such as a logo, existing website, or style guide) that the interface’s colors and decorative elements should be aligned with, or should the peru/cornsilk scheme simply stand on its own without extra branding?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about aligning it to an existing brand or style guide. The peru/cornsilk scheme can just stand on its own—simple and clean.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to compose and send emails within the platform so I can handle outbound email from one place.  
Feature2: As a user, I want my email drafts to auto-save reliably so I don’t lose work while composing.  
Feature3: As a user, I want to create, edit, and reuse customizable email templates/snippets so I can compose emails faster.  
Feature4: As a user, I want the system to keep a clear record of sent emails (recipients, subject, timestamp, final body) so I can review them later.  
Feature5: As a user, I want to organize and manage emails in one place so I can keep my inbox and sent items orderly.  
Feature6: As a user, I want emails to be grouped into threads/conversations so I can follow related messages together.  
Feature7: As a user, I want the platform to store contacts with at least name and email so I can reference recipients easily.  
Feature8: As a user, I want to view contact details showing at least name and email so I can confirm I’m messaging the right person.  
Feature9: As a user, I want to create and use labels/folders (name only) to categorize emails for easier organization.  
Feature10: As a user, I want to attach files to emails and have attachments stored (filename + file) so I can send and retain supporting documents.  
Feature11: As a user, I want tags/labels to be optional (not required) so I can send and store emails without extra data entry.  
Feature12: As a user, I want the interface to feel straightforward and not sluggish so common email tasks are quick to perform.  
Feature13: As a user, I want the main accent color for buttons and links to be peru (or a close warm tan/brown alternative) so the UI matches my preferred look.  
Feature14: As a user, I want the main UI background (including cards/panels) to be cornsilk so the app has a light, warm appearance.  
Feature15: As a user, I want the navigation bar to use cornsilk or a slightly darker beige/tan so it is distinct but consistent with the theme.  
Feature16: As a user, I want buttons and basic form inputs to have consistent styling across the app so it feels like a single cohesive product.  
Feature17: As a user, I want text and interactive elements to remain easy to read (avoid low contrast), including disabled and error states, so the UI stays usable.

initial_requirements: I want to build a short message service platform that lets me send messages easily, see whether they’ve been delivered, manage users, set some basic sending rules, and check the overall message status and past records.
user_stories: As a user, I want to send short messages, so that I can communicate using the short message service platform.
As a user, I want to manage user information, so that user-related data can be maintained on the platform.
As a user, I want to configure sending policies, so that I can control how short messages are sent.
As a user, I want to view short message sending records, so that I can see the history of sent short messages.
As a user, I want to monitor short message sending situations, so that I can observe and track the status of short message sending.
As a user, I want the platform to apply azure mist as the background, so that the visual background appearance matches this style.
As a user, I want all components to be styled with dark slate blue, so that the component appearance is consistent with this color.

conversation.interviewer: What concrete messaging and notification capabilities do you want—for example, should users be able to reply to messages, receive status or alert emails, or get in‑app/web notifications when certain messaging events occur, and how should these work?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about replies or extra notifications like emails/in-app alerts right now. The main thing I need is delivery status tracking in the dashboard and a clear history of sent messages.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of admin/management screens do you want for this platform—for example, how should admins log in, view and search users and their message activity, and configure sending rules or system settings, and what specific actions should they be able to perform there?
conversation.user: I want a simple admin web dashboard with secure login (email/password is fine) and basic roles (admin vs regular user). Admins should be able to list/search users, view each user’s sent-message history and delivery statuses, and export logs if needed. For rules/settings, just a screen to set basic sending limits (per minute/day), allowed sender IDs, and maybe a global enable/disable switch for sending.

conversation.interviewer: For the admin vs regular user roles, what specific actions should be restricted to admins only (e.g., managing users, changing sending limits/settings, exporting logs, toggling global send enable/disable)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super granular on role permissions right now. At a minimum, admins can manage users and system-wide settings (limits, sender IDs, global send on/off) and export logs; regular users just send messages and view their own history/status.

conversation.interviewer: For each type of entity in the system (users, sending rules/limits, allowed sender IDs, etc.), which specific lifecycle actions should be available in the admin dashboard—for example, should admins be able to create, edit, deactivate/disable, reactivate, and permanently delete them, and are there any entities that should be view-only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a full lifecycle workflow right now. Just keep it simple: admins can create/edit/deactivate users and adjust limits/sender IDs, but I don’t need permanent deletion or complex states at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One thing: I’d like the admin dashboard to use an azure mist background theme throughout (login and all main screens), as the default look and feel.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need an audit log that records admin actions (who did what and when), and if so, what actions must be captured (e.g., user create/edit/deactivate, changing limits/sender IDs, toggling global send on/off, exporting logs)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a formal admin audit log right now. If it’s easy to add later, that’s fine, but it’s not a requirement for the first version.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like the UI to use a consistent dark slate blue styling for all components (buttons, headers, tables, forms) so everything feels visually uniform across the dashboard.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the admin dashboard navigation to be structured—e.g., what main sections should appear in the sidebar/top menu and which screens should be inside each section?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific navigation structure right now. As long as it’s simple and lets admins get to Users, Message History/Status, and Settings quickly, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond setting sending limits and allowed sender IDs, are there any other system-level configuration or maintenance capabilities you want admins to have in the dashboard (for example, restarting or pausing the app, managing scheduled background jobs, or clearing caches/logs), or should those be handled entirely outside the app for now?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about in-app maintenance controls like restarts, jobs, or cache/log clearing for now. Let’s handle that outside the app; the dashboard can stick to users, message history/status, and the basic sending settings.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users’ login sessions to persist across browser restarts (e.g., “remember me” for X days), and if so, what session timeout duration should apply for admins vs regular users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about “remember me” details right now. A standard session is fine for v1; we can decide on exact timeouts later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: When an admin clicks a user or message in a list, what should the navigation do—open a dedicated detail page, a side panel/modal, or expand inline within the list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which pattern you use for v1. Just pick whatever is simplest to implement and keeps things quick to navigate.

conversation.interviewer: When creating or editing a user in the admin dashboard, what exact fields do you want on the form (e.g., name, email, phone number, role, status), and which of those are required?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact user form fields for v1. Just keep it minimal—email and role are enough, and status (active/deactivated) if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: For searching and filtering in the admin dashboard (e.g., when viewing users or message history/status), what specific capabilities do you want—such as text search, date range filters, status filters, or saved filter presets—and how should these searches/filters behave?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about anything fancy here for v1. Basic text search and maybe a simple date range and delivery-status filter is enough—no saved presets needed.

conversation.interviewer: How real-time do you need delivery-status updates to be in the dashboard—for example, should statuses update live as they change (without page refresh), or is updating only when the user refreshes/reloads acceptable?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about live real-time updates for v1. It’s fine if statuses update on page refresh/reload, or even with a simple periodic refresh.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the sending rules (per‑minute/day limits, allowed sender IDs, global send on/off) to be configurable globally for the whole system only, or also configurable per user?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about per-user rules for v1. Global system-wide limits/sender IDs and the global send on/off switch are enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: What message control/moderation capabilities do you need in v1—should admins be able to block specific recipients/sender IDs, cancel queued sends, or delete/hide sent-message records from the dashboard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about moderation controls like blocking recipients, canceling queued sends, or hiding/deleting message records for v1. Let’s keep it focused on sending, delivery status tracking, and history.

conversation.interviewer: When admins export message logs from the dashboard, what file format should the download use (e.g., CSV or JSON)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the export format for v1—CSV is fine if you need a default. As long as it’s easy to open and share.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specialized admin workflows you need beyond the basic Users/Message History/Settings screens—for example, a guided onboarding flow for new users/sender IDs or a multi-step “test message campaign” flow?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specialized admin workflows for v1. Basic Users, Message History/Status, and Settings screens are enough.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific events in the system (such as failed delivery, hitting a sending limit, or global sending being turned off) for which you now or in the future would want the platform to send notifications or reminders to admins or users, or should it remain with no email/in-app notifications at all?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about notifications/reminders for v1—no email or in-app notifications. Maybe later we’d want alerts for failed deliveries or hitting limits, but it’s not a requirement right now.

conversation.interviewer: In future (even if not in v1), what parts of any system notifications/messages would you want to be configurable via templates (e.g., the text body and subject only)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about notification templates right now since we’re not doing notifications in v1. If we add alerts later, I’d probably want at least the message body editable, and maybe the subject if it’s email.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps manage and track products across the supply chain and provides visibility into their status and movement.
user_stories: As a user, I want to track and verify the origin and circulation of products using unique product IDs, so that I can understand where products come from and how they have moved through the supply chain.
As a user, I want to register products on the website, so that they are included in the supply chain traceability system.
As a user, I want to track the circulation path of products, so that I can see how products have moved through the supply chain.
As a user, I want to query the current status of products, so that I can know their present condition or position in the supply chain.
As a user, I want to verify the authenticity of products, so that I can confirm whether the products are genuine.
As a user, I want to use data statistics and analysis functions on the website, so that I can understand the operation of the supply chain.
As a user, I want the website’s background to be misty rose, so that the visual appearance matches the specified background color.
As a user, I want the website’s components to be firebrick, so that the visual appearance of components matches the specified component color.

conversation.interviewer: What product-management workflows should users be able to perform in the site (e.g., create/update products, update shipment status, assign locations/owners), and do you need bulk actions or data import (CSV/API) for these?
conversation.user: Users should be able to create/update products one at a time, assign them to a shipment/location/owner, and update key status milestones (received, in transit, delivered, delayed, etc.). I don’t really need bulk actions, and CSV/API import isn’t necessary for now.

conversation.interviewer: When users create or update a product, what specific fields should the form include, and which of those fields are required versus optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact list of product form fields right now—keep it simple. Just make sure there’s a product name/ID and current status at minimum, and everything else can be optional.

conversation.interviewer: For individual products (not in bulk), beyond creating and updating them, do you also want users to be able to delete products or duplicate an existing product into a new one?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about duplicate right now. Deleting is fine to have, but it should probably be restricted (like admin-only) so people don’t remove things by accident.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any processes (e.g., creating a shipment or changing a product’s status) that should follow a defined multi-step workflow with required phases/approvals, or should updates be immediate with no step gating?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about multi-step approvals right now. Updates can be immediate with no gating, as long as there’s some basic audit trail of who changed what.

conversation.interviewer: What authentication and role setup do you want—should users be required to log in, and if so what roles (e.g., admin vs standard user) and permissions should each have?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a complicated role system right now. Basic login is fine, with just admin vs standard user—admins can delete products and manage users, regular users can create/update products and statuses.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I’d like a really fast, simple search bar that can find a product by name or ID and jump straight to its detail page with current status and latest movement history.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond searching by name or ID, do you want any additional search or filter capabilities (for example, filtering by status, location, or date ranges), and if so which ones are most important to support first?
conversation.user: Yeah, basic filters would be helpful—start with status (in transit/delayed/delivered), current location, and maybe a simple date range for last status update. Those three would cover most of what I’d need early on.

conversation.interviewer: Which filtering options and conditions should be available for narrowing lists or data sets (e.g. attributes, ranges, statuses)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super detailed with filtering conditions beyond the basics we already mentioned. Status, current location, and a simple date range for last update are enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: When a user searches or applies filters, how would you like the results to be presented and organized—such as a table with sortable columns, simple list with key fields, or another layout—and do you want any quick preview of status/movement history directly in that results view?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact layout. A simple table/list with product name/ID, current status, and current location is fine, and clicking a result should take you to the detail page—no need for a preview panel in the results.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I think we already covered the main interaction stuff—fast search and basic filters. I don’t really have another specific interaction requirement right now.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core entities (data objects) you want the system to model besides Product—for example Shipment, Location, Owner/Organization, Status Update/Milestone, or Movement Event?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about modeling a bunch of separate entities right now. As long as each product can store its current location, assigned shipment/owner (even just as simple fields), and a basic status/movement history, that’s enough for me initially.

conversation.interviewer: For the audit trail and history of each product, what level of detail do you want to store and show (e.g., just who changed the status and when, or also previous values, comments/reasons, and location/shipment changes), and should this history be retained indefinitely or only for a certain period?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super detailed here. Just track who changed the status and when (and maybe the previous status), and keep the history indefinitely unless it becomes a storage issue later.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I think we’ve covered most of the content I care about. Just make sure the product detail page clearly shows current status, current location, assigned shipment/owner, and a simple timeline of status changes—otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level pages/sections should the site have, and how should they be organized in the main navigation (e.g., Dashboard, Products list, Shipments/Locations, Users/Admin, Reports)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact nav structure. At minimum I’d want a Products list/search page, a product detail page, and an Admin/Users section for admins—everything else can be added later.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really care to add anything else on content right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the primary accent color used on interactive components like buttons and links (for example, a particular brand color, or simply “use a standard blue/green with good contrast”)?
conversation.user: Yeah—please use firebrick as the primary accent color for buttons, links, and other interactive elements, as long as contrast/readability stays solid.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard for text and interactive elements (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA), or is “good readable contrast” sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about targeting a specific WCAG level right now. Just aim for good, readable contrast (especially with the firebrick accent) and avoid anything that’s hard to see.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar use (e.g., white, light gray, dark)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a misty rose background overall. For cards/panels and the nav, a white or very light gray base works, as long as it looks clean with the firebrick accent and stays readable.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for interactive/component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should these state colors be derived from the firebrick accent or use separate fixed colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super defined color system right now. Just do sensible defaults—hover/active can be slightly darker/lighter firebrick, and use standard obvious colors for success (green) and error (red), with disabled looking muted but still readable.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI components should use the same standardized style across the whole site (e.g., buttons, form fields, tables, cards, navigation, status badges)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting too specific there. Just keep the basics consistent site-wide—buttons/links, form fields, tables, cards, the top nav, and any status badges—so it feels uniform.

task_name: Paper Cup Inventory and Sales Management System
initial_requirements: I want a system that helps me manage production and sales operations, keep track of inventory and materials, and understand overall business performance.
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to manage raw materials, so that I can handle all raw material-related operations within the paper cup manufacturing process.
As a user, I want the system to manage finished products, so that I can handle all finished paper cup product-related operations.
As a user, I want the system to manage inventory, so that I can maintain an accurate view of available raw materials and finished products.
As a user, I want the system to manage production, so that I can oversee and control the paper cup manufacturing activities.
As a user, I want the system to manage sales, so that I can handle the selling of paper cups.
As a user, I want to record the inventory of raw materials, so that I can keep an accurate log of raw material stock levels.
As a user, I want to record the inventory of finished products, so that I can keep an accurate log of finished paper cup stock levels.
As a user, I want to track the inventory of raw materials, so that I can monitor changes and current stock of raw materials over time.
As a user, I want to track the inventory of finished products, so that I can monitor changes and current stock of finished products over time.
As a user, I want to record the usage of raw materials, so that I can monitor how raw materials are consumed in production.
As a user, I want to record the usage of finished products, so that I can track how finished products are allocated or utilized.
As a user, I want to track the usage of raw materials, so that I can follow how raw materials are used over time.
As a user, I want to track the usage of finished products, so that I can follow how finished products are used over time.
As a user, I want to record the sales of raw materials, so that I can log transactions involving raw materials.
As a user, I want to record the sales of finished products, so that I can log transactions involving finished paper cup products.
As a user, I want to track the sales of raw materials, so that I can monitor sales activity related to raw materials.
As a user, I want to track the sales of finished products, so that I can monitor sales activity related to finished products.
As a user, I want to generate detailed reports, so that I can review and analyze information about inventory, usage, and sales of raw materials and finished products.
As a user, I want the system to provide customer management capabilities, so that I can handle all customer-related information and activities.
As a user, I want to record customer information, so that I can maintain a register of customer details.
As a user, I want to record customer sales history, so that I can review what each customer has purchased over time.
As a user, I want to record and view sales statistics for customers, so that I can see summarized sales data related to customers.
As a user, I want the system background to use light goldenrod, so that the interface appearance matches the specified background color.
As a user, I want the UI elements to use olive drab, so that the interface elements match the specified color.

conversation.interviewer: When your team is entering or updating data (like new orders, inventory counts, or production batches), how would you like those workflows to function in practice—for example, do you prefer guided step-by-step forms, inline table editing, bulk upload/import, or something else, and why?
conversation.user: A mix would be best: guided step-by-step forms for creating orders and production batches (to avoid mistakes), and inline table editing for quick inventory adjustments. Bulk import via CSV/Excel would be great for initial setup or big updates so we’re not keying everything in by hand.

conversation.interviewer: For creating a new sales order, what specific fields should the form include, and which of those are required versus optional?
conversation.user: For a new sales order we need: customer, order date, delivery/ship date, order status, and line items (product/SKU, quantity, unit price, tax/discount) — those are required. Optional: PO/reference number, shipping address (if different), sales rep, payment terms, notes/special instructions, and attachments like a signed PO.

conversation.interviewer: For inventory items, which bulk operations should the interface support (e.g., bulk import, bulk edit fields, bulk adjust quantities, bulk delete, duplicate/cloning)?
conversation.user: Definitely bulk import (CSV/Excel) and bulk edit for common fields like category, supplier, reorder levels, and unit cost. Bulk quantity adjustments should be supported too, but with a required reason and an audit trail. Bulk delete should be limited/permissioned, and cloning/duplicating items would be handy for similar SKUs.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond creating new sales orders and production batches, which other processes in your system (if any) should follow a defined multi-step workflow with explicit phases or statuses (e.g., submission → review → approval → completion), and what would those phases be for each?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about formal multi-step approval workflows beyond basic statuses. As long as orders, production, and inventory changes can be tracked with simple statuses and an audit log, that’s enough for us.

conversation.interviewer: When a data entry action (like saving an order, posting a production batch, or applying a bulk inventory change) succeeds or fails, what specific follow-up actions do you want users to have on the result screen—for example, retry, edit and resubmit, roll back/undo, download or export a log, or request an override?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a special result screen flow. Basic success/failure messages with a link to fix errors and retry is fine, and an audit log we can reference if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the “feel” details too much. As long as it’s quick to load and has a simple global search to find orders, customers, and SKUs, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: For actions like recalculating stock levels, generating production plans, or updating dashboards/reports, which ones should run automatically (e.g., immediately after data changes or on a schedule) and which should only run when a user explicitly triggers them?
conversation.user: Stock levels should recalculate automatically right after anything that affects inventory (sales orders, production batches, adjustments). Dashboards/reports can refresh on a schedule (say hourly/daily) with a manual “refresh now” button when needed. Production plans should be user-triggered so we can control when we commit to a plan and review inputs first.

conversation.interviewer: When someone changes a configuration/setting (e.g., tax rates, units of measure, reorder rules), should the change apply immediately on save, or should it go into a draft/review step (with confirmation or approval) before it takes effect?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a draft/review step for settings. Applying changes immediately on save is fine, as long as there’s an audit log and an easy way to revert if something was entered wrong.

conversation.interviewer: For the admin side of the system, what concrete screens and capabilities do you want administrators to have (for example, managing users/roles and permissions, configuring master data like products/customers, or viewing an admin-specific dashboard), and which of these are most important to you?
conversation.user: Admins should be able to manage users/roles/permissions, maintain master data (customers, products/SKUs, suppliers, units/tax rules), and view audit logs of key changes. Most important are customer management (structured customer records with sales history/stats), permissions, and the ability to correct/revert master data changes when something’s wrong.

conversation.interviewer: For user roles and permissions, could you describe the main types of users you expect (e.g., admin, manager, warehouse, sales) and, for each type, what they should be allowed to do and what they should be restricted from doing?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super granular with roles. Basic roles like Admin (full access), Sales (create/edit orders, view inventory), Warehouse (inventory adjustments/receipts, view orders), and Manager (view reports, approve big inventory adjustments if you add that) are enough.

conversation.interviewer: For administrative actions like changing master data, user permissions, or core settings, which specific operations do you want to be guarded with extra oversight (e.g., confirmation dialogs, manager approval, or restricted to certain roles) beyond just being recorded in the audit log?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra oversight beyond the audit log. Just restrict sensitive admin actions (like deleting master data, changing roles/permissions, or tax/unit settings) to Admins and add a simple confirmation prompt for destructive changes.

conversation.interviewer: For each master-data entity you want admins to manage (customers, products/SKUs, suppliers, units, tax rules), which lifecycle operations must the system support (e.g., create, edit, activate/deactivate, archive, delete, restore/undo)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super formal lifecycle model. Just support create/edit for all of them, and ideally deactivate/archive instead of hard delete, with restore/undo from the audit log for mistakes.

conversation.interviewer: For the admin area specifically, what main sections or menu items would you like (e.g., Users & Roles, Master Data, Audit Logs, System Settings), and how should they be grouped or arranged in the navigation so admins can quickly find what they need?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about the exact menu grouping. As long as there are clear top-level sections like Users & Roles, Master Data, System Settings, and Audit Logs, and everything’s easy to find with search, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: What are the exact lifecycle statuses you want for a sales order (e.g., Draft → Confirmed → Shipped/Delivered → Invoiced → Closed/Cancelled), and what specific rules should control moving between those statuses?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about an exact lifecycle beyond a few simple statuses like Draft, Confirmed, Shipped/Delivered, and Cancelled. Basic rule is you can’t ship unless it’s confirmed, and cancelled orders shouldn’t be editable except maybe notes.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One specific thing: I’d like the app to use a light goldenrod background theme across the main screens (with good contrast for readability).

conversation.interviewer: For your global search that finds orders, customers, and SKUs, what specific search and filtering capabilities do you want (for example, keyword search across all fields, field-specific filters like date ranges or status, saved filter sets), and how should users interact with those?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy search/filtering. Just a simple keyword search box that matches order numbers, customer names, and SKU/product names, plus maybe quick filters for order status and date range.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific fields should the global keyword search match against (e.g., order number, customer name, SKU/product name), and should it support partial matches as you type?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific there. Just match order number, customer name, and SKU/product name, and yes—partial matches as you type would be nice.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the quick filters for order status and date range you mentioned, are there any other specific filters you want when narrowing lists (for example, filtering orders by customer, products by category, or inventory by location)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more filters right now. If it’s easy, filtering orders by customer and products by category would be nice, but it’s not a must-have for us.

conversation.interviewer: When users run a global search, how would you like the results to be presented—e.g., a single combined list or separate tabs for Orders/Customers/SKUs?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If I had to choose, separate tabs for Orders/Customers/SKUs is a bit cleaner so it’s easier to scan.

conversation.interviewer: For the search result lists (in each tab like Orders, Customers, SKUs), which specific fields do you want users to be able to sort by, and should sorting support both ascending and descending order?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific sort fields. Just let people sort the obvious columns (like order date/number/status, customer name, SKU/name, on-hand qty) and support both ascending and descending.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps manage hospital operations, including clinical, administrative, and operational activities, and provides a clear overview of the hospital’s overall performance.
user_stories: As a user, I want a hospital management website that manages hospital finances, reports, inventory, and patient information, so that all key hospital operations are supported in one system.
As a user, I want the website to provide financial management functionality, so that hospital finances can be managed.
As a user, I want the system to allow collecting patient fees, so that patient payments are handled within the financial management functionality.
As a user, I want the website to provide reporting functionality, so that I can access different types of operational reports.
As a user, I want to generate inventory reports, so that I can view information about hospital inventory.
As a user, I want to generate patient reports, so that I can view information about patients.
As a user, I want to generate financial reports, so that I can view information about hospital finances.
As an employee, I want to submit daily reports to my superiors, so that they receive information about my daily activities.
As an employee, I want my daily reports to include detailed information about daily activities, so that my superiors have complete information on what was done.
As a user, I want pharmacy management functionality that includes inventory management of medicines, so that medicine stock is tracked and managed.
As a user, I want patient electronic files to store the patient name, so that the patient can be identified.
As a user, I want patient electronic files to store the date of visit, so that each visit is recorded.
As a user, I want patient electronic files to store the diagnosis, so that the patient’s medical condition is documented.
As a user, I want patient electronic files to store comments, so that additional notes about the patient or visit are recorded.
As a user, I want the website to provide claim formulation functionality, so that claims can be prepared and managed.
As a user, I want the website to provide laboratory management functionality, so that laboratory-related activities can be managed.
As a user, I want the website to provide theater management functionality, so that theater-related activities can be managed.
As a user, I want the website’s background color configured to peach puff, so that the overall background appears in that color.
As a user, I want the website’s components to use indian red, so that interface components appear in that color.

conversation.interviewer: What key workflows should users be able to perform in the system (e.g., admitting/discharging patients, scheduling appointments, updating patient records), and should any of these support bulk updates?
conversation.user: Key workflows: patient registration/admission/transfer/discharge, appointment and procedure scheduling, updating the electronic patient file (demographics, insurance, visit notes, diagnoses, labs/imaging, meds), bed/ward management, billing/claims, and staff/OR scheduling. Bulk updates should be possible for admin-type data (e.g., insurance plan changes, ward/bed reassignments, importing lab results), but not for clinical notes/diagnoses without strict review/approvals.

conversation.interviewer: For administrative-type data where you do want bulk operations (e.g., insurance plans, ward/bed assignments, imported lab results), which specific bulk actions should be supported in the UI (for example, bulk create/import, bulk edit, bulk deactivate, or bulk delete), and are there any of these you explicitly want to prohibit?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact list of bulk actions in the UI as long as we can import and do safe bulk edits for admin data. I’d want bulk delete generally prohibited (or at least restricted) and prefer deactivate/archive instead for anything important.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific processes in the system should follow a defined multi-step workflow with explicit statuses/phases (e.g., admission, billing/claims, staff scheduling, bulk admin edits), and what are the statuses for each?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about spelling out every status list right now. The big ones that should have clear phases are admission/transfer/discharge, billing/claims, and appointment/OR scheduling—just make the statuses configurable so we can refine them later.

conversation.interviewer: For this hospital operations system, what are your expectations around authentication and user accounts—for example, do you require strict real-name, role-based accounts only (no anonymous or shared logins), any form of single sign-on with existing hospital identity systems (e.g., Active Directory/SSO), or support for session sharing across web and mobile?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specifics right now. Just no anonymous access, and ideally role-based logins; if SSO with something like Active Directory is easy to add later, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: For the patient registration/admission workflow, which specific fields must be captured on the form, and which of those are required versus optional?
conversation.user: I don’t care about nailing down the exact required vs optional fields right now. Just cover the usual basics (patient identity/contact, insurance, emergency contact, admitting reason, and initial ward/bed if applicable), and make the field requirements configurable.

conversation.interviewer: For actions like importing lab results, updating bed/ward assignments, or generating bills/claims, which of these should run automatically based on events or schedules (e.g., new file received, end of day), and which should only run when a user manually triggers them?
conversation.user: Lab result imports should run automatically when a new file/interface message arrives, with a queue and error review. Bed/ward assignment updates should be user-driven (or triggered by admission/transfer/discharge events), not scheduled. Billing/claims can auto-generate drafts on discharge/end-of-day, but submission/finalization should be manually triggered with an approval step.

conversation.interviewer: For configuration or settings changes in the system (such as workflows, required fields, or status lists), should updates take effect immediately when a user saves them, or would you prefer a draft-and-approval/change-request process before they are applied to production use?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact mechanics there. If there’s a simple way to avoid accidental changes—like limiting who can edit settings and keeping an audit log—that’s enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core top-level pages/modules you want in the main navigation (e.g., Dashboard, Patients, Scheduling, Bed/Ward, Billing/Claims, Staff/OR, Reports), and which page should users land on after login?
conversation.user: Main nav should cover: Dashboard, Patients (EHR), Admissions/ADT, Scheduling (appointments/procedures/OR), Bed/Ward, Billing/Claims, Staff, Labs/Imaging, Reports/Analytics, and Admin/Settings. Default landing page after login should be the Dashboard (or role-based—e.g., schedulers land on Scheduling).

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between the major modules (Dashboard, Patients, ADT, Scheduling, Bed/Ward, Billing, etc.)—via a persistent left sidebar, a top navigation bar with dropdowns, tabs, or primarily from the Dashboard tiles?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a left sidebar or top nav—whatever is standard and easy to use. Just make it persistent so people can jump between modules quickly, and the Dashboard can have tiles as shortcuts.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific admin/configuration areas (e.g., user/role management, workflow/status configuration, required-field rules, reference/master data, integrations/import settings, audit logs) must be available under Admin/Settings at launch?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact breakdown at launch. At minimum we need user/role management, basic integrations/import settings, and audit logs; the rest can be added iteratively.

conversation.interviewer: For user and role management, could you describe the main role types you expect (e.g., clinician, nurse, scheduler, billing clerk, department manager, admin) and how their access should differ—for instance, which modules or actions each role must be allowed to view, edit, or configure?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining detailed role matrices right now. Broadly we’ll have clinicians/nurses, schedulers, billing, department managers, and admins—admins can configure settings, everyone else should only see/edit what they need for their module, with patient data access restricted by role/department.

conversation.interviewer: When a user clicks an item in a list (e.g., a patient, appointment, claim, bed), should that open a dedicated full detail page for that item, or should details appear in a side panel/modal while staying on the list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a full detail page or a side panel/modal. Just make it quick to view/edit details without losing your place in the list.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific admin actions must require an explicit approval step (e.g., two-person approval) before taking effect, versus being allowed immediately with just an audit log?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining two-person approvals right now. For now, just restrict sensitive admin actions to admins and make sure everything is audited; we can add approval steps later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: For the key entities you’ll manage (patients, appointments/procedures, beds/wards, claims/bills, staff schedules), which lifecycle operations must the system support (e.g., create, edit, approve, activate/deactivate, archive, delete), and should delete be disabled by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about enumerating lifecycle operations per entity right now. As a general rule, yes—delete should be disabled by default, and we should use archive/deactivate instead, with auditing for any sensitive changes.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond user/role management, integrations/import settings, and audit logs, which additional entities or areas (for example, reference/master data like departments, wards, insurance plans, procedure catalogs, or billing rules) do you want explicitly manageable through the Admin/Settings interface in the first version?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about expanding Admin/Settings beyond the basics in the first version. If we have time, the most useful would be managing departments/wards/bed types and insurance plans, but it’s not a must-have at launch.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—make it really quick to file a daily activity report: a persistent “Daily Report” button available from any module, opening a short form with autosave and one-click submit, and it should prefill the user/department/date.

conversation.interviewer: For operations that can partially fail or produce errors (like lab imports, billing runs, or bed assignment updates), what specific follow-up actions should users be able to take on each failed item—for example, retry as-is, edit and resubmit, ignore/mark resolved, or escalate to another role for review?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact follow-up actions list right now. As long as there’s a clear error queue where staff can retry, fix the underlying data and resubmit, or mark it resolved with a note, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding another interaction requirement right now—we already called out the Daily Report button/form, and that’s the main one.

conversation.interviewer: For your hospital operations system, could you specify the main data elements and groupings you definitely want to track for each core entity—patients, encounters/visits, appointments/procedures/OR cases, beds/wards, and claims/bills (for example, whether you want a separate “encounter” record linked to a patient and then to orders, results, and billing)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down the exact data model details right now. Just use a standard hospital setup—patient linked to encounters/visits, and encounters linked to orders/results and billing/claims—so we can refine the fields later.

conversation.interviewer: What data retention and archiving policy should the system enforce for patient records and operational records (e.g., keep indefinitely, archive after X years, purge after X years), and are there any record types that must never be purged?
