As a general preference, don’t purge patient records by default; archive them instead unless there’s a clear mandate to delete.

initial_requirements: I want an e-government system that helps manage daily administrative operations, support internal processes, and handle approvals and related activities in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to provide office management functionalities, so that I can manage office-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want the system to provide infrastructure management functionalities, so that I can manage infrastructure-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want the system to provide procurement management functionalities, so that I can manage procurement-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want the system to provide personnel management functionalities, so that I can manage personnel-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want the system to provide financial management functionalities, so that I can manage financial-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want the system to provide decision-making management functionalities, so that I can manage decision-making-related activities within the e-government system.
As a user, I want to browse related information in the system, so that I can view the information relevant to my e-government tasks.
As a user, I want to submit applications in the system, so that I can initiate required e-government processes.
As a user, I want to approve items in the system, so that I can complete approval steps in e-government workflows.
As a user, I want to query the status of items in the system, so that I can know the progress of my applications and related processes.
As a user, I want to perform related operations in the system, so that I can complete all necessary actions associated with my e-government tasks.
As a user, I want the system to include leave management functions, so that I can handle leave-related processes.
As a user, I want the system to include management functions for middle-level cadres leaving Shenzhen, so that I can handle processes related to middle-level cadres leaving Shenzhen.
As a user, I want the system to include attendance management functions, so that I can handle attendance-related processes.
As a user, I want the system to include “five powers” management functions, so that I can handle “five powers”-related processes.

As a user, I want the system to allow designing corresponding forms and processes for leave, middle-level cadres leaving Shenzhen, attendance, and “five powers” management, so that these functions can use appropriate forms and workflows.

As a user, I want the system to allow circulating the corresponding forms and processes for leave, middle-level cadres leaving Shenzhen, attendance, and “five powers” management, so that these workflows can be routed and processed.
As a user, I want the page background of the system to be light pink, so that the interface uses the specified background color.
As a user, I want the elements of the system to be medium violet red, so that the interface uses the specified element color.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific administrative areas and management functions (for example user/role management, organizational structure, approval workflow configuration, system settings, reporting dashboards) do you want administrators to be able to access and control from their admin dashboard?
conversation.user: From the admin dashboard I’d want full user/role and permission management, org structure/department setup, and configurable approval workflows (forms, routing, SLAs, escalations). Also system settings (templates, notifications, integrations), master data for key domains (procurement, HR, finance, assets/infrastructure), and reporting/audit dashboards (KPIs, backlog, compliance logs).

conversation.interviewer: Could you describe the main roles you envision in the system (e.g., super admin, department admin, regular staff, auditor) and outline what each of these roles should be allowed to see and do versus what must be restricted?
conversation.user: Main roles: Super Admin (global config, users/roles, org structure, workflow builder, integrations, master data). Department Admin (manage department users/permissions, department-specific forms/workflows, view department dashboards/backlogs, can’t change global settings). Regular Staff (browse policies/forms, submit requests, track status, respond to queries, limited access to their own records). Approvers/Managers (approve/reject/return, delegate, view workload/SLA/escalations for their scope). Auditor/Compliance (read-only access to logs, reports, and case histories; no edits/approvals).

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of oversight and safety controls do you want around admin actions—for example, which specific operations should require extra confirmation, dual approval, or be fully logged with before/after values and justification comments?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about dual-approval or extra confirmations for admin actions right now. Basic audit logging of key changes is enough for me at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: For the typical request and approval processes (e.g., HR, procurement, finance), how do you want data entry and workflows to behave—should users fill in structured, configurable forms with validations and dynamic fields (show/hide, required based on answers), and then move through predefined steps, or are you expecting something more free-form and flexible?
conversation.user: I want it mostly structured and process-driven: configurable forms with validations and dynamic fields, then predefined workflow steps with routing and SLAs. Free-form should be limited to comments/attachments and maybe an “other” request type when something doesn’t fit standard processes like leave, attendance, cadre movement, and five-powers approvals.

conversation.interviewer: For the structured, process-driven requests you mentioned (like leave, attendance, cadre movement, and five-powers approvals), could you list which ones must go through a clearly defined multi-step workflow and briefly name the key steps or statuses each should pass through (e.g., draft → submitted → department review → final approval → completed)?
conversation.user: Yes—these should be multi-step. Leave: Draft → Submitted → Supervisor review → HR review → Final approval → Completed (or Rejected/Returned). Attendance correction: Draft → Submitted → Supervisor review → Time/HR verification → Approved/Posted. Cadre movement: Draft → Submitted → Department head review → HR review → Finance/budget check (if needed) → Executive approval → Implemented. Five-powers approvals: Draft → Submitted → Department review → Compliance/Legal (if needed) → Finance (if needed) → Final authority approval → Completed.

conversation.interviewer: For one of your core processes (for example, leave requests), could you specify the exact data fields that should appear on the form and indicate which of those fields must be mandatory and which can be optional or editable later?
conversation.user: For leave requests, fields: Employee (auto from profile, read-only), Department (auto, read-only), Leave type (mandatory), Start date/time (mandatory), End date/time (mandatory), Total days/hours (auto-calculated, read-only), Reason (mandatory), Contact during leave (phone/email, mandatory), Backup/acting person (optional), Attachments (optional but mandatory for sick/medical leave), Notes/comments (optional). Most fields can’t be edited after submit except attachments and comments if it’s returned for correction.

conversation.interviewer: When a user submits a request and it fails or is rejected/returned, what exact follow-up actions should the system offer on that screen (e.g., retry submission, edit and resubmit, save as draft, download error/details, contact support/escalate, request override)?
conversation.user: If submission fails (technical/validation), show clear error details, highlight the fields, let them fix and retry, or save as draft. If it’s returned, allow edit and resubmit, keep the reviewer comments visible, and preserve the history/attachments (with option to add more). If it’s rejected, show the reason and workflow history, and offer “create new request based on this” plus contact/escalate to the right department/helpdesk.

conversation.interviewer: For key entities like users, departments, requests/cases, and master data records, which specific create/read/update/delete actions and bulk operations (e.g., bulk approve, bulk reassign, bulk update fields, bulk deactivate/delete) do you want users to be able to perform directly from list or dashboard views?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about bulk operations or detailed CRUD controls from list views right now. As long as admins can manage users/departments and staff can create and track their own requests, that’s enough for this stage.

conversation.interviewer: When should the system trigger workflow actions like routing to the next approver, SLA timer start/stop, escalations, and notifications—immediately on submit/approval events, on a scheduled batch (e.g., every hour), or only when a user/admin manually triggers them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact trigger mechanism right now. As long as routing, SLAs, escalations, and notifications happen reliably without users having to manually trigger anything, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific UI interaction details right now. Just make it reasonably fast and easy to find my pending tasks and submitted requests.

conversation.interviewer: What core entities (tables/records) must the system model across all modules (e.g., employee, department, request/case, approval step, SLA, master-data item), and how should they be grouped/categorized in your master data structure?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining the exact core entities/tables or how to group master data right now. As long as the system supports users/employees, departments, requests/cases, workflows/approvals, and basic master data for HR/procurement/finance/assets, that’s enough for this stage.

conversation.interviewer: How long should the system retain completed requests/cases and their full audit trail (e.g., indefinitely, or archive/delete after a specific number of years)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact retention period right now. Keeping completed requests and the audit trail indefinitely (or at least long-term) is fine for this stage.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now. We can move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent/highlight color should the system use for key UI components (e.g., primary buttons and active states)?
conversation.user: Let’s use medium violet red as the primary accent color for buttons and active states.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme—for example, should all text and key UI elements meet WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios to ensure readability for users with visual impairments?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific WCAG AA/AAA targets right now. Just make sure the text is readable and the main buttons have good contrast.

conversation.interviewer: What base colors (fills) would you like for major UI components such as cards/panels and the top navigation bar, apart from the medium violet red accent already chosen for buttons and active states?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact base colors. A clean light theme is fine—white or very light gray for cards/panels and a dark/navy top bar (or just white) as long as it looks professional and readable.

conversation.interviewer: For component states like success, warning, and error messages (e.g., banners, validation messages, status chips), do you want to use a standard “traffic light” palette (green for success, yellow/orange for warning, red for error) or derive these colors as tints/shades of your chosen medium violet red accent?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of color detail. Just use standard green/yellow/red for success/warning/error as long as it’s clear and readable.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the overall page/layout background be (e.g., white vs very light gray)?
conversation.user: I’d like the overall page background to be a very light pink—something subtle so it still feels clean and readable.

conversation.interviewer: Across all modules and pages, which specific UI aspects (for example button style, form field appearance, table layout, icon style, or heading typography) do you want to be strictly standardized so the interface feels visually consistent everywhere?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict UI standardization details right now. Just keep buttons, form fields, and tables consistent across pages so it feels cohesive and easy to use.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific brand colors, patterns, or thematic motifs (e.g., government seal colors, flag elements, or branding guidelines) that the UI should incorporate in addition to the medium violet red accent and light pink background?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about additional branding motifs right now. No need for seals or flag elements—just keep it clean and professional with the colors we already picked.

task_name: Employee Time and Attendance Management System
initial_requirements: I want a system that helps track employee attendance and provides an overview of attendance information.
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to record employee attendance, so that employee attendance information is tracked.
As a user, I want the system to provide functionality for employees to clock in, so that their start time is recorded.
As a user, I want the system to provide functionality for employees to clock out, so that their end time is recorded.
As a user, I want the system to provide functionality for employees to view attendance records, so that they can review their attendance information.
As a user, I want the attendance records to include attendance time, so that they can see when they were present.
As a user, I want the attendance records to include absence time, so that they can see when they were absent.
As an administrator, I want to view all employees’ attendance records, so that I can see attendance information for the entire organization.
As an administrator, I want to perform statistics on employees’ attendance records, so that I can obtain quantitative attendance information.
As a user, I want the system’s base color to be papaya whip, so that the overall interface uses this specified base color.
As a user, I want all components to use dark orange, so that the interface components follow the specified color.

conversation.interviewer: What specific admin/manager functions should the system include (e.g., creating and managing employees, configuring attendance rules/shifts, approving exceptions, and viewing/editing attendance records)?
conversation.user: Admins/managers should be able to create/edit employee profiles, set up shifts and attendance rules, and view organization-wide attendance dashboards with summaries/trends. They should also be able to review/approve exceptions (late/early leave, missing punches), and view/edit individual attendance records with an audit trail.

conversation.interviewer: What distinct user roles should exist (e.g., Super Admin, HR/Admin, Manager, Employee), and for each role, what attendance-related actions should they be allowed to perform and over which employees/teams (scope)?
conversation.user: We need at least: Super Admin (system-wide settings, manage all orgs/users), HR/Admin (manage all employees, shifts/rules, view/edit records, approve exceptions), Manager (view dashboards for their team only, approve exceptions for direct reports, limited edits like adding notes), and Employee (view their own attendance history, punches, balances, and submit correction/exception requests). Scope-wise, HR/Admin is org-wide; Managers only their assigned teams; Employees only themselves.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic create/edit, for each key entity type (employees, shifts/schedules, attendance rules, exception/correction requests), which additional lifecycle actions do you need the system to support (e.g., activate/deactivate, soft-delete/archive, restore, versioning, bulk update), and are there any that must be restricted to specific roles?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra lifecycle stuff like versioning or soft-delete beyond the basics. As long as we can deactivate/terminate employees and archive old shifts/rules for history, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: Which admin/manager actions must be captured in the audit trail (e.g., edits to attendance records, shift/rule changes, employee deactivation/termination), and what details should each audit entry record (who, when, before/after values, reason/comment)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about getting super detailed with the audit trail. Just log who did what and when for key changes like attendance record edits, shift/rule updates, and employee deactivations, with an optional comment/reason.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the admin/HR dashboard to be structured in terms of main sections and navigation (e.g., separate pages or tabs for attendance overview, exception approvals, employee management, shift/rule configuration), and which of these should be most prominent on first login?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple left-nav with sections: Attendance Overview (default landing), Exceptions/Approvals, Employees, Shifts & Rules, and Reports/Exports. On first login, the Attendance Overview should be most prominent with high-level stats and quick links to pending exceptions.

conversation.interviewer: Within each section you mentioned (Attendance Overview, Exceptions/Approvals, Employees, Shifts & Rules, Reports/Exports), how do you want users to move from high-level lists or summaries into detailed views (e.g., click a row to open a detail page, slide-in side panel, modal), and should there be an easy way to navigate back to the list without losing filters or context?
conversation.user: From the overview/list pages, clicking a row should open a full detail page (not a modal), and there should be a clear back-to-list link that preserves filters/sort and the date range. For Exceptions, a quick slide-in panel to review/approve is fine, but it should still let you jump to the full attendance record detail if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Which main pages or sections should the product include for each user group (e.g. end users, admins, merchants), and how should users navigate between them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about separate “merchant” type sections—this is just for employees and admin/HR/managers. Main areas should be Attendance (overview + history), Exceptions/Requests, and for admins: Employees, Shifts & Rules, Reports; navigation can just be a simple left sidebar with role-based access.

conversation.interviewer: Which platforms and entry points must the system support (e.g., desktop web, mobile web, iOS/Android app, kiosk/terminal), and for each, what should the primary navigation pattern be (sidebar, bottom tabs, kiosk flow, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which specific platforms you choose. A responsive desktop/mobile web app is fine as long as it’s easy to use; no need for a dedicated kiosk or native iOS/Android app.

conversation.interviewer: When a user needs to switch between major modules like Attendance, Exceptions/Approvals, Employees, Shifts & Rules, and Reports, should they do so only via the left sidebar, or do you also want an in-page module switcher (e.g., top tabs or a dropdown) for faster switching?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—left sidebar is fine. If you add a simple top dropdown/tabs for quicker switching that’s okay, but not necessary.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about interaction polish details like animations or button behavior. Just make it fast and keep search/filters quick and easy to use.

conversation.interviewer: How should users browse and discover attendance data and exceptions—do you want primarily list/table views with search and filters, or any category/grouped views (e.g., by team, location, shift, or exception type) as the main discovery structure?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy discovery structures. Plain list/table views with solid search and filters are enough, and grouping by things like team/shift/exception type can just be optional filters rather than a whole separate view.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra interaction requirements beyond what I already said. Just keep it fast, and make search/filters respond quickly without page reloads if possible.

conversation.interviewer: For your attendance domain, which specific data fields and structures do you consider mandatory for each core entity (e.g., Employee, Shift/Schedule, Attendance Record, Exception/Correction Request)—such as IDs, dates/times, statuses, reason codes—so we know exactly what must be modeled in the data schema?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down the exact schema fields right now. Just cover the basics (employee ID, timestamps in/out, shift, status, and an exception reason/status) and we can refine details later.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific attendance metrics and breakdowns must the dashboards and reports support (e.g., total present/absent, late/early leave counts, overtime, exception volume), and at what time granularity (daily/weekly/monthly)?
conversation.user: At minimum: counts/percent present, absent, late, early leave, missing punches, and exception volume (pending vs approved/denied). Overtime/total hours worked would be great if feasible. Granularity should be daily with weekly and monthly rollups, plus a custom date range filter.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the dashboards to show any ranked comparisons (e.g., top/bottom teams or managers by lateness/absence/exception volume), or should they display only aggregated totals and trends without rankings?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about rankings like top/bottom teams. Aggregated totals and trends are enough for us.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the daily/weekly/monthly views you mentioned, are there any specific filter or breakdown controls you definitely need on analytics and reports (for example, filtering by team, manager, location, shift type, or employment status), or are basic date-range filters sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a bunch of extra breakdowns. Basic date range is the main thing—if you can add optional filters like team/manager and location, that’s nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content requirement: attendance records should clearly distinguish actual worked/attendance time vs absence time (e.g., unpaid absence/leave) so reports and totals don’t mix them. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What specific reporting and export capabilities do you need—for example, which formats (CSV, Excel, PDF), any required filters in exports, and whether users should be able to schedule reports or only download them on demand?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about advanced reporting/export features right now. Basic on-demand downloads in CSV or Excel are enough; scheduling and PDFs aren’t necessary.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now—let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the colors used on key interface components (such as buttons, links, and highlights)—for example, a primary accent color, any colors to avoid, or accessibility requirements like minimum contrast?
conversation.user: No strong color preferences—just use a clean, neutral theme with a single primary accent color. Please meet basic accessibility contrast (WCAG AA) and avoid relying on color alone to show status (use icons/labels too).

task_name: Barber Shop Management and Notification System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me manage a barber shop’s operations and stay in touch with customers.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse barbers, so that I can see which barbers are available.
As a user, I want to browse services, so that I can see which services are offered.
As a user, I want to add new barbers, so that I can manage the list of barbers on the website.
As a user, I want to add new services, so that I can manage the list of services on the website.
As a user, I want to send WhatsApp notifications to clients, so that I can notify them through WhatsApp.
As a user, I want the website layout styled with snow in the background, so that the background appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the interface styled with dim gray, so that the interface color matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like customers to book and manage their appointments—such as rescheduling, canceling, or choosing specific barbers and services—through the website?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the detailed booking flows right now. As long as customers can book online and get confirmations, that’s enough for me at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic booking confirmations, what kinds of messages or notifications would you like the website to be able to send to customers (for example reminders, promotions, follow-up messages), and through which channels (email, SMS, WhatsApp, etc.)?
conversation.user: I’d like it to send appointment reminders, confirmations/changes, and occasional promos or follow-ups. WhatsApp is the main channel I want—email is optional as a backup.

conversation.interviewer: For which specific events should the system send WhatsApp notifications, and who should receive each one (customer, assigned barber, shop admin)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on all the notification events right now. Just cover the basics: booking confirmation, reminder, and any reschedule/cancel updates to the customer—and optionally notify the assigned barber for changes.

conversation.interviewer: How long before an appointment should the WhatsApp reminder be sent, and should booking/reschedule/cancel notifications go out immediately or be batched (and if immediate, should the system retry if delivery fails)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down exact timing/retry rules right now. A default reminder like 24 hours before is fine, and notifications can go out immediately; basic retries are okay but not something I want to spend time specifying yet.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: What filters should the browse/search page provide for narrowing barbers and services (e.g., service type, date/time availability, price range, rating), and should the selected filters persist when the customer navigates back from the booking page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting too detailed on filters yet. Basic service type and date/time availability are enough for now, and yeah it’d be nice if the filters stayed selected when they go back from booking.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more interaction details right now. Keeping it simple and easy to use is enough for me at this stage.

conversation.interviewer: What core entities do you need the system to store and manage for your barber shop (e.g., customers, barbers, services, appointments, working hours/availability)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about going deep into the data model right now. At a high level though: customers, barbers, services, appointments, and basic availability/working hours.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main sections of the website to be organized in the navigation (for example, which top-level pages or menu items you definitely want, and how customers should move between them)?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like the site to use (e.g., for primary buttons and links)?

conversation.interviewer: Besides the charcoal accent and white text, what base colors (if any) would you like for the main UI components—for example, the default button background, cards/panels, and the top navigation bar?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your charcoal accent or set as separate specific colors?

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a customer, I want to book an appointment online so that I can schedule a visit without calling the shop.

Feature2: As a customer, I want to receive a WhatsApp booking confirmation so that I know my appointment is confirmed.

Feature3: As a customer, I want to receive a WhatsApp reminder about 24 hours before my appointment so that I don’t forget it.

Feature4: As a customer, I want to receive WhatsApp notifications when my appointment is rescheduled or canceled so that I stay informed about changes.

Feature5: As a barber, I want to receive notifications when an appointment assigned to me is created, rescheduled, or canceled (TBD level of detail) so that I can keep track of my schedule.

Feature6: As a customer, I want the system to send booking, reschedule, and cancel notifications immediately so that I get timely updates.

Feature7: As a system, I want to perform basic retries for failed WhatsApp notifications (TBD exact rules) so that important messages have a better chance of being delivered.

Feature8: As a customer, I want a simple browse/search page to find barbers and services so that I can quickly choose who and what I’m booking.

Feature9: As a customer, I want to filter barbers and services by service type so that I can see providers that offer what I need.

Feature10: As a customer, I want to filter available time slots by date/time so that I can find appointments that fit my schedule.

Feature11: As a customer, I want to book directly from the browse/search page so that I don’t have to go through many extra steps.

Feature12: As a customer, I want my selected filters (service type, date/time) to persist when I navigate back from the booking page so that I don’t have to reapply them.

Feature13: As a customer, I want the website to be simple and easy to use so that I can complete bookings without confusion.

Feature14: As an admin or staff member, I want the system to manage basic entities (customers, barbers, services, appointments, working hours/availability) so that I can run the shop’s operations from one place.

Feature15: As a customer, I want to easily access Services/Barbers, Book Appointment, and Contact pages from the main navigation so that I can quickly find what I need.

Feature16: As an admin or staff member, I want a dedicated Admin/Staff area so that I can manage barbers, services, schedules, and appointments separately from the customer-facing site.

Feature17: As a customer, I want to see a clear list of currently available barbers so that I can choose who to book with.

Feature18: As a customer, I want each barber listing to show at least their name, photo, services they provide, and next available times so that I can make an informed choice.

Feature19: As a customer, I want the site to use a charcoal/dark gray accent color with white text on key elements so that important buttons and links are visually clear.

Feature20: As a customer, I want the site to use a snow/off‑white background with white cards and subtle borders/shadows so that the interface feels clean and readable.

Feature21: As a customer, I want the top navigation bar to use the charcoal/dark gray background with white text so that navigation is consistent with the overall theme.

Feature22: As a customer, I want colors and text contrast to be clearly readable (approximately WCAG AA if feasible) so that I can comfortably use the site.

Feature23: As a user, I want standard success and error states (e.g., green for success, red for errors) derived from the charcoal theme so that feedback and status messages are easy to understand.

Feature24: As a customer, I want the visual design to be minimal and clean without extra barber-themed decorations so that the site looks modern and uncluttered.

task_name: Women’s Health Survey Information Management System
initial_requirements: I want a website that lets people submit health information and supports collecting and managing survey data.
user_stories: As a user, I want to access a health survey website specifically for women, so that I can fill out and submit my health information.
As a user, I want to fill out the relevant health survey on the website, so that I can provide my health information.
As a user, I want to submit my completed health survey information through the website, so that my data is sent to the system.
As a user, I want the system to provide data management functions, so that my submitted health information can be organized and maintained.
As a user, I want the system to provide permission management functions, so that access to my health information can be controlled.
As a user, I want the system to provide data review functions, so that my submitted health information can be examined and checked.
As a user, I want the system to provide reporting functions, so that information derived from my submitted data can be presented in reports.
As a user, I want the website to use whitesmoke as the default background, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the website components to be styled in dark cyan, so that the component appearance matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: For entering and managing survey and health information, could you describe the typical workflows you want users and staff to follow (e.g., how they start a form, save progress, submit, edit, or perform bulk updates), and any specific steps or constraints those workflows must include?
conversation.user: Participants should be able to start a survey from a link or their account, save progress, and come back later (mobile-friendly), then submit and get a confirmation. After submission they can only edit for a short window or by request, and staff can review, flag, and correct entries with an audit trail. Staff also need bulk tools to export/import (CSV) and send reminders to incomplete surveys, but no one should be able to see other participants’ health info.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the participant survey completion and staff review/correction process, are there any other processes that you want to be modeled as explicit multi-step workflows with named statuses (for example, “submitted → under review → approved → archived”), and if so, which ones and what key steps should they include?
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like a clear status workflow for each submission: Draft → Submitted → Under staff review → Clarification requested (if needed) → Finalized/Approved → Archived. Also for participant accounts/permissions: Invited → Active → Suspended/Revoked, with staff actions logged.

conversation.interviewer: For a typical survey submission, what specific data fields should the participant be able to enter or edit, and which of those fields are required versus optional?
conversation.user: It’ll vary by survey, but generally: required fields are participant identifier (pre-filled), consent/acknowledgment, survey date, core health questions (e.g., conditions, medications, key symptoms), and required demographics (age range, sex at birth). Optional fields: free-text notes, attachments (if we allow uploads), additional lifestyle questions, and contact preferences. Participants should be able to edit anything in Draft; after submit only a short window, and some fields (like ID) should never be editable.

conversation.interviewer: Focusing on survey submissions specifically, which actions do you want staff to be able to perform in the interface (create new, view details, edit, delete, duplicate, bulk export, bulk import, bulk update, bulk delete, etc.), and are there any of these that should be restricted or disallowed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact set of staff UI actions as long as they can review/correct submissions with an audit trail and do CSV export/import and reminders. I’d prefer staff can’t hard-delete health submissions—only archive/void them—and bulk updates should be tightly permissioned.

conversation.interviewer: For actions like sending reminder emails, running CSV imports/exports, archiving submissions, or moving items between statuses, which of these should happen automatically based on time or events (e.g., after X days in Draft or immediately on submission) and which should only occur when a staff user explicitly triggers them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact split, as long as reminders can be scheduled/automated and status changes are controlled. Archiving and anything that changes submitted data should be staff-triggered, not automatic.

conversation.interviewer: When a participant or staff user hits an error or conflict while saving/submitting or changing a submission’s status (e.g., validation errors, edit window expired, permission denied), what specific follow-up options should the UI offer—such as retry, return to edit, save as draft, request an override/clarification, or contact support?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact UI options here. Just make the error messages clear and let users either fix and retry, save as draft, or contact support/request staff help if they’re blocked by permissions or an expired edit window.

conversation.interviewer: How should participants and staff authenticate to the site (e.g., email/password, magic link, SSO), and do you need any identity verification beyond account login?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact authentication method, as long as it’s secure and easy for participants. Email/password or magic links are fine, and I don’t think we need extra identity verification beyond login unless you think it’s required for compliance.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the interface details like that. Just keep it fast and mobile-friendly so people can complete surveys without friction.

conversation.interviewer: For the admin side of the system, could you describe what kind of admin area or dashboard you want (if any)—for example, whether you want a single “system admin” section with navigation for managing users, surveys, permissions, and system settings, and what key items should be manageable from there?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact admin dashboard layout. As long as staff can manage users/invites/roles, create/edit surveys, view submissions by status, run exports/imports, send reminders, and see audit logs, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: For staff and administrators who manage users, surveys, and submissions, could you describe the main roles you envision (e.g., super admin, data manager, read-only reviewer) and what each role should be allowed to do or be prevented from doing with participant data and system settings?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact role breakdown. At minimum we need an admin who can manage surveys/users/settings, staff who can review and correct submissions with an audit trail, and a read-only role for viewing/exporting only—no one should be able to access data they don’t need or hard-delete submissions.

conversation.interviewer: For each managed entity (surveys, participant accounts, and survey submissions), what specific lifecycle operations must the system support (e.g., create, edit, publish/unpublish, activate/deactivate, archive/void), and are any operations explicitly forbidden (like hard delete)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about listing every lifecycle operation in detail. The only strong constraint is: no hard-deleting health submissions—archive/void instead—and participant accounts should be able to be invited, activated, or suspended with actions logged.

conversation.interviewer: For admin and staff actions (like changing statuses, editing submissions, managing users/roles, or running imports/exports), what specific oversight and control mechanisms do you want—such as mandatory action logs, justifications/notes for sensitive changes, approval steps, or extra confirmations for certain operations?
conversation.user: I don’t care a lot about the exact oversight mechanics. Just make sure there’s a solid audit log for staff actions, and maybe require an extra confirmation (and optional note) for sensitive things like edits after submission, status changes, and bulk imports/updates.

conversation.interviewer: What notification channels should the system use to communicate with participants (e.g., email only, SMS, or in-app notifications)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact channels. Email-only is fine to start, and SMS could be a nice add-on later if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any other specialized admin-only process flows you need (beyond managing surveys/users/submissions), such as running a periodic data quality review cycle or compliance reporting, and if so what is one example flow and its key steps?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specialized admin-only flows like that right now. If it becomes necessary later, we can add something, but it’s not a current requirement.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details beyond keeping it fast and mobile-friendly. If I had to pick one: make it easy to resume an in-progress survey from any device without hunting through menus.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the participant area and the staff/admin area, and how should users navigate between them (e.g., top menu vs dashboard tiles vs sidebar)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact page list or navigation pattern. As long as participants can quickly start/resume surveys, see submission status/confirmations, and staff can get to submissions-by-status, user management, survey setup, exports/imports, and audit logs without it being confusing.

conversation.interviewer: In the staff interface for viewing submissions, what filters/search fields must be available (e.g., participant ID, status, date range, survey type), and should the system remember the last-used filter settings between visits?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact filter set. The basics like status, date range, survey type, and participant ID are enough, and yes—remembering last-used filters would be nice but not critical.

conversation.interviewer: For the staff/admin area, how would you prefer the main navigation to be structured—what top-level sections or menus (for example, “Submissions,” “Surveys,” “Participants/Users,” “Exports/Imports,” “Audit Logs,” “Settings”) should exist, and which one should be the default landing view when an admin signs in?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation structure. If you need a default, land staff on a Submissions-by-status view, with the other sections (Surveys, Participants/Users, Exports/Imports, Audit Logs, Settings) accessible from a simple sidebar or top menu.

conversation.interviewer: When staff or admins change important configuration/settings (like survey definitions, reminder schedules, or permissions), do you want those changes to apply immediately inline, or go through a draft-and-review/approval step before they take effect?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of configuration workflow right now. Applying changes immediately is fine, as long as there’s an audit log and maybe a simple confirmation for big changes.

conversation.interviewer: How should the system handle file uploads and downloads for optional attachments—what file types and maximum size should be allowed, and should downloads be direct links or require signing in each time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the attachment upload specifics right now. If we do support them, I’d default to common formats (PDF/JPG/PNG) with a reasonable size limit and require sign-in to download.

task_name: Driver Recruitment and Job Posting System
initial_requirements: I want a recruitment website that connects drivers with job opportunities and helps employers find suitable drivers.
user_stories: As a user, I want to register on the website and create a profile, so that I can use the recruitment services for drivers and job listings.
As a user, I want to be able to apply for jobs, so that I can seek driver positions available on the website.
As a user, I want to manage my contact information, so that my details are up to date for communication regarding job opportunities.
As a client, I want to post job listings, so that I can advertise driver positions that need to be filled.
As a client, I want to view my active job postings, so that I can see which positions are currently advertised.
As a user, I want to fill out and submit a contact form, so that I can get in touch with the website operators.
As a user, I want to access a home page, so that I can see the main entry point and overview of the website.
As a user, I want to access an about us page, so that I can learn more about the organization behind the website.
As a user, I want to access a clients page, so that I can view information relevant to clients using the recruitment services.
As a user, I want to access a drivers page, so that I can view information relevant to drivers using the recruitment services.
As a user, I want to access a jobs page, so that I can view available job listings.
As a user, I want to access a contact page, so that I can find ways to contact the organization.
As a user, I want the website design to use white as the background color, so that the interface matches the specified visual style.
As a user, I want the website design to use navy for content blocks, so that the interface matches the specified visual style.

conversation.interviewer: What user roles should the site support (e.g., driver, employer, admin), and should visitors be able to browse listings without logging in?
conversation.user: It should support driver, employer, and admin roles. I’d like drivers and employers to register and create profiles before they can apply, post jobs, or message, but visitors can browse basic job listings without logging in.

conversation.interviewer: What specific information and verification/approval steps (e.g., email/phone verification, license upload, admin approval) should be required when drivers register, and what should be required when employers register?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed verification workflows right now. Just basic email verification for both drivers and employers is fine to start, and we can add things like license uploads or admin approval later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What login methods should users have besides email/password (e.g., Google/LinkedIn social login, magic link, two-factor authentication)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra login methods right now. Email/password with basic email verification is fine to start; we can add Google login or 2FA later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific UI interaction details right now. Just make it clean and responsive on mobile and desktop, and we can refine the feel later.

conversation.interviewer: How long should a user stay logged in before their session expires due to inactivity (and should “remember me” keep them logged in across browser restarts)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about session timeout specifics right now. A reasonable default is fine, and we can tweak it later if it becomes an issue.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—navigation should be simple with clearly separated top-level pages: Home, Jobs, Drivers, Clients/Employers, and Contact. A persistent top nav (and hamburger menu on mobile) should make it easy to jump between them.

conversation.interviewer: For the dimension «NavigationAndPages» (covering aspects such as browsing and discovery structure, core pages and navigation structure, list to detail navigation, and related aspects), could you tell me your specific preferences? Please describe what you have in mind, for example: which options you prefer, or any concrete requirements.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about more navigation/page details beyond what I said—just keep the top-level pages simple (Home, Jobs, Drivers, Employers, Contact) with a clear menu on desktop and a hamburger on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Should drivers and employers be able to send direct in-platform messages to each other, or should communication happen only via contact details/email after an application?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about messaging specifics right now. If it’s simple to include, in-platform messaging would be nice, but we can also start with email/contact details after applying and add chat later.

conversation.interviewer: When a driver applies to a job, what specific fields should the application form require (e.g., phone, location, license type, years of experience, availability, resume/CV upload)?
conversation.user: Keep it pretty simple to start: name, phone, email (pre-filled from profile), current location, license type/class, years of experience, availability, and a short note. Optional CV/resume upload would be nice, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: For employer job posting, what fields should the “Post a Job” form include, and which of those fields are required vs optional?
conversation.user: For the “Post a Job” form, required fields should be: job title, company name (from employer profile), location, license type/class required, job type (full-time/part-time/contract), schedule/shift, pay range, and a short job description. Optional: benefits, start date, experience minimum, equipment/truck type, routes (local/regional/OTR), number of openings, application deadline, and contact preference (in-platform vs email/phone).

conversation.interviewer: What filters should users have on the Jobs list page (e.g., location, license class, job type, pay range, schedule), and should the site remember their chosen filters when they leave and come back?
conversation.user: On the Jobs list, filters should include location (city/region + radius), license class/type, job type (FT/PT/contract), pay range, schedule/shift, and route type (local/regional/OTR). Yes, please remember the last-used filters (and sort) when they come back, at least on the same device/browser.

conversation.interviewer: For the job filters you described, should they auto-apply as users change each filter, or only update results after clicking an “Apply filters” button (and should multi-select be allowed within a filter like license type or route type)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of filter behavior right now. Default behavior is fine—just whatever feels standard and not confusing.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a keyword/text search box on the Jobs list, and which job fields should it search (e.g., title, company, location, description)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the keyword search specifics right now. Having a basic search box is fine—just a standard search over job title and location to start.

conversation.interviewer: For the jobs results list, should users be able to sort the listings, and if so, which sort options do you want (for example, newest first, highest pay first, closest location first)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sorting specifics right now. If you include it, just the basics like newest first and maybe highest pay first are enough.

conversation.interviewer: For job postings, what bulk actions should employers be able to perform from their jobs list (e.g., bulk close/expire, bulk delete, bulk duplicate, bulk edit pay or schedule)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about bulk actions right now. If you include anything, bulk close/expire and bulk delete are the only ones I’d want to start with.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the job search results themselves to be laid out and organized—for example, a simple vertical list of job cards with basic info and “View details” links, or a more tabular layout with columns like title, company, location, pay, and type?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact layout right now. A simple vertical list of job cards with the key info and a “View details” link is totally fine to start.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific fields should the Jobs keyword search query look through (e.g., job title only, title + location, or also company name and description)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of detail right now. Just search job title and location to start, and we can expand to company name/description later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond job applications themselves, do you want any user-generated content or community features at launch—such as driver reviews of employers, employer ratings of drivers, or public comments on job posts—or should there be none initially?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about community features at launch—let’s skip reviews/ratings/comments for now and keep it focused on job listings and applications. We can add that later if there’s demand.

conversation.interviewer: What specific entities should the admin be able to manage in an admin area at launch (e.g., users, job posts, applications, reported content), and what actions should they be able to perform on them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed admin management at launch. Just let admins view/manage users, job posts, and applications—basic actions like edit, deactivate/ban, and remove/close listings are enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the site should be multi-step workflows with clear stages/statuses (for example: job posting draft → published → closed, or application submitted → reviewed → shortlisted/rejected → hired)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed multi-step workflows or statuses right now. Basic states like job post: draft/published/closed and application: submitted/accepted/rejected are enough to start.

initial_requirements: I want a website that connects blue-collar workers with employers by helping workers showcase their skills and employers find suitable candidates.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use a blue-collar job site that connects blue-collar workers with employers, so that I can find or fill blue-collar job opportunities.
As a user, I want to create a profile that includes my name, so that employers can identify me.
As a user, I want to add my contact information to my profile, so that employers can reach me.
As a user, I want to list my skills and qualifications in my profile, so that employers can understand my capabilities.
As a user, I want to provide my email address in my profile, so that communication can occur via email.
As a user, I want to upload photos to my profile, so that employers can view visual information about me.
As a user, I want to browse job listings on the site, so that I can see available blue-collar job opportunities.
As a user, I want to search job listings on the site, so that I can find relevant blue-collar job opportunities efficiently.
As a user, I want the job listings to include roles such as construction workers, plumbers, electricians, and more, so that I can find specific types of blue-collar positions.
As a user, I want the website layout background to use an ivory color, so that the visual appearance is consistent with that design.
As a user, I want interactive elements on the website to use a forest green color, so that the interactive parts are visually distinguished according to that design.

conversation.interviewer: For your platform, what types of user accounts and authentication flows do you want to support (e.g., separate worker vs. employer roles, social login vs. email/password, and any need for real-name or ID verification for either role)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy auth flows right now. Just basic worker vs employer accounts with email/password, and maybe Google login later—no ID verification needed initially.

conversation.interviewer: During registration, what information must a new worker or employer provide (e.g., name, email, phone, company details), and is the account activated immediately or after any approval step?
conversation.user: For workers: name, email, phone number, and city/area, plus a couple skill tags. For employers: name, email, phone, company name, and location. Accounts should activate immediately—no manual approval at launch.

conversation.interviewer: When employers search for workers, what specific search and filter options do you want them to have (for example, search by skill tags, city/area, availability, experience level), and which of those should be required for a useful first version?
conversation.user: For a first version, let employers search by skill tags and filter by city/area—that’s the minimum. Nice-to-have filters are availability (full-time/part-time/contract) and experience level/years, but those can come later.

conversation.interviewer: To confirm the first release behavior: beyond filtering workers by city/area, do you want any additional filters at all in version one (such as availability or experience), or should those be completely omitted until a later update?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra filters in version one—just skill tags + city/area is fine. We can add availability and experience later.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want employers to have a free-text/keyword search box for workers, and if so which fields should it search (e.g., name, skill tags, city/area, profile summary)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a keyword search box for the first version. Skill tags + city/area filters are enough to start with.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific UI interaction requirements right now—just make it simple and reasonably fast on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: Apart from workers and employers, are there any other core entities you definitely want the system to model from the start (for example, job postings, applications, saved favorites), and if so which ones?
conversation.user: Yes—job postings are the main extra entity I want from the start so workers can browse listings. Applications can be a simple “apply/contact” action tied to a posting, but we can keep it lightweight in v1; favorites can wait.

conversation.interviewer: For each of your three core entities—worker, employer, and job posting—what are the exact fields you want to store on their records in version one (beyond what you’ve already listed for registration), such as descriptions, status flags, salary or rate, job type, or any other key attributes?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super exact on all the fields in v1. Just add a basic profile summary for workers, and for job postings a title, description, pay range, job type (full-time/part-time/contract), and an active/closed status; employers can have a short company description.

conversation.interviewer: For worker profiles, employer/company pages, and job posting pages in v1, which specific fields should be displayed on the detail view for each (not stored—just shown to users)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about being super specific on what’s displayed in v1. Just show the essentials: worker name/city/skills/summary/contact button, employer company name/location/short description, and job title/location/pay range/type/description plus an apply/contact button.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want workers and job postings to be categorized in v1—for example, what exact set of skill tags or industry/trade categories will you use, and are those tags user-entered or chosen from a predefined list?
conversation.user: In v1, I’d keep it simple with a predefined list of common trades (construction, plumbing, electrical, HVAC, carpentry, welding, painting, landscaping, driving/warehouse, cleaning). Workers and employers should pick from that list, and maybe allow a couple custom tags if nothing fits.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level navigation/pages should the v1 site have (e.g., Home, Browse Workers, Browse Jobs, Post a Job, Messages/Applications, Profile, Admin), and how should they be grouped in the menu?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about perfect navigation structure for v1. Just keep it simple: Home, Browse Jobs, Browse Workers, Post a Job (employers), and Profile/Account; maybe a basic Applications/Contacts page later.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the data your own platform stores (workers, employers, job postings), do you want the system in v1 to use or integrate with any external data sources (e.g., public job feeds, government/union trade registries, external resume databases), or should it rely only on its internal data?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about external data integrations for v1. Let’s rely on internal data only for now, and we can revisit integrations later if we need them.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any more content requirements right now—what we covered is enough for v1. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color would you like UI components such as buttons, links, and highlights to use across the site?
conversation.user: Let’s use a forest green as the primary accent color for buttons, links, and highlights across the site.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for text and UI components (for example, meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios), or should we just follow general best practices without targeting a formal standard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about targeting a formal accessibility standard in v1. Just follow general best practices and make sure text is readable with good contrast, especially on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color set for UI states like hover/active/disabled and feedback states like success/error, derived from your forest green accent, or can we pick standard independent colors for those states?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a full color system for v1. Just pick standard, clear colors for hover/disabled and success/error, and keep everything readable with good contrast.

conversation.interviewer: What base color should key UI components like cards/panels and the top navigation bar use (e.g., white, light gray, dark)?
conversation.user: Let’s use an ivory base for the overall background and cards/panels. For the top nav, a slightly darker warm gray/off-white would work so the forest green accents stand out.

conversation.interviewer: Which colors should be used for accents and highlights on interactive or emphasized elements (e.g. links, active states, badges, focus outlines)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down all those accent/highlight colors in v1. Just use the forest green for primary accents and pick standard, clear colors for things like focus/active/badges as long as contrast stays good.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI components should use the same standardized style across the entire site (e.g., buttons, form inputs, cards, navigation, modals)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about standardizing every component in v1. If you do anything, just keep buttons, form inputs, and cards consistent site-wide so it feels cohesive.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific additional colors, patterns, or visual motifs (e.g., tools, construction textures, trade-related icons) that you want incorporated so the overall look clearly reflects a blue-collar/trades brand, or should we keep the design mostly clean and minimal around the forest green/ivory scheme?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding specific motifs or patterns in v1. Let’s keep it clean and minimal with the forest green/ivory scheme, and maybe just use simple trade-related icons where they fit.

initial_requirements: I want a website that connects students with internship opportunities and helps employers find suitable interns.
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to provide an internship portal website that connects students with companies offering internship opportunities, so that both groups can interact for internship placements.
As a user, I want the system to provide a student panel, so that students have a dedicated area to access student-specific internship features.
As a user, I want the system to provide a company panel, so that companies have a dedicated area to access company-specific internship features.
As a user, I want the students to browse internships via the student panel, so that they can view available internship opportunities.
As a user, I want the students to apply for internships via the student panel, so that the students can submit applications for positions they are interested in.
As a user, I want the companies to post internship positions via the company panel, so that they can offer internship opportunities to students.
As a user, I want the website to be optimized for navigation, so that I can easily find and access the features and information I need.
As a user, I want the website background to use the color mint cream, so that the site has the specified background appearance.
As a user, I want all components on the website to use the color teal, so that the components have the specified color appearance.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like authentication and user roles to work on the site—for example, should students and employers have separate account types with different permissions, and do you require real-name or student-status verification for either group?
conversation.user: Yes—separate account types for students and employers with different dashboards/permissions. Students should have a student panel where they can browse and apply; employers can post roles and manage applicants. I’d like basic email verification for everyone, and some kind of student-status verification for students (school email or upload ID), but employers don’t need real-name verification beyond company email/domain.

conversation.interviewer: During registration, what specific information and fields should students and employers have to fill out (e.g., profile details, documents), and do you want any manual approval or is access granted automatically once email/student-status is verified?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact field-by-field registration form details right now. As long as students can verify student status (school email or ID upload) and employers can verify via company email/domain, and then access is granted automatically once those checks pass.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the basic student and employer roles, do you want any more granular permission levels (e.g., different types of employer staff or admin roles with restricted capabilities), or is a simple two-role model sufficient for how you imagine controlling access to features and data?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about granular roles right now—two roles (student and employer) is fine. We can always add an admin role later if it becomes necessary.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—clear, intuitive navigation: a simple top nav plus a prominent search bar so students can quickly filter internships (location, role type, keyword) and get to apply in a couple clicks.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the top navigation for each role (student vs employer), and how should the browsing flow go from search results to an internship detail page to applying?
conversation.user:
For students: Home/Search, Internships (browse), Applications, Messages/Notifications, Profile/Verification. Flow: search/filter -> results list -> internship detail page with requirements and company info -> “Apply” button -> quick form (resume/cover letter) -> confirmation and it shows up in Applications.

For employers: Dashboard, Post Internship, Manage Listings, Applicants, Messages, Company Profile. Flow: create/post -> listing page -> view applicants per listing -> open applicant profile -> message/shortlist/reject.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want the internships browsing experience to be structured—primarily as a filterable list of postings, or should there also be category/grouped views (e.g., by industry, location, remote/on-site, company) that users can browse without searching?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about category/grouped browsing right now. A strong filterable list with search (location, role type, keywords, remote/on-site) is enough to start.

conversation.interviewer: When a student runs a search with filters (location, role type, remote/on-site, keywords), how would you like the search and filters to behave—for example, should filters stay applied as they move between pages or sessions, and do you want any advanced options like saving searches or sorting results (by date posted, relevance, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about anything advanced right now. Just keep filters applied while they’re browsing results and detail pages, and basic sorting like “newest first” is enough—no need for saved searches yet.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding another interaction requirement right now—what we’ve covered for navigation and filtering is enough for the first version.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main data elements you want to store for each core entity—specifically, what fields should an internship posting have (e.g., title, location, duration, paid/unpaid, requirements), and what fields should a student profile have (e.g., education, skills, resume link)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down every field right now. For internships, just the basics like title, company, location/remote, duration, description, requirements, and how to apply; for student profiles, name, school, major/year, skills, and a resume upload/link is enough to start.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main content to be structured hierarchically—for example, which sections or pages should be grouped together under broader areas in the navigation (for students and for employers), and are there any sections you want nested or separated to keep things clear?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact hierarchy/nesting right now. As long as the top nav stays simple and the key pages we listed are easy to find, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else on content for now—just make sure employers can create/edit/close listings and see applicant lists per posting, and students can view clear requirements and application instructions on the detail page. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic resume and student-ID uploads, do you envision supporting any other file or media types (e.g., employer-attached job PDFs, company intro videos, student portfolios/links), and if so, which ones are important for this first version?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting extra media types in the first version. Resume upload (PDF) and optional student ID upload is enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements right now—we can move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color should the site use for primary actions (e.g., the main “Apply” button and active navigation state)?
conversation.user: Let’s use teal as the main accent/highlight color for primary actions like the Apply button and active nav states.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme (for example, adhering to WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and buttons), or is general good readability without formal standards sufficient for now?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about formal WCAG targets right now. Just make sure it’s generally readable—good contrast for text/buttons and nothing too low-contrast with the teal.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your teal accent or specified separately?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining all the state colors right now. Just use sensible defaults—maybe derive hover/active from the teal, and use standard success/error colors that are easy to read.

conversation.interviewer: What base color should key UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar use as their primary background/fill (e.g., white, light gray, dark)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a mint cream base background for the main UI—cards/panels can be white on top of that, and the nav can be white or a very light gray so the teal accents stand out.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the overall page/layout background be across the site (outside of cards/panels)—should it be mint cream globally?
conversation.user: Yeah, mint cream globally is fine for the overall background. I’m not too picky on that as long as it stays clean and readable.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual rules you want enforced consistently across all pages (for example, a single standard button style, card style, and heading style), or is it enough to just follow the chosen colors and “clean, simple” look without a formal style system?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a formal style system right now. Just keep it consistent—same button/card styles and a clean, simple look using the teal and mint cream palette.
