conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site’s visual theme to reflect any specific brand or vibe (e.g., “modern tech,” “academic/campus,” “corporate/professional”), or should it stay neutral with just the teal + mint cream palette?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific brand vibe right now—neutral is fine. Just keep it clean and modern with the teal + mint cream palette.

initial_requirements: I want an online platform that connects athletes with sports organizations, helping both sides find opportunities and communicate.
user_stories: As a user, I want a high-performance sports recruitment platform that connects athletes and sports organizations, so that I can use it efficiently for recruitment-related activities.
As a user, I want the athletes to register on the platform, so that they can create an athlete profile and participate in recruitment activities.
As a user, I want to log in to the platform, so that I can securely access my account and its functionalities.
As a user, I want to browse job listings, so that I can view available sports-related opportunities.
As a user, I want the athletes to apply for jobs of interest, so that they can be considered for relevant sports positions.
As a user, I want to receive relevant notifications, so that I stay informed about important activities related to my account and jobs.
As a user, I want the sports organization users to post jobs on the platform, so that they can advertise opportunities to athletes.
As a user, I want the sports organization users to communicate with athletes, so that they can interact with potential candidates.
As a user, I want the platform to have message notification functionality, so that I am alerted when I receive new messages.
As a user, I want the platform’s body background set to ghost white, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the platform’s UI to use slate gray, so that the interface color scheme matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like communication between athletes and sports organizations to work on the platform—for example, do you want in‑platform messaging (1:1 and/or group chat), email notifications, and any moderation or approval rules before messages are exchanged?
conversation.user: I’d like in‑platform 1:1 messaging as the default, with optional group chats for team tryouts or event threads. Email/push notifications should alert users to new messages, but keep the full conversation in the platform. Basic moderation like spam reporting/blocking and restricting first contact until profiles are verified would be good.

conversation.interviewer: What real-time and reliability behavior do you want for in-platform messages—should chats update live without refresh, and should the system show sent/delivered/read indicators and queue messages for delivery when a user is offline?
conversation.user: Yes—chats should update in real time without refresh. I’d like sent/delivered/read indicators, and messages should queue and deliver once the other user comes back online so nothing gets lost.

conversation.interviewer: For which specific events should the platform send email/push notifications, and to which roles (athletes, organizations, or both) for each event?
conversation.user: Notify both athletes and orgs for new messages (and @mentions in group chats), plus when someone requests to start a chat and when a verified user reaches out. Also notify both sides for key application/tryout updates (invites, accept/decline, schedule changes/cancellations). Account/security alerts (password change, new login) should go to the account owner only.

conversation.interviewer: Which notification delivery channels do you want to support—email, mobile push, in-app notifications, and/or SMS?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about SMS. Email + mobile push (if they have the app) and in-app notifications are enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like to control when and how often notifications are sent—for example, how far in advance of tryouts/events reminders should go out, whether message and update alerts should be batched or sent immediately, and whether the system should retry delivery if a notification initially fails?
conversation.user: For messages and key application/tryout updates, I want notifications sent immediately. For events/tryouts, send reminders 24 hours and 1 hour before (and maybe a 7-day reminder for bigger events), with user-configurable quiet hours and a daily digest option for non-urgent stuff. Yes, retry on failures with a few backoff attempts, and fall back to in-app if push/email fails.

conversation.interviewer: What parts of the notification text should be configurable via templates—for example, which fields to include (sender name, preview snippet), whether to quote message content, and whether to support multiple languages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about templating details like exact fields or multi-language right now. Just keep notifications short and safe—show sender name and maybe a tiny preview, but don’t quote full message content in email/push by default.

conversation.interviewer: Do users need to verify their identity (for example, real name and/or documents) before they can message others, and if so, what level of verification is required for athletes vs organizations?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict identity/document verification right now. Basic email/phone verification and profile completeness is enough, with an option for organizations to get a “verified org” badge later.

conversation.interviewer: During registration, what exact information must an athlete provide before their account is created and usable (e.g., email, phone, name, sport/position, age/location), and are any steps required beyond email/phone verification and profile completeness?
conversation.user: Minimum for an athlete account: email (or phone) + password, first/last name, primary sport and position/role, date of birth/age bracket, and location (city/state). Verify email/phone, accept terms, then they can use the platform; anything else (bio, stats, highlights, eligibility) can be completed after signup but should be required before they can initiate first contact/apply.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond direct messaging, what kinds of user-generated content and community features do you want athletes and organizations to have—such as public posts, comment threads on events/tryouts, reviews/ratings, or following/feeds—and how visible should that content be (public vs only to matched/connected users)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about broader community features like public posts or reviews right now. I mostly just want profiles, listings/opportunities, and messaging; if anything, maybe a simple follow/watchlist and private comments on a tryout thread for invited participants only.

conversation.interviewer: What user roles do you need on the platform (e.g., athlete, organization admin, organization staff/coach, moderator/support), and should permissions be role-based only or configurable per organization (e.g., admins can manage billing and listings while staff can only message and review applications)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about super granular roles/permissions right now. For MVP, just athlete and organization (with one org admin account) is fine, and we can add staff/coach roles and configurable permissions later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I’d like search/browsing to feel fast and structured: a listings page with filters for sport, position, location radius, age/eligibility, and date, plus sort by “newest” and “closest.” Filters should update results instantly without a full page reload.

conversation.interviewer: Should the selected search filters persist when a user leaves and returns (e.g., via URL parameters/shareable links and/or saving their last-used filters to their account), or should filters reset each visit?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much either way for MVP. If it’s easy, URL/shareable links with the filters is nice, but resetting each visit is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—when an athlete clicks an opportunity, I want a clear “Apply” flow (not just messaging): a short form, ability to attach highlights/stats, and a confirmation screen showing the application status (submitted/seen/accepted/declined). It should be quick and mobile-friendly.

conversation.interviewer: For the “Apply” workflow, what exact fields should the short application form collect from an athlete (and which of those should be required vs optional)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact form fields right now. Keep it minimal for MVP—basic contact info, a short note, and optional links/files for highlights or stats.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages and navigation structure do you want in the platform—for example, how should users move between home, listings/search, individual opportunity detail, messaging, applications/status, and their profile?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact page/nav structure for MVP. As long as it’s simple to get to search/listings, opportunity details + apply, messages, and my profile/applications from a top nav or bottom tab bar, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific login methods do you want to support when users return to the platform—for example, traditional email/phone + password only, or also social logins (Google, Apple, etc.) or app-level biometrics (Face ID/Touch ID) on mobile?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about social logins or biometrics for the MVP. Email or phone + password is fine, as long as password reset is easy and secure.

conversation.interviewer: What rules do you want for session and account security—for example, how long users stay logged in before automatic logout, whether logins should be limited per account/device, and what security controls (like logout from all devices, 2FA, or protections for underage athletes) should be available?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super detailed on session/security rules for MVP. Just keep it standard: stay logged in for a while, easy password reset, and a “log out of all devices” option would be nice.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific parts of the platform, if any, should be usable or viewable by visitors who are not logged in—for example, can they browse opportunity listings and view basic profiles, or should almost everything require registration before access?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about guest access for the MVP. If it’s easy, letting visitors browse listings and see very basic org profiles is fine, but require login to apply or message.

conversation.interviewer: When users attach or view highlights/stats files in an application or chat, should the platform stream/play them in-app, or require downloading—and do you want an offline cache so previously viewed media is available without a connection?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about offline caching. For MVP, just let people view common media in-app when possible (videos/images), and fall back to download for other file types.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific file/media types and sources should athletes be able to attach (e.g., images, video, PDFs) and do you want uploads from device only or also links/imports from platforms like YouTube, Hudl, Google Drive, or Dropbox?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about exact types/sources for MVP. If you cover basics like images, video, and PDFs, with either a simple upload or a paste-a-link option, that’s enough for now.

task_name: Global Institute of Information Security Course Enrollment Portal
initial_requirements: I want a website for the Global Institute of Information Security where I can learn about its courses, take part in learning activities, and get in touch with the institute.
user_stories: As a user, I want to access a website for the Global Institute of Information Security, so that I can interact with its courses and enrollment services online.
As a user, I want to view a course catalog on the website, so that I can see all available courses from the institute.
As a user, I want to browse courses on the website, so that I can explore the different learning options offered.
As a user, I want to view detailed information for each course, so that I can understand what each course covers before deciding to enroll.
As a user, I want to enroll in courses online through the website, so that I can register for courses without needing to visit the institute physically.
As a user, I want to use a contact form on the website, so that I can contact the institute directly through the site.
As a user, I want to view certification pathways on the website, so that I can understand how different courses lead to specific certifications.
As a user, I want all pages of the website to use a lavender background, so that the visual style is consistent across the site.
As a user, I want all UI components to be styled in indigo, so that the website maintains a unified and coherent visual appearance.

conversation.interviewer: What core pages should be in the main navigation menu (e.g., Home, Courses, Learning Activities, About, Contact), and how should they be grouped?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact grouping in the main navigation—as long as it’s easy to find Courses, Learning Activities, and Contact quickly.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like communication and messaging with the institute to work on the website—for example, do you want just a contact form and email notifications, or also features like live chat, messaging within a student area, or different notification channels (email/SMS)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about advanced messaging features. A simple contact form that emails the right team (and maybe an auto-confirmation to me) is enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific interaction details beyond it feeling straightforward and not confusing. No extra requirements here.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s content to be organized hierarchically—for example, should “Courses” be broken into categories (like by level or topic) with dedicated subpages, or kept as a single page with sections?
conversation.user: I’d like Courses to be a structured catalog, grouped by topic and level, with each course having its own detail page. A main Courses landing page with filters and categories would be ideal.

conversation.interviewer: Besides Courses, how should the Learning Activities section be categorized for browsing (e.g., by topic, level, format, or schedule)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a strict categorization for Learning Activities. As long as I can quickly see what’s upcoming and filter by format (workshop/webinar/lab) and date, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the site should be accessible to everyone without logging in, and which parts (if any) should require users to sign in (e.g., participation in learning activities, downloadable materials, course enrollment)?
conversation.user: Most of the site should be public—Home, About, course catalog + course detail pages, and Contact. I think signing in should be required for course enrollment and for participating in learning activities (and accessing any downloadable materials tied to those).

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the Courses and Learning Activities areas you’ve described, are there any additional main hubs or child pages (such as separate sections for Research, News/Blog, Resources, or Partnerships) that you want included in the overall page hierarchy?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding extra hubs like Research or Partnerships right now. If anything, a simple News/Announcements page and maybe a basic Resources page would be nice, but not required.

conversation.interviewer: For the core data your site will manage, could you specify the main entities and key fields you want to track—for example, what exact information should be stored for each course, each learning activity, and each enrolled user?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specifying an exact data model right now. At a high level: courses need title/description/topic/level/duration and a schedule if applicable; learning activities need title/format/date-time/registration link; users just need name, email, and enrollment/participation history.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements right now. As long as course pages and activity listings are clear and easy to browse/filter, we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent/highlight color should the site use (e.g., for buttons and links)?
conversation.user: Let’s use an indigo accent/highlight color for buttons and links—something like #3F51B5 or similar—so the UI feels consistent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility requirements for color contrast and readability (such as meeting WCAG AA or AAA contrast ratios) that the site’s color scheme must adhere to?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about targeting a specific WCAG level like AA vs AAA. Just make sure the text is easy to read and the contrast isn’t low or washed out.

conversation.interviewer: For interactive elements like buttons, links, and form fields, do you want us to define a clear set of state colors (hover, active, disabled, success, error) based on your indigo accent, or are you fine with us choosing a sensible, standard state color system on our own?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining all those state colors myself—go ahead and use a sensible, standard set that works well with the indigo accent and stays readable.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components like cards and panels use (e.g., white, light gray, or a dark surface)?
conversation.user: I’d like a lavender background across the site, and for cards/panels to be a slightly lighter tint of lavender (or near-white) so they stand out but still feel cohesive.

conversation.interviewer: Should the lavender page background apply globally across all pages, or only to specific sections (and if so, which sections)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care that much—just apply the lavender background globally across all pages for consistency.

conversation.interviewer: Which visual elements should be standardized site-wide to ensure a consistent look (e.g., typography choices, spacing rules, button/card styles, icon style)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specifying which visual elements to standardize. Just keep typography, spacing, and button/card styles consistent site-wide so everything feels cohesive.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional brand-aligned decorative elements (e.g., subtle security/cyber motifs or patterns) incorporated into the UI, or should it stay clean and minimal with just the lavender background and indigo accent?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about decorative motifs—keep it clean and minimal. If you add anything, make it very subtle so it doesn’t distract from the content.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other style requirements from me. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to easily find key sections like Courses, Learning Activities, and Contact from the main navigation so I can quickly get to the most important content.

Feature2: As a user, I want a Home page that clearly introduces the Global Institute of Information Security and directs me to Courses, Learning Activities, and Contact so I understand what the institute offers.

Feature3: As a user, I want a Courses landing page that lists all courses with filters by topic and level so I can quickly narrow down the catalog.

Feature4: As a user, I want each course to have its own detail page showing the title, description, topic, level, duration, and schedule (if applicable) so I can evaluate whether the course is right for me.

Feature5: As a user, I want Learning Activities to be listed in a clear overview so I can see what opportunities are available.

Feature6: As a user, I want to filter Learning Activities by format (workshop, webinar, lab) so I can find the type of activity that suits me.

Feature7: As a user, I want to filter Learning Activities by date so I can find upcoming sessions that fit my schedule.

Feature8: As a user, I want each learning activity to show its title, format, date and time, and a registration link so I understand how and when to participate.

Feature9: As a user, I want most of the site content (Home, About, course catalog, course detail pages, Contact) to be accessible without logging in so I can explore offerings freely.

Feature10: As a user, I want to be required to sign in to enroll in courses so my enrollments are tracked under my account.

Feature11: As a user, I want to be required to sign in to participate in learning activities so my participation can be managed and recorded.

Feature12: As a user, I want to be required to sign in to access downloadable materials tied to courses and learning activities so restricted resources stay within the enrolled community.

Feature13: As a user, I want a simple Contact page with a form so I can easily get in touch with the institute.

Feature14: As a user, I want the contact form to route my message to the appropriate team by topic (TBD) so my inquiry reaches the right staff.

Feature15: As a user, I want to receive an automatic confirmation email after submitting the contact form so I know my message was received.

Feature16: As a user, I want the option of a basic News/Announcements page so I can stay informed about updates from the institute.

Feature17: As a user, I want the option of a basic Resources page so I can find helpful materials in one place.

Feature18: As a user, I want my user profile to store my name and email so I can manage my account and communications.

Feature19: As a user, I want my enrollment history in courses to be stored so I can review what I’ve taken.

Feature20: As a user, I want my participation history in learning activities to be stored so I can track my engagement with the institute.

Feature21: As a user, I want the interface to feel straightforward and not confusing so I can navigate and use the site without frustration.

Feature22: As a user, I want the site to present course and activity listings in a clear, easy-to-browse layout so I can quickly scan and compare options.

Feature23: As a user, I want the site to use an indigo accent color (around #3F51B5) for buttons and links so I can easily recognize interactive elements.

Feature24: As a user, I want text and interface elements to have sufficient contrast and readability so I can comfortably read content without eye strain.

Feature25: As a user, I want interactive elements (buttons, links, forms) to use a standard, sensible set of state colors (hover, active, disabled, success, error) that work with the indigo accent so I receive clear visual feedback on my actions.

Feature26: As a user, I want a lavender background applied consistently across all pages so the site feels visually cohesive.

Feature27: As a user, I want cards and panels to appear on a slightly lighter lavender or near-white surface so key content blocks stand out from the page background.

Feature28: As a user, I want typography, spacing, and button/card styles to be consistent across the site so the experience feels unified and professional.

Feature29: As a user, I want the visual design to be clean and minimal with only very subtle security/cyber motifs (if any) so the content remains the main focus.

initial_requirements: I want an online learning platform where I can choose data science courses, study the materials, and track my learning progress.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse Python data science courses, so that I can see what courses are available on the online learning platform.
As a user, I want to select Python data science courses of interest, so that I can choose which courses to learn.
As a user, I want to learn course content for the Python data science courses I select, so that I can study data science online.
As a user, I want to submit assignments for the Python data science courses I am taking, so that my work can be evaluated.
As a user, I want to query my own learning grades, so that I can see my performance in the Python data science courses.
As a user, I want the platform’s background layer to use a honeydew color, so that the interface follows the specified background styling.
As a user, I want the platform’s component layer to use a dark olive green color, so that the interface follows the specified component styling.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the platform and how should users navigate between them (e.g., course catalog → course detail → lesson view → progress dashboard)?
conversation.user: Core pages: Course catalog (with filters), course detail page, lesson/lecture view, and a progress dashboard/profile. Navigation should be straightforward: catalog → course detail → start course → lesson view, with a persistent menu to jump back to catalog and a “My progress” link from anywhere.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to browse and discover courses in the catalog—such as by topic categories, skill level, recommended lists, or other discovery views—and which of these should be most prominent?
conversation.user: I’d like browsing mainly by topic/category and skill level (beginner/intermediate/advanced), plus a solid search bar. Recommendations are fine but should be secondary—maybe a small “Recommended for you” section, not the main view.

conversation.interviewer: When a user is on a course detail page, which specific related views should they be able to navigate to directly from there (e.g., lessons list, first lesson, syllabus, instructor profile, reviews), and in what order of prominence?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a bunch of extra related views from the course detail page. As long as there’s a clear lessons list/syllabus and a “Start course” button that jumps into the first lesson, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between the major modules (course catalog, active course/lesson view, and progress dashboard)—for example via a top tab bar, a left sidebar, a dropdown, or a dashboard-style hub?
conversation.user: I don’t really care what UI pattern you use for switching modules. Just make it obvious and consistent—something like a simple top nav or sidebar with Catalog and My Progress always accessible.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t have any specific interaction requirements beyond it feeling fast and not laggy. As long as navigation and search respond quickly, I’m fine.

conversation.interviewer: How should lessons within a course be organized in the syllabus—one flat list, or grouped into modules/weeks (and if grouped, what grouping scheme do you prefer)?
conversation.user: I’d prefer lessons grouped into modules (or weeks) with clear titles, and a simple ordering within each module. If a course is short, a flat list is fine, but default to modules for anything bigger.

conversation.interviewer: How should courses in the catalog be categorized by topic—do you want a fixed set of top-level categories (and if so, what are they), or should categories be tag-based with multiple tags per course?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s fixed categories or tags, as long as I can filter by topic easily and the labels are consistent. If I had to pick, tags are fine.

conversation.interviewer: Within the Progress dashboard/profile, what sections should it be organized into (e.g., overall progress summary, in-progress courses, completed courses, course-by-course detail, goals/streaks)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy breakdowns like goals or streaks. Just show me my in-progress courses, completed courses, and a simple overall progress summary (percent complete/time spent) with the ability to click into a course for details.

conversation.interviewer: On the course detail page, what should the top-to-bottom layout be—for example, should it start with the course title/summary and a prominent “Start course” button, then show the lessons/syllabus, with any secondary info (e.g., instructor, prerequisites) below?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact top-to-bottom layout. Just make the “Start course” button and the lessons/syllabus easy to find near the top, and put any extra info lower down.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities do you need the platform to model and store (e.g., users, courses, modules, lessons, enrollments, and per-lesson progress records)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model as long as it supports courses with modules/lessons, user enrollments, and tracking my progress through lessons (percent complete/time spent). Everything else can be whatever’s simplest.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific parts of the platform’s content (e.g., course catalog, course detail, lesson content, progress dashboard) should be visible to anyone, and which should only be accessible after a user signs in or enrolls in a course?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact access rules. Basic browsing (catalog + course detail) can be public, but lesson content and the progress dashboard should require signing in, and probably enrolling to access the full course materials.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other content requirements come to mind. As long as the course pages have the syllabus and lesson materials, and the dashboard shows progress (percent complete/time spent), we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the primary accent (used for key buttons/links like “Start course” and active navigation) be?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact accent color. Just pick something accessible with good contrast (blue is fine).

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to browse a course catalog so that I can see available data science courses.

Feature2: As a user, I want to filter catalog courses by topic so that I can quickly find courses relevant to my interests.

Feature3: As a user, I want to filter catalog courses by skill level (beginner, intermediate, advanced) so that I can find courses that match my experience.

Feature4: As a user, I want to search the course catalog by keywords so that I can locate specific courses or topics.

Feature5: As a user, I want to see consistent topic labels/tags in the catalog so that filtering by topic feels predictable and clear.

Feature6: As a user, I want a secondary “Recommended for you” section in the catalog so that I can discover suggested courses without it overwhelming the main browsing experience.

Feature7: As a user, I want to open a course detail page from the catalog so that I can learn more about a course before starting it.

Feature8: As a user, I want the course detail page to clearly show the course syllabus/lessons list so that I understand what the course covers.

Feature9: As a user, I want a prominent “Start course” button on the course detail page near the top so that I can quickly begin learning.

Feature10: As a user, I want to jump directly from the “Start course” button into the first lesson so that I can begin the course with minimal friction.

Feature11: As a user, I want lessons within a course to be organized into titled modules/weeks by default so that longer courses feel structured and easier to navigate.

Feature12: As a user, I want short courses to optionally present lessons in a simple flat list so that the layout stays straightforward for smaller courses.

Feature13: As a user, I want a clear lesson/lecture view so that I can study course materials online.

Feature14: As a user, I want to access my in-progress course lessons from the lesson view so that I can move through the course in order.

Feature15: As a user, I want an always-accessible navigation element for the Course Catalog so that I can return to browsing from anywhere.

Feature16: As a user, I want an always-accessible navigation element for My Progress so that I can view my learning status from anywhere.

Feature17: As a user, I want the navigation pattern (e.g., top nav or sidebar) to be obvious and consistent so that I don’t get confused moving between sections.

Feature18: As a user, I want to move between the course catalog, active course/lesson view, and progress dashboard using a simple, unified navigation system so that the platform feels coherent.

Feature19: As a user, I want to browse the course catalog and view course detail pages without signing in so that I can explore offerings before committing.

Feature20: As a user, I want lesson content to require sign-in so that my learning activity is associated with my account.

Feature21: As a user, I want full course materials (beyond previews) to require enrollment so that access is tied to my course enrollments.

Feature22: As a user, I want a progress dashboard/profile so that I can see an overview of my learning status across courses.

Feature23: As a user, I want to see a list of my in-progress courses on the progress dashboard so that I can quickly resume active learning.

Feature24: As a user, I want to see a list of my completed courses on the progress dashboard so that I can review what I’ve finished.

Feature25: As a user, I want a simple overall progress summary (e.g., percent complete and/or time spent) on the dashboard so that I can gauge my learning activity at a glance.

Feature26: As a user, I want to click from the dashboard into a specific course to see course-level progress details so that I can understand my status in that course.

Feature27: As a user, I want the system to track my enrollment in each course so that it knows which courses are active or completed for me.

Feature28: As a user, I want the system to track my progress at the lesson level (e.g., percent complete, time spent) so that I can see how far I’ve advanced in each course.

Feature29: As a user, I want the platform to feel fast and responsive when navigating and searching so that I don’t experience noticeable lag.

Feature30: As a user, I want the primary accent color (e.g., on “Start course” and active navigation) to have good contrast and be accessible (blue is acceptable) so that key actions are easy to see and use.

initial_requirements: I want a student portal that connects students with suitable training opportunities and helps training providers find appropriate candidates.
user_stories: As a user, I want to register on the student portal website, so that I can create an account for managing my student information.
As a user, I want to manage my profile on the student portal, so that I can keep my personal details up to date.
As a user, I want to input and manage my qualifications, so that my educational background is accurately represented on the portal.
As a user, I want to input and manage my career preferences, so that my career interests are reflected in my profile.

As a user, I want the system to use an advanced matching algorithm, so that I can be matched with training providers based on criteria such as qualifications, location, field of study, and career interests.
As a user, I want an intuitive interface for the application process, so that I can easily apply for programs.
As a user, I want training providers to access student information based on predefined criteria, so that they can identify relevant students for their skills development programs.
As a user, I want training providers to directly communicate with students whose information they can access, so that they can attract them to their skills development programs.
As a user, I want the website to use azure as the main background color, so that the visual design aligns with the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the website controls to use midnight blue, so that the controls follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of search and filtering options should students and training providers have (e.g., search by skills, location, schedule, modality, prerequisites, language), and which of these need to be easily combinable and/or saved as reusable filters?
conversation.user: Students should be able to search trainings by location (or remote), dates/weekly schedule, modality, required skills/prereqs, language, duration, and whether it’s paid/credited—these should be combinable and they should be able to save searches/alerts. Providers should filter student profiles with predefined criteria like skills, education level, certifications, availability, location/remote, language, and eligibility (e.g., work permit), and save those filter sets as reusable templates.

conversation.interviewer: When students or providers are using filters, how do you want the interaction to work—should filter changes apply instantly as they click (auto-apply) or only after hitting an “Apply” button, and should their filter selections persist if they navigate away and come back to search later in the same session?
conversation.user: I’d prefer auto-apply with a short debounce so it feels responsive, but also an “Apply” button for heavy filters (date ranges, multiple criteria) if performance becomes an issue. And yes—filters should persist within the session if they navigate away and come back, and ideally restore last-used filters per user when they return later.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like search results to be presented—e.g., as a list of cards or a table with sortable columns—and should results load via pagination or infinite scroll?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s cards or a table—either is fine as long as it’s clear and fast. Same for pagination vs infinite scroll; just pick what’s simplest and performs well.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a general keyword/text search box for students and providers (in addition to filters), and if so, what specific fields should that search run across (e.g., training title, provider name, skills, location, description)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a general keyword search—filters are the main thing for us. If you do add it, just make it a simple “search all” across the obvious fields.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any extra interaction requirements beyond what we already covered—just keep it simple, fast, and not cluttered.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you definitely want the system to model (for example, training program, session/cohort, provider organization, student profile, application, enrollment, assessment), and how do you expect them to relate to each other (e.g., one training with many sessions, one student with many applications)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model details as long as students can find trainings and providers can find candidates. At a high level you’ll probably need trainings/sessions, providers, student profiles, and applications connecting students to sessions.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main sections of the portal to be structured and grouped in the navigation—for example, what top-level menu items or pages should exist for students and for providers, and how should related features (search, applications, profile, messaging, etc.) be organized under them?
conversation.user: For students, top-level should be: Find Trainings (search + saved alerts), My Applications, Messages, and Profile. For providers: Find Candidates (search + saved filter templates), Post/Manage Trainings, Applications/Shortlist, Messages, and Organization/Profile settings. Messaging should be accessible from applications and from a match/shortlist so providers can contact students directly.

conversation.interviewer: Should students and providers have completely separate dashboards/menus and page structures after login, or share the same core pages with the content changing based on their role?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. As long as students and providers see the right options for their role and it’s clear and simple after login.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the portal should be publicly viewable without logging in, and which pages/features should require login (and be restricted to student-only vs provider-only access)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about what’s public vs behind login. If you need a default, make browsing basic training listings public, but require login for applying, saving alerts, messaging, and for providers to view candidate profiles and manage postings.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One thing on content: student profiles should have structured fields like education/qualifications, certifications, key skills, languages, availability/schedule, location/remote preference, and work eligibility. For training listings, include clear prerequisites, schedule/dates, modality, duration, language, and whether it’s paid/credited. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: How should trainings be categorized for browsing—for example, what primary categories or taxonomy should users navigate by (e.g., industry/field, skill area, level, credential type)—to make it easy to find relevant opportunities without using filters?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed taxonomy for browsing since we’re mostly relying on filters. If you need something simple, use broad industry/field categories plus level (beginner/intermediate/advanced) and credential type.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content need: show a “match score/why matched” explanation on both sides (e.g., which skills, location, availability, eligibility criteria aligned), and flag missing requirements. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: On a training detail page, how would you like the main information to be ordered and grouped—for example, what should appear first (title, key facts like dates/location/prerequisites/match score), what should come next (description, “why matched” explanation, flagged missing requirements), and what can be pushed further down (provider info, similar trainings, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact ordering on the training detail page. Just make the key facts and prerequisites easy to spot, and include the match score/why matched somewhere obvious.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need an audit trail/change history for key records (e.g., trainings, student profiles, applications), and if so who should be able to view it and for how long should that history be retained?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about an audit trail/change history for this. If you add something by default, just keep a basic internal log for admins for troubleshooting, but it’s not a priority for us.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any built‑in templates or reusable content blocks (for example, standard training listing templates or standard student profile sections) that providers or students can use as a starting point, and if so, what specific templates should be available?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about built-in templates right now. If you include anything, a basic training listing template with the standard fields (prereqs, schedule, modality, duration, language, paid/credited) would be enough.

conversation.interviewer: What file/media uploads should the portal support (e.g., PDF resumes, certificates, portfolio links, training brochures), and what limits should apply per upload (allowed formats and maximum size)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about uploads for now. If you need a default, support PDF resumes and PDF/JPG/PNG certificates, maybe up to ~10MB per file, and let portfolios be links rather than uploads.

conversation.interviewer: What analytics dashboards or metrics do you want in the portal (for students, providers, and/or admins), and what should each show?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about analytics dashboards right now. If you need basics, give providers simple stats like views, applications, and shortlists per training, and admins a high-level count of active users/trainings and application volume.

conversation.interviewer: What user-facing help or guides do you want in the portal (e.g., a Help Center/FAQ and short in-page tooltips), and where should users access them (top navigation link, page footer, or contextually within pages)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about help/guides. If you add something, a simple Help/FAQ link in the footer plus a few contextual tooltips on the search filters and application steps is enough.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the accent/highlight colors used on interactive components (like primary buttons, links, and selected filters), including how bold/subtle they should feel and any accessibility or contrast requirements you want us to follow?
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like azure as the main background color. For buttons/links, keep highlights fairly subtle but clearly visible, and please follow standard WCAG contrast so everything stays readable.

conversation.interviewer: Should the azure you mentioned be used as the main background for the entire page (global layout), or only for certain sections (e.g., header/sidebar), and if partial, where should you still prefer a neutral/light background instead?
conversation.user: I don’t really care that much—use azure more as an accent in the header/sidebar and key sections, and keep the main content area on a neutral light background so it stays easy to read.

task_name: Coaching Match and Session Management System
initial_requirements: I want a web application that helps me understand myself, connect with suitable coaches, and support my personal development over time.
user_stories: As a user, I want the application to provide one-to-one coaching session capabilities to match coaches and users, so that I can engage in individualized coaching.
As a user, I want the application to include a personality assessment functionality, so that I can complete a personality assessment.
As a user, I want the application to provide user profile functionality, so that I can create and manage my profile.
As a user, I want the application to include coaching and mentorship matching functionality, so that I can be matched with suitable coaches.
As a user, I want the application to provide scheduling and session management functionality, so that I can manage my coaching sessions.
As a user, I want the application to include goal setting and progress tracking functionality, so that I can set and track my goals.
As a user, I want to search for suitable coaches, so that I can find coaches who meet my needs.
As a user, I want to select suitable coaches from the search results, so that I can choose who will coach me.
As a user, I want to schedule coaching sessions, so that I can plan when my coaching will take place.
As a user, I want to set goals within the application, so that my coaching objectives are clearly defined.
As a user, I want to track my goals within the application, so that I can monitor my progress over time.
As a user, I want the web application’s background to be beige, so that the interface appears with that background color.
As a user, I want the components in the web application to be styled with saddle brown, so that the interface components appear in that color.

conversation.interviewer: What communication features should the app include between users and coaches—e.g., in-app chat, scheduled video calls, email messaging, or all of these?
conversation.user: I mainly want one-to-one coaching with scheduled video calls. In-app messaging would be great for quick follow-ups between sessions, but I don’t really need email inside the app.

conversation.interviewer: For the in-app messaging between users and coaches, what specific capabilities do you want it to support (for example, text only, file or voice-note sharing, read receipts, typing indicators, or anything else)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy messaging features—text-only is fine for quick follow-ups. File sharing would be nice to have, but I don’t need voice notes, read receipts, or typing indicators.

conversation.interviewer: When a user sends an in-app message, should it update live in real time for the other person when they’re online, and if they’re offline should it be stored and delivered later automatically?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about real-time vs. delayed delivery details—whatever’s simplest is fine. As long as messages don’t get lost and show up when the other person comes back online.

conversation.interviewer: Which events should trigger notifications, and who should receive them (user, coach, or both)—for example new in-app messages and upcoming/changed video-call appointments?
conversation.user: Notify both of us for new messages, and for upcoming sessions (like 24h and 1h before). If an appointment is created/changed/canceled, both user and coach should get notified right away.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the 24-hour and 1-hour reminders you mentioned, do you want users and coaches to be able to customize how many reminders they receive and at what lead times, or should those two fixed reminders be the only ones the system sends?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fully customizable reminders—keeping it simple with the fixed 24-hour and 1-hour reminders is fine. Maybe just an option to turn reminders off if someone wants.

conversation.interviewer: What should the booking lifecycle be for coaching sessions—can users instantly book any available slot, or should coaches review and approve each booking request before it’s confirmed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact approval flow—whatever’s simplest is fine. Instant booking of available slots works for me as long as both sides get notified and it’s easy to reschedule or cancel.

conversation.interviewer: After a user has booked a coaching session, what specific actions should they be able to perform on that booking directly in the app (for example, view details only, reschedule to another available slot, cancel, or request a refund)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about refunds in the app. The basics are enough: view the booking details, reschedule to another available slot, or cancel, with both sides getting notified.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific business rules you want around how users can book and cancel coaching sessions—such as minimum/maximum time before a session to book or cancel, limits on how many future sessions a user can have booked at once, or requirements like completing an intake questionnaire before booking?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict business rules here—keep it simple. Maybe just a reasonable cutoff like you can’t cancel within a few hours of the session, but otherwise I’m flexible.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to book coaching sessions directly in the app, and if so should booking be a direct “book this time slot” flow or a cart-style checkout flow?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a cart-style checkout—keeping it simple is best. Just a direct “book this time slot” flow is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One specific UI requirement: I’d like the app to use a beige background as the default theme so it feels calm and warm.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like authentication and roles to work in the app—for example, should users create an account with email/password or social login, and should there be distinct roles like “coach” and “coachee” with different permissions?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specifics of authentication—as long as it’s secure and easy. Having separate roles for coach vs coachee makes sense, but I’m not picky about how it’s implemented.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more interaction requirements beyond the beige default theme—no other specifics come to mind.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the app to model and store (for example: user profile, coach profile, coaching session booking, messages, goals, journal entries, assessments), and which of those are must-haves vs. optional?
conversation.user: Must-haves: user profile, coach profile, session bookings (with availability/calendar), and basic in-app messages. Also important for the “understand myself” part: assessments and a simple personal development plan (goals + reflections/journal entries). Optional: file attachments in messages, coach notes/private logs, and analytics/progress charts.

conversation.interviewer: For each must-have entity you listed (user profile, coach profile, session booking, message, assessment, personal goal, reflection/journal entry), what are the essential fields you want stored for each one (for example, what exactly should a “user profile” record contain)?
conversation.user:
Here’s what I think we need at a minimum:
- User profile: name, email/login, timezone, basic bio, coaching goals/interests, preferences (notifications on/off), and maybe a profile photo.
- Coach profile: name, bio, specialties/topics, certifications, languages, timezone, availability schedule, session price/length, and profile photo.
- Session booking: user ID, coach ID, start/end time, status (booked/canceled), video call link, notes/agenda, and timestamps.
- Message: sender, recipient, text content, optional attachment link later, sent time, and conversation/thread ID.
- Assessment: type/name, date taken, questions/answers, and a scored result/summary.
- Personal goal: title, description, target date, status, and linked coach (optional).
- Reflection/journal entry: date, text content, mood/tags (optional), and linked goal/session (optional).

conversation.interviewer: How should the key entities relate to each other—for example, should messages belong to a conversation thread between one user and one coach, can a user have multiple coaches and goals per coach, and can a booking have multiple linked journal entries/assessments or just one?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact relationship model as long as it supports the basics. A 1:1 conversation thread per user+coach pair is fine, users can have multiple coaches and goals, and it’s fine if bookings can link to multiple journal entries/assessments if that’s easier.

conversation.interviewer: What are the top-level sections you want in the app’s main navigation (e.g., Home/Dashboard, Find a Coach, Calendar/Sessions, Messages, Assessments, Goals & Journal, Profile/Settings)?
conversation.user: I’d like: Dashboard/Home, Find a Coach, Sessions/Calendar, Messages, Assessments, Goals & Journal, and Profile/Settings. That’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: For each entity (user profile, coach profile, session booking, message thread, assessment, goal, journal entry), which of the fields you listed should be shown on the detailed view page to the user (and which should be hidden/internal)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of detail right now—whatever’s standard is fine. Just don’t show anything sensitive like private coach notes or internal admin fields to the user.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to categorize and group their Goals & Journal entries—for example using tags (topics/moods), folders/collections, or no grouping at all?
conversation.user: Simple tags would be enough—like topics and mood tags—and maybe an option to filter by coach or by a specific goal. I don’t think I need folders/collections unless it’s really easy to add later.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the data users and coaches create inside this app, do you want the system to pull in or connect to any external data sources (for example, calendar systems, personality/assessment platforms, or note-taking tools), and if yes, which ones should be in scope?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about external integrations right now—let’s keep it standalone. If we ever add one later, calendar sync (Google Calendar/Apple Calendar) would be the only thing I’d maybe want.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a consistent set of required system fields and naming conventions across all tables (e.g., `id` as UUID, `created_at`/`updated_at` timestamps, `deleted_at` for soft deletes, snake_case column names), or is no strict schema standard needed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict naming conventions or schema standards. Just use whatever’s standard and maintainable for the stack you choose.

task_name: Coaching Match and Session Management System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me study with others by joining groups, sharing resources, and collaborating on learning activities.
user_stories: As a user, I want to create study groups, so that I can set up virtual spaces for focused study.
As a user, I want to join study groups, so that I can participate in existing study communities.
As a user, I want to share resources in study groups, so that other group members can access relevant study materials.
As a user, I want to collaborate on projects in study groups, so that we can work together on shared academic tasks.
As a user, I want to download shared resources, so that I can access study materials locally.
As a user, I want to participate in project discussions, so that I can communicate with others about our shared projects.
As a user, I want a personal center where I can view my personal information, so that I can see my account-related details.
As a user, I want all backgrounds on the website configured with alice blue, so that the visual background is consistently styled.
As a user, I want all components on the website configured with steel blue, so that the interface elements have a consistent appearance.

conversation.interviewer: What user-generated community features do you want—e.g., discussion posts/comments, direct messaging between members, and the ability to upload/share resources—and should any of this be moderated (who can post and who approves/removes content)?
conversation.user: I’d like discussion posts with comments in each study group, plus direct messaging between members. Members should be able to upload/share resources (files and links) inside the group. Moderation can be handled by group admins/owners—any member can post, but admins can remove content and approve new members if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What types of user-generated content should users be able to create or submit, and what information should each submission include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down all the exact fields right now. As long as people can post in discussions, comment, DM, and share files/links in a group, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What specific management actions should study group owners/admins be able to perform (e.g., rename/delete the group, change roles, remove members, control who can post or share resources)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about all the granular admin controls right now. The basics are enough: approve/remove members and delete inappropriate posts/resources; anything beyond that can be decided later.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific UI interaction details right now—just keep it simple and easy to navigate, and we can refine the feel later.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s content to be organized—specifically, what main sections or navigation items should exist (for example, “My Groups,” “Browse/Find Groups,” “Resources,” “Messages”), and how should a user move between them?

Dashboard can show my active groups and recent posts/resources; clicking a group takes you into its own space with tabs for Discussions and Resources, and Messages is global across the site.

conversation.interviewer: Within each main area you mentioned (Dashboard, My Groups, Browse Groups, Messages, Profile, and an individual group’s space), do you envision any additional sub-pages or nested sections (beyond the Discussions/Resources tabs in a group), or should each area remain as a single, flat page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more sub-pages right now. Keeping each area mostly flat is fine—maybe just a simple “Group Settings/Members” page for admins later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: For each area of the site (e.g., group discussions, shared resources, group membership lists, and user profiles), which parts should be publicly visible to anyone and which should be restricted to logged-in users or only to members of that specific group?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about public visibility details right now. If we need a default, I’d keep everything behind login, and only group members can see a group’s discussions/resources/members, with profiles limited to basic info unless someone’s in the same group.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One content thing I do want: resources people share (files) should be downloadable so members can save study materials locally. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Besides being downloadable, are there any specific rules or preferences for the files and media members can share in groups—such as allowed file types/formats, maximum file size, or any content types that should be blocked or discouraged?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting specific on file type rules or size limits right now. If you need a default, just allow common study formats (PDF, DOCX, PPTX, images) and set a reasonable size cap.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content thing: it’d be nice if groups could create a simple “project” or “study plan” post (like an assignment/task list) that everyone can comment on and update. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Within a study group, how would you like posts, shared resources, and study plans to be organized—should they be grouped or tagged by things like topic, course/class, resource type (notes, slides, practice problems), or another scheme you prefer?
