conversation.interviewer: What are the core entities you want the system to model (e.g., User, Study Group, Post, Comment, Message, Resource/File, Study Plan/Task), and are there any must-have fields for any one of them (for example, a Study Group should have name, subject/course, privacy, and owner)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about formally modeling all the entities and must-have fields right now. As long as it supports users, groups, discussions/comments, messages, shared resources (files/links), and a simple study plan/task list, we’re good.

conversation.interviewer: Is there any additional core entity or relationship—beyond users, groups, discussions/comments, messages, shared resources, and study plans/tasks—that you consider essential to model explicitly in the system’s data (for example, courses/classes, institutions, or group membership/roles as a separate entity)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more core entities right now. Users, groups, and membership/roles plus the posts/messages/resources/study plans are enough for a first version.

conversation.interviewer: For just one of your core entities (pick whichever feels most important—User, Study Group, Post, Message, Resource/File, or Study Plan/Task), which specific fields do you consider absolutely must-have to store for it (beyond a generic ID)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about locking down exact must-have fields right now. If you need a bare minimum, for a Study Group just store name, owner, and a short description/topic.

conversation.interviewer: How should content inside a study group be categorized—do you want optional tags/labels (and who can create/apply them), or a fixed set of predefined categories?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down a category system right now. If you need a default, make tags optional and let any group member add/apply them, with admins able to remove or rename tags if they get messy.

conversation.interviewer: Within a study group’s main page (for example, the Discussions tab or a single discussion post view), how would you like information to be laid out on the screen—for instance, what should appear at the top (title, key details, quick actions), what should follow (main content, comments, related resources), and in what general order?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact on-screen layout right now. As long as it’s straightforward—title and key actions up top, content in the middle, comments/resources below—I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: Should the site’s structure and pages change depending on who is viewing them (e.g., admins/owners vs regular group members vs non-members), or would you prefer mostly shared pages where only certain controls/options appear or disappear based on role?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having different page structures by role. I’d prefer mostly shared pages where the same views exist, and admin-only controls just show up (or are hidden) depending on permissions.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any built-in templates for creating group content (e.g., a “study plan/task list” template), and if so, what sections/fields should that template include by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about templates right now. If you want a default for the study plan, just keep it simple: title, short description, a checklist of tasks (with due date optional), and a comments section.

conversation.interviewer: When a user opens a detailed view of a study group, which specific pieces of information about that group do you want prominently displayed (for example, name, short description/topic, owner, member count, tags, upcoming study plans/tasks), and which of those are essential to show?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting specific on what’s “prominently displayed” right now. Just show the group name and short description/topic, plus an easy way to jump to Discussions, Resources, and the study plan/tasks.

conversation.interviewer: Will all content in the site be limited to user-created data inside the platform (groups, posts, messages, resources, study plans), or should the system also be able to access or integrate any external data sources (for example, imported course materials from Google Drive or a school LMS)—and if so, which ones?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about external integrations for the first version. Let’s keep everything user-created inside the platform, and we can revisit Google Drive/LMS imports later if it becomes necessary.

task_name: Adult Vocabulary Learning and Quiz System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me steadily learn and practice new vocabulary, stay motivated, and track my learning progress over time.
user_stories: As a user, I want to learn adult vocabulary through a website, so that I can improve my vocabulary skills.
As a user, I want the website to include a variety of quizzes and word games, so that my learning experience is engaging.
As a user, I want to play crossword puzzles on the website, so that I can practice vocabulary in a puzzle format.
As a user, I want to play unjumble-letters games on the website, so that I can practice forming correct words from scrambled letters.
As a user, I want to play games for finding synonyms on the website, so that I can learn words with similar meanings.
As a user, I want to play games for finding antonyms on the website, so that I can learn words with opposite meanings.
As a user, I want to use flashcards on the website, so that I can review and memorize vocabulary.
As a user, I want to do fill-in-the-blank activities on the website, so that I can practice using words in context.
As a user, I want a dashboard that displays a progress summary, so that I can see how I am progressing in my vocabulary learning.
As a user, I want the system to teach me a set of 10 new words every week, so that my vocabulary grows at a steady weekly pace.
As a user, I want to be able to choose an avatar, so that I can personalize my presence on the website.
As a user, I want to play a simple game while waiting in the waiting room, so that I am engaged during waiting periods.
As a user, I want the website to include a home page, so that I have a starting point for accessing the site’s features.
As a user, I want the website to include 5 activity pages, so that I can access different vocabulary activities separately.
As a user, I want the website to include a dashboard page, so that I can view my progress summary in a dedicated area.
As a user, I want the website to include blog pages, so that I can access additional content related to vocabulary learning.
As a user, I want the body backgrounds of the website to be light gray, so that the overall page background has the specified color.
As a user, I want the main components of the website to be dark red, so that the primary interface elements have the specified color.

conversation.interviewer: What core pages should the site have, and how would you like users to navigate between them (e.g., a top menu, bottom tabs, or a sidebar)?
conversation.user: I’d like a few core pages: Home, Practice/Activities, Progress Dashboard, and a Blog/Resources section. A simple top navigation bar is fine, with clear links and maybe a “Start Practice” button on Home to jump right in.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between major modules, workspaces, or data types (e.g. via tabs, sidebars, dropdowns, or dashboards)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having separate modules or workspaces. A straightforward top nav plus a clear dashboard/home hub is enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to browse and discover new vocabulary sets or practice activities—for example, through searchable lists, topic/categories, recommended feeds, or another structure?
conversation.user: I’d like a searchable list of vocab sets and activities with simple filters like topic, difficulty, and how long it takes. Also a “Recommended for you” section based on what I’ve been missing, plus a quick way to jump into quizzes/games/puzzles from each set.

conversation.interviewer: When a user applies the topic/difficulty/time filters in the searchable list, should those filters persist as they move between pages or start a practice session (e.g., remembered until cleared), or reset each time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If you pick one, I’d slightly prefer the filters stay remembered until I clear them.

conversation.interviewer: When a user clicks a vocabulary set or activity in the searchable list, should it open a dedicated detail page (with info like description and preview) or start the practice immediately?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much. If you need a default, I’d prefer it starts practice immediately, with an optional “details” link if someone wants to preview first.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific interaction details beyond it feeling snappy and not getting in the way.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main types of vocab-related data you want the system to explicitly track and model (for example, individual words, phrases, example sentences, user-created lists, tags/topics), and how should these be grouped or related to each other?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super detailed data model. As long as it tracks individual words (maybe phrases) tied to a set/topic, and my mastery over time (seen, correct/incorrect, streak), that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the vocabulary content to be organized in the hierarchy—should users primarily browse by topic/category first, by difficulty level first, or by vocabulary set first?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which comes first. If you need a default, browse by vocabulary set first, with topic and difficulty as filters.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else major on content. Just make sure each word has a definition and at least one example sentence, and let me add my own notes or a mnemonic if I want.

conversation.interviewer: What specific metrics and breakdowns would you like on the Progress Dashboard (e.g., accuracy over time, words mastered, streaks, performance by topic/difficulty, time spent), and at what time granularity (daily/weekly/monthly)?
conversation.user: I’d like to see accuracy over time, total words learned vs mastered, current/longest streak, and a breakdown by topic and difficulty (so I know what to focus on). Weekly and monthly views are most useful, with an optional daily view if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: What filters or segments should the Progress Dashboard let users apply when viewing metrics (e.g., by topic, difficulty, vocabulary set, or date range)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a ton of filtering there. Just basic date range plus topic/difficulty, and maybe vocab set if it’s easy to add.

conversation.interviewer: What visualization formats would you like the Progress Dashboard to use for those metrics (e.g., line charts, bar charts, tables, heatmaps)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific chart types. Simple line charts for accuracy over time and bar charts for topic/difficulty breakdowns are fine, plus a small table for totals.

conversation.interviewer: When a user clicks or hovers on a chart in the Progress Dashboard, what specific interactive behavior would you like most—for example, simple tooltips only, or the ability to click a bar/point to drill down into a more detailed view for that topic/difficulty or time period?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy chart interactions. Simple hover tooltips with the exact numbers are enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else on content comes to mind. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like for key UI elements (e.g., the “Start Practice” button and links)?
conversation.user: I’d like a dark red as the main accent/highlight color for key buttons and links. Everything else can stay pretty neutral so it stands out.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme—such as meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and buttons—so that everything remains clearly readable for all users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific accessibility standards. Just make sure the text and buttons are clearly readable and not too low-contrast.

conversation.interviewer: What color(s) would you like for the overall page background (e.g., white, light gray, off-white), applied globally across the site?
conversation.user: A light gray background across the whole site would be great—something subtle so the dark red accents stand out.

conversation.interviewer: What base/neutral color would you like for the backgrounds of key UI components like cards/panels and the top navigation bar (e.g., white, slightly darker gray than the page, or another neutral)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much—white or a slightly darker gray than the page background both work. Just keep it neutral so the dark red accents pop.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a specific color scheme for component states (like hover, active/pressed, disabled, success, and error), and if so, should these mostly be tints/shades of the existing dark red/neutral palette or use distinct colors (e.g., green for success, orange/red for errors)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed state color system. Just keep hover/active as subtle tints/shades, disabled clearly muted, and use standard green for success and red for errors so it’s obvious.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should strictly keep the same styling across the whole site (e.g., buttons, form inputs, cards, charts, navigation), versus allowing page-specific variations?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict global styling rules. If you need a default, keep buttons, form inputs, and the top nav consistent site-wide, and let cards/charts vary a bit per page as long as it still feels cohesive.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps children learn about recycling and waste sorting in a fun and engaging way.
user_stories: As a user, I want a children’s recycling game website to educate kids on proper waste recycling, so that they can learn how to recycle correctly.
As a user, I want the game to include competitive elements such as a leaderboard, so that kids stay engaged and motivated.
As a user, I want the game to use a cartoon-style visual design, so that it is visually appealing to children.
As a user, I want kids to receive feedback while playing the game, so that they understand their actions and learn from them.
As a user, I want kids to learn how to correctly sort waste into the corresponding containers, so that they understand proper waste sorting.
As a user, I want kids to receive rewards and recognition through the game, so that their achievements are acknowledged and reinforced.
As a user, I want seashell to be used for container backgrounds, so that the container visuals follow the specified style.
As a user, I want crimson to be used for component visuals, so that the visual components follow the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want kids to be able to play the game, so that they can interact with the recycling activities.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages should the site have, and how do you want children to move between them (e.g., a simple top menu, big icon tiles on the home page, or step-by-step “next” buttons)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation style as long as it’s super simple for kids. Main pages could be Home, Learn, Games/Quizzes, Sort-It Practice, Rewards/Badges, and a Parents/Teachers section.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like kids to find specific learning activities or games on each page—for example, by choosing from a few big categories (like “Plastic,” “Paper,” “Food Waste”), scrolling a simple list, or tapping picture-based tiles for each activity?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which method you pick, as long as it’s easy for kids. Picture-based tiles with a few big categories sounds fine.

conversation.interviewer: How should kids switch between the main sections (Home, Learn, Games/Quizzes, Sort-It Practice, Rewards/Badges, Parents/Teachers)—for example via a persistent top bar with big icons, a sidebar, or always returning to the Home tile dashboard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which navigation you use—as long as it’s super simple and kid-friendly. A home tile dashboard plus a small persistent bar with big icons would be fine.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want kids to be able to use the site without creating an account, or should they log in (e.g., with a parent/teacher-managed username) to save progress and earn badges?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If it’s easy, let kids play without an account, and optionally have a parent/teacher login to save progress and badges.

conversation.interviewer: When a child taps a learning topic or game tile, should it open a dedicated full-page detail view for that specific activity, or should the activity run inline on the same page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which approach you use. Just make it feel clear and focused for kids, with an easy way to get back to where they were.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: Will kids mainly access this through a regular web browser on tablets/computers, or do you also want a special mode (like a fullscreen/kiosk classroom version), and should navigation behave any differently in that special mode?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a special kiosk/fullscreen mode. Regular browser use on tablets and computers is fine, and navigation can stay the same.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One more: keep controls really big and forgiving—large tap targets and drag-and-drop that “snaps” into bins so kids don’t get frustrated if their aim isn’t perfect.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any way to organize content into sub-sections or “sub-pages” within a main section (for example, grouping multiple games under a “Sorting Games” area or multiple lessons under “Plastic,” “Paper,” etc.), or should each main page just show a flat list/grid of its items without deeper hierarchy?

conversation.interviewer: Will any children or classes share the same device so that you need a simple way to switch between different user profiles or groups (e.g., different students or classrooms) without fully logging out and back in each time?

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any settings or forms where a parent/teacher can enter or manage data (e.g., child name/age, classroom list, progress reset), and if so, what’s the single most important workflow it must support?

conversation.interviewer: Is there any configuration you want adults (parents/teachers) to control themselves—such as turning sounds/animations on or off, choosing difficulty levels, or enabling/disabling certain games—or would you rather everything be fixed and the same for all users?

conversation.interviewer: Should the site work fully offline after an initial load (caching lessons/games, images, and sounds), or is it okay if it requires an internet connection each time to load content?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want kids to be able to create or edit any media in the site (e.g., take/upload a photo of an item for sorting), and if yes, what editing tools should be available (none, simple crop/rotate, stickers/drawing)?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a search feature for kids to find lessons/games, and if so should it be a simple keyword search or a picture-based category filter that stays applied while they browse?

conversation.interviewer: For the parent/teacher “management” side of the site, do you want a dedicated, password-protected admin area with its own simple dashboard (e.g., to toggle sounds, reset progress, view basic stats), or should any such controls just appear as a small settings panel within the main site instead of a separate admin section?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to send any notifications via email (e.g., progress summaries or badge earned alerts to parents/teachers), and if so who should receive them and how often?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any community features where kids can share or communicate (e.g., posting their results/artwork or sending messages), or should the site have no sharing/messaging at all?

conversation.interviewer: Will your site need any kind of “ordering” or “booking” flow at all (for example, reserving classroom sessions, purchasing premium content, or scheduling school workshops), or should there be no orders/bookings and everything just be freely accessible without that kind of process?

task_name: DMV Practice Test and Exam Simulation System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me prepare for my driver’s license exam and understand how well I’m doing.
user_stories: As a user, I want a DMV practice test website to help me practice for my driver's license exam, so that I can prepare for the actual test.
As a user, I want to be able to select practice questions, so that I can choose which questions to practice.
As a user, I want to be able to take simulated exams, so that I can complete full practice tests and receive results.
As a user, I want to view error analysis, so that I can review my mistakes and improve my knowledge.
As a user, I want to view my exam scores, so that I can see how well I performed on the simulated exams.
As a user, I want the page background to be floral white, so that the website appearance matches the specified background color.
As a user, I want all components to be colored dark goldenrod, so that the interface uses the specified component color consistently.

conversation.interviewer: What core pages should the site have, and how would you like users to navigate between them (e.g., a top menu, sidebar, or dashboard-style home)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact page structure or navigation style as long as it’s simple. A basic home/dashboard, practice tests, review/incorrect answers, and progress page would be fine.

conversation.interviewer: How should user accounts and access work on the site—for example, do you want people to be able to practice anonymously, or should they register/login (email, Google, etc.) so their progress is saved, and are there any verification or role differences you need (like regular user vs. admin)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy account stuff. Let people practice anonymously, and optionally sign up with email or Google if they want progress saved—no special verification or roles needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—make the full-length simulated exam feel like the real thing: timed, one question at a time, no jumping around, and show the results only at the end.

conversation.interviewer: When users are setting up or taking practice tests, what specific options and workflows do you want them to be able to configure themselves (e.g., number of questions, topic selection, time limit), and how should that configuration process work on the screen?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a bunch of configurable options. Just let them start a quick practice set or a full simulated exam, maybe pick a topic or “all topics,” and keep the setup to one simple screen.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other interaction requirements beyond the simulated exam behaving like the real test. As long as the site is simple and easy to use, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: What progress analytics would you like on the progress page (e.g., overall score trend over time, topic-by-topic accuracy, time-per-question, and/or pass/fail readiness), and at what granularity (per test session vs. weekly/monthly summary)?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple overall score trend over time, topic-by-topic accuracy, and a clear “readiness” indicator (like pass probability based on recent simulated exams). Granularity-wise, show it per test session, with an optional weekly summary if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Which breakdown dimensions and controls are needed for analytics (e.g. filters, segments, comparison periods, and data granularity levels)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy filters or segmentation. Just let me see per test session, and maybe a simple weekly summary toggle—no need for comparisons or lots of controls.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main types of content and data you want the system to explicitly track as separate “things” (for example: question banks, topics/categories, individual practice sessions, full simulated exams, and user profiles), and how would you like those to be organized or grouped?
conversation.user: Track a question bank (each question with the correct answer, explanation, and topic tag), a list of topics/categories, and my attempts as separate sessions (quick practice) and full simulated exams. If I’m logged in, also track a simple user profile with progress history; if not, keep it just for the current device/session. Organize questions by topic and keep session/exam history grouped by date with scores and which questions I missed.

conversation.interviewer: Could you specify the key relationships between the core entities—for example, can a question belong to multiple topics or exactly one, and should each attempt record which question option was chosen (not just whether it was correct)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the data modeling details like multi-topic questions. But yes, please record which option the user chose so the review page can show what they picked vs. the correct answer.

conversation.interviewer: For each question in the question bank, what exact fields do you need stored (e.g., question text, answer choices, correct choice, explanation, topic tag, difficulty, source/region, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact list of fields as long as each question has the text, multiple-choice answers, the correct answer, an explanation, and a topic/category tag. Anything beyond that is optional.

conversation.interviewer: For organizing and browsing your content, do you want any additional grouping beyond a single topic/category per question—such as tags for difficulty level, question type (signs, rules, scenarios), or separate folders for quick practices vs. full simulated exams history?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra grouping like difficulty tags or folders. Just keep questions grouped by topic, and keep history split into quick practice vs. full simulated exams by date.

conversation.interviewer: For a completed test/exam entry in the history list and its detail view, which fields should be shown (e.g., date/time, score %, pass/fail, topics covered, time taken, number correct/incorrect, missed questions list)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about an exact set of fields. Just show the date, score %, pass/fail readiness, time taken, and a list of missed questions I can review.

conversation.interviewer: How long should the site retain a user’s practice/exam history and progress records (e.g., indefinitely, or auto-delete after a set period)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about retention rules. Keeping history indefinitely is fine, and if you need a cutoff for anonymous users, whatever’s simplest works.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content/reporting requirements—what we covered is enough. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color would you like for key interactive components such as buttons and progress indicators (for example, blue, green, or another specific color)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a dark goldenrod as the main accent color for buttons, links, and progress indicators, and keep it consistent across the site.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or readability requirements for the color scheme—such as meeting WCAG contrast ratios for text and buttons, or a preference for “high contrast mode” options for users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific WCAG targets or a high-contrast mode. Just make sure the text and buttons are easy to read and not low-contrast.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the overall page background be (e.g., white, light gray, off-white), applied consistently across all pages?
conversation.user: Let’s go with a floral white background across the site—clean and easy on the eyes.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the dark goldenrod accent, what base colors (for example, white, light gray, or another shade) should be used for the main UI components like cards/panels and the navigation bar backgrounds?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact base colors for cards/nav as long as it looks clean and readable. Something like white or a very light gray is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from the dark goldenrod accent or be separate fixed colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a strict state color system. Just keep it consistent and readable—deriving hover/active from the dark goldenrod is fine, and use standard clear colors for success/error (like green/red).

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual style rules you want enforced consistently across the whole site (for example, a single shared button style, card style, and heading style used on every page), or is “just make it look uniform” enough without defining exact standards?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific style rules or design system details. Just make it look uniform and consistent across pages.

task_name: Canadian Nutrition Facts and Packaging Design System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me understand food nutrition information and support compliant food product labeling in Canada.
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to display Canadian nutrition facts labels, so that I can understand food nutrition information.
As a user, I want a product search function where I can input food names or keywords (such as “apple”), so that I can search for related nutrition information.
As a user, I want a nutrition analysis function where I can input food ingredients (such as chicken, rice, broccoli) and serving sizes, so that I can calculate their nutritional value.
As a user, I want a packaging design function, so that I can design my own food packaging according to Canadian regulations.
As a user, I want the website’s background to be defined as linen, so that the appearance of the site follows the specified background style.
As a user, I want the website’s components to be defined with maroon, so that the appearance of the site follows the specified component color.

conversation.interviewer: What data-entry workflow do you want for creating a Canadian-compliant product label—e.g., a guided step-by-step form wizard or a single-page form?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which UI pattern you use—wizard or single-page is fine—as long as it’s quick and not confusing. I mostly want it to catch compliance issues and calculate things correctly.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the site and how should users move between them (e.g., Dashboard → Product list → Product detail/label editor → Compliance report)?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact page structure, as long as it’s easy to get from a product list into editing a label and then seeing a compliance report. A simple flow like Products → Label editor → Compliance checks/Export would be fine.

conversation.interviewer: How should the site handle exporting and downloading compliant label files (e.g., which file formats to support and whether downloads should be generated instantly or emailed as a link)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact export workflow or formats right now. As long as I can download something usable without hassle, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re editing a product label, what kind of live preview and editing controls do you want—for example, do you need to zoom, switch between front/back or bilingual layouts, and see an instant WYSIWYG preview as you change nutrition data and text?
conversation.user: I’d like an instant WYSIWYG preview that updates as I change nutrition values and text. Basic controls like zoom and switching between English/French (and front/back panels if applicable) would be really helpful, but it doesn’t need to be super fancy.

conversation.interviewer: Should the label preview update immediately with every change the user makes (real-time), or only after they click a specific “refresh/update preview” button?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either is fine. If it doesn’t slow things down, real-time is nice, but a simple update/refresh button is totally acceptable.

conversation.interviewer: Within the preview itself, what specific interactive controls do you want for adjusting the label’s appearance or layout (for example, toggling gridlines/margins, simulating different package sizes, or switching predefined layout templates)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fine-tuning layout controls like gridlines, margins, or package-size simulation. A couple of basic template options and maybe a simple safe-area/margin toggle is enough, as long as the output stays compliant.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—search should be fast and forgiving. I want to type a food name or keywords (including partial matches/misspellings) and get relevant nutrition info suggestions immediately, with filters like brand vs generic and serving size.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond speed and typo-tolerance, are there any specific advanced search or filtering capabilities you want—such as saving favorite searches, filtering by nutrient thresholds (e.g., low sodium, high fiber), or combining multiple filters in one query?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about advanced search features like saved searches or complex multi-filter queries right now. Basic filters (brand vs generic, serving size) and good suggestions are enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t have any other specific interaction requirements right now. As long as it stays fast and clear to use, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: What specific nutrition and labeling data elements do you want the system to store for each product (for example, ingredient list, full Nutrition Facts panel fields, allergen declarations, CFIA category, bilingual names), and are there any that are mandatory for you?
conversation.user: For each product, I want it to store the full Canadian Nutrition Facts table fields (serving size, calories, all required nutrients/units/%DV), plus ingredient list, allergens/“may contain,” and product name in English and French. Also store net quantity, company/contact line, and any required claims/warnings tied to the category. Mandatory for me: Nutrition Facts data, serving size, ingredients, allergens, and bilingual name—everything else can be optional.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the product-level fields you described, are there any additional attributes you want stored for related entities—such as per-ingredient details (e.g., supplier, country of origin, internal ID) or per-company details (e.g., CFIA license number, address lines)—that are important for your labeling workflow?
conversation.user: Yeah—per-ingredient I’d want at least an internal ID, supplier name, and a nutrition profile/source (so the system can calculate totals), plus optional country of origin and allergen flags. For company details, store the full mailing address and contact info; a CFIA license number would be nice but not mandatory.

conversation.interviewer: What core entities should the system model and how do they relate (e.g., Product ↔ Ingredients ↔ Nutrition data sources, Company/Brand ↔ Products, Label/Revision ↔ Compliance report ↔ Exports)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model or entity relationships, as long as it supports products with ingredients, nutrition sources/calculations, company/brand info, and generating a compliant label plus a compliance report/export reliably.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specialized, domain-specific parameters you want to store for products or ingredients beyond the basic fields you’ve listed—such as CFIA category codes, nutrient rounding rules/versions, algorithm or rule-set IDs for compliance calculations, or other configuration metadata that affects how labels are generated?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about storing those specialized parameters right now. As long as the system applies the correct Canadian rules automatically and stays up to date, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What color scheme would you like for the main interactive components (such as buttons, tabs, and links)—for example, a specific brand color, a light vs dark theme, or any contrast/accessibility requirements you want us to follow?
conversation.user: I’d prefer a maroon color scheme for the main UI elements like buttons, tabs, and links. A light theme is fine, but please make sure contrast meets accessibility standards.

conversation.interviewer: What accessibility contrast standard should we meet for the maroon UI components (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA with at least 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text/UI elements)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact standard details—just make sure it meets common accessibility expectations. If you need a target, WCAG 2.1 AA is totally fine.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color set for UI component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your maroon primary color or specified independently?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a defined state color set right now. Just pick sensible accessible hover/active/disabled/success/error colors—deriving them from the maroon is fine as long as contrast stays good.

conversation.interviewer: For accents and highlights on emphasized elements (like active states, badges, or focus outlines), do you want to keep using variations of the maroon theme, or would you prefer a distinct secondary accent color—and if so, which color?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either is fine. If you want to pick a secondary accent, a teal or navy would work, but keep it accessible and not too loud.

conversation.interviewer: What overall page and layout background color(s) do you prefer (e.g., white, light gray, very pale maroon), and should that background be applied site-wide or only to specific sections like sidebars or headers?
conversation.user: I’d like a linen-colored background overall—something warm and light. Apply it site-wide for the main pages, and you can still use white cards/sections where you need more contrast for forms and previews.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific visual aspects (for example, button style, link appearance, heading text style, or card/panel look) do you want us to standardize so they remain consistent across all pages and devices?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific visual standardization details. Just keep buttons/links/headers/cards consistent and readable across pages, and make sure the maroon + linen theme stays accessible.

task_name: Shipping Industry News and Company Portal
initial_requirements: I want a website that provides news and information about the shipping industry, where users can stay informed and the content can be managed in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to access a news blog website for the shipping industry, so that I can view news and company information related to the shipping sector.
As a user, I want to view a dedicated news section, so that I can browse shipping industry news.
As a user, I want to view a dedicated company profiles section, so that I can browse information about shipping companies.
As a user, I want to view a dedicated events section, so that I can browse shipping industry events.
As a user, I want to browse news items, so that I can stay informed about current developments in the shipping industry.
As a user, I want to browse company information, so that I can learn more about different companies in the shipping industry.
As a user, I want to browse events, so that I can find relevant shipping-related events.
As a user, I want to subscribe to newsletters, so that I can receive shipping industry updates by email or other subscribed channels.
As a user, I want the website background styled with old lace, so that the site has the specified visual appearance.
As a user, I want the website components styled with rosy brown, so that the site’s components have the specified visual appearance.

conversation.interviewer: Could you describe how you’d like users to move around the site—for example, what main menu items or core pages you want (e.g., Home, News, Market data, Company profiles, Reports), and how you’d like them to drill down from lists of articles or items to detailed views?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple top menu with Home, News, Company Profiles, Events, and maybe Insights/Reports plus Search. News should have category filters (e.g., tankers, containers, ports, regulations) and list pages that click through to full article pages. Company Profiles should be a directory you can filter/search, then drill into a company detail page with related news and events.

conversation.interviewer: Which main pages or sections should the product include for each user group (e.g. end users, admins, merchants), and how should users navigate between them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about splitting things by multiple user groups—this is mostly just public readers and an admin/editor side. For readers, the main sections are Home, News, Company Profiles, Events, Insights/Reports, and Search; for admins, a simple dashboard to create/edit articles, categories, events, and company profiles.

conversation.interviewer: How should the site search work—should it be a simple keyword search, or include advanced filters (e.g., by category, date range, company, event) with those filters persisting as users browse results?
conversation.user: I’m fine with a simple keyword search to start. If it’s easy, basic filters like category and date would be nice, but I don’t need anything super advanced or persistent right now.

conversation.interviewer: For the admin/editor side, could you describe the main actions and flows you want in the dashboard—for example, how an editor should create, edit, publish/unpublish, and organize articles, events, categories, and company profiles?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed admin workflows. As long as there’s a straightforward dashboard where an editor can add/edit articles, events, categories, and company profiles and publish/unpublish them, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific interaction details. Just keep it fast and responsive on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: Should the News landing page primarily be a chronological feed of latest articles, or should it default to a category-based view (showing category tiles/sections users pick from first)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either approach works for me. If you need a default, just show the latest articles chronologically with category filters at the top.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any specific interaction requirements beyond it feeling fast and working well on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the Insights/Reports section organized—by topic categories, by report type (e.g., weekly/monthly/special), or as a simple chronological list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact organization there. A simple chronological list is fine, maybe with a couple topic tags or report-type filters if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the system to model (e.g., Article, Category, Company, Event, Report), and what key fields should each entity have?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about modeling the data in detail. At a high level it’s just Articles, Categories, Companies, Events, and Reports with basics like title, slug, content/summary, publish date, tags, and status (draft/published).

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other big content requirements—just keep it focused on current shipping industry developments and make it easy to categorize/tag so readers can find what they need. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What types of media files should editors be able to upload and embed in content (e.g., images, PDFs, videos), and are there any size/format limits you want to enforce?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific media types or strict limits right now. Basic image uploads are enough to start, and if PDFs are easy to support for reports, that’s a nice-to-have.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No additional content requirements from me. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components like buttons, links, and highlights (for example, a particular shade of blue, green, or a color from an existing brand palette)?
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like the main accent color to be a rosy brown tone for buttons, links, and highlights.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors (including the rosy brown accent) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG 2.1 AA for normal text and UI controls?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about meeting a specific standard like WCAG 2.1 AA. Just make sure the text and buttons are readable and not too low-contrast.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the rosy brown accent for buttons and links, what base colors would you like for key UI components such as card backgrounds, content panels, and the top navigation bar (e.g., light grey, white, very dark navy)?
conversation.user: I’d like an Old Lace-style off‑white as the main page background. Cards/content panels can be white (or a slightly warmer off‑white) with subtle light grey borders, and the top nav can be a very dark navy/charcoal so the rosy brown accents pop.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your rosy-brown accent or specified separately?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a full state color system right now. Just do sensible defaults—hover/active can be subtle variations of the rosy brown, and use standard red/green for error/success.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual style rules you want applied consistently across the whole site (for example, a single button style, link style, and card style used everywhere), or should the designer just aim for general consistency without a strict design system?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a strict design system. Just keep things generally consistent—one primary button style, consistent links, and a simple card layout across the site.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No other style requirements from me—what we’ve covered is enough. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to access a website that provides news and information about the shipping industry so I can stay informed in one place.

Feature2: As a user, I want a simple top navigation menu with Home, News, Company Profiles, Events, Insights/Reports, and Search so I can easily move between main sections.

Feature3: As a user, I want the site to be fast and responsive on both mobile and desktop so I can comfortably browse on any device.

Feature4: As a user, I want the Home page to highlight key recent content (TBD) so I can quickly see what’s new when I arrive.

Feature5: As a user, I want the News landing page to show the latest articles in chronological order so I can see the most recent industry updates first.

Feature6: As a user, I want to filter News articles by category (e.g., tankers, containers, ports, regulations) so I can focus on the segments that matter to me.

Feature7: As a user, I want to click on a News item in a list to open a full article page so I can read the complete content.

Feature8: As a user, I want each article to include basic information like title, summary, full content, publish date, tags, and publication status so I can understand the context of what I’m reading.

Feature9: As a user, I want News content to be categorized and tagged clearly so I can quickly discover related topics and articles.

Feature10: As a user, I want a Company Profiles section that acts as a directory so I can browse shipping-related companies in one place.

Feature11: As a user, I want to filter and/or search the Company Profiles directory so I can find specific companies or types of companies.

Feature12: As a user, I want each company detail page to show key company information (TBD) so I can understand who they are and what they do.

Feature13: As a user, I want each company detail page to display related news so I can see recent coverage about that company.

Feature14: As a user, I want each company detail page to display related events so I can see conferences or activities involving that company.

Feature15: As a user, I want an Events section so I can view upcoming and past shipping-related events in one place.

Feature16: As a user, I want to open an individual event detail page so I can see information such as title, date, location, and description (TBD).

Feature17: As a user, I want an Insights/Reports section so I can access more in-depth analyses and reports about the shipping industry.

Feature18: As a user, I want the Insights/Reports section to be presented as a simple chronological list so I can quickly see the newest reports.

Feature19: As a user, I want basic filters or tags (e.g., topic or report type) on the Insights/Reports list if available so I can narrow down the reports I see.

Feature20: As a user, I want to open an individual report detail page so I can view its full content or download associated materials (TBD).

Feature21: As a user, I want a simple keyword search that works across key content types (e.g., articles, company profiles, events, reports) so I can find relevant information quickly.

Feature22: As a user, I want the search results to clearly indicate the type of each item (article, company, event, report) so I can understand what I’m clicking on.

Feature23: As a user, I want basic search filters like category and date when possible so I can narrow down my results.

Feature24: As a user, I want article and report pages to support images so I can see visual context like charts or photos.

Feature25: As a user, I want some reports to optionally include downloadable PDFs if available so I can save or print them.

Feature26: As a user, I want the site content to focus on current shipping industry developments so I can rely on it as a relevant industry source.

Feature27: As a user, I want the visual design to use an Old Lace-style off‑white page background so the site feels clean and readable.

Feature28: As a user, I want cards or content panels to be white or a slightly warmer off‑white with subtle light grey borders so content blocks are clearly separated but not harsh.

Feature29: As a user, I want the top navigation bar to use a very dark navy/charcoal background so the main menu is visually distinct and easy to see.

Feature30: As a user, I want the main accent color for buttons, links, and highlights to be a rosy brown tone so key interactive elements stand out.

Feature31: As a user, I want hover/active states on interactive elements to be subtle variations of the rosy brown so I get clear feedback when I interact with the interface.

Feature32: As a user, I want success and error feedback (e.g., form submissions) to use standard green and red colors so I can quickly understand what happened.

Feature33: As a user, I want a consistent primary button style used across the site so I can easily identify main actions.

Feature34: As a user, I want link styles to be consistent so I can recognize clickable text anywhere on the site.

Feature35: As a user, I want a simple, consistent card layout across the site for lists of articles, companies, events, and reports so I can quickly scan and compare items.

Feature36: As a user, I want text and buttons to be clearly readable with sufficient contrast so I don’t struggle to see content, even if no formal accessibility standard is enforced.

Feature37: As an editor/admin, I want a simple dashboard so I can manage all site content from one place.

Feature38: As an editor/admin, I want to create, edit, and delete articles so I can keep the news content up to date.

Feature39: As an editor/admin, I want to publish or unpublish articles so I can control what is visible to users.

Feature40: As an editor/admin, I want to create, edit, and delete events so I can keep the Events section current.

Feature41: As an editor/admin, I want to publish or unpublish events so I can control which events are visible.

Feature42: As an editor/admin, I want to create, edit, and delete company profiles so I can maintain an accurate directory.

Feature43: As an editor/admin, I want to publish or unpublish company profiles so I can manage which companies are publicly listed.

Feature44: As an editor/admin, I want to create, edit, and delete insights/reports so I can maintain the Insights/Reports section.

Feature45: As an editor/admin, I want to publish or unpublish insights/reports so I can control when reports are available to readers.

Feature46: As an editor/admin, I want to create, edit, and delete categories so I can organize articles, reports, and possibly other content types efficiently.

Feature47: As an editor/admin, I want to assign tags to content (e.g., articles, reports) so I can improve discoverability through filters and search.

Feature48: As an editor/admin, I want to upload images to embed in articles and reports so I can enhance content visually.

Feature49: As an editor/admin, I want to upload PDFs for reports when needed so users can download full documents.

Feature50: As an editor/admin, I want each content item (article, event, company profile, report) to have basic metadata such as title, slug, content/summary, publish date, tags, and status (draft/published) so I can manage and display content consistently.

task_name: Agricultural Information Management and News Portal
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me stay informed about agriculture, including news, products, and local weather conditions.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse agriculture-related news, so that I can stay informed about agricultural information.
As a user, I want to view different types of farm product information, so that I can understand details about available farm products.
As a user, I want to check local weather forecasts, so that I can see weather conditions relevant to agriculture.
As a user, I want to perform searches, so that I can quickly find specific agricultural information on the website.
As a user, I want to apply filters when browsing information, so that I can narrow down agricultural content based on my needs.
As a user, I want the website to use a light cyan background, so that the visual theme matches the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the website elements to use cadet blue, so that the interface styling is consistent with the specified theme.

conversation.interviewer: What search and filtering capabilities should the site provide (e.g., keyword search, filters like topic/location/date, and whether selected filters should persist when you navigate between pages)?
conversation.user: I’d like a keyword search across news and products, plus filters for topic/crop, location (my county/region), and date. Filters should persist as I browse and come back, and it’d be great to save a few favorite filter presets.

conversation.interviewer: When a user adjusts the filters (topic/crop, location, date), should those changes apply immediately as they are selected, or only after clicking an “Apply filters” button, and do you want users to be able to select multiple values per filter (e.g., several crops or locations) at the same time?
conversation.user: I’d prefer filters apply immediately as I change them, but with a clear “Reset” option. And yes, multi-select would be great for crops and topics; for location, maybe let me pick multiple nearby counties/regions too.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need keyword or text-based search on lists or records, and what basic fields should be searchable?
conversation.user: Yes—I'd like keyword search on both news and product listings. Search should cover titles/headlines, short descriptions/content, tags/topics/crops, product names/brands, and location mentions (county/region).

conversation.interviewer: How would you like search results to be displayed and organized—for example, as a list or grid, with sortable fields (like date or relevance), pagination or infinite scrolling, and any quick-preview details you’d want visible without opening each item?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact layout—list or grid is fine as long as it’s easy to scan. Sorting by date and relevance would be nice, and I’d want to see the headline/name, short snippet, date, and location at a glance.

conversation.interviewer: For search results, which sort options and default sort should you support (e.g., relevance, newest/oldest, and any others), and should users be able to switch between ascending/descending order?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a bunch of sort options. Relevance and newest-first are enough, and yes, letting me flip ascending/descending would be fine.

conversation.interviewer: Would you like users to be able to choose or limit what’s being searched—for example, search only news, only products, or both together—or should the search always run across all available content by default without any scope controls?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having scope controls. Searching across everything by default is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific interaction requirement beyond it feeling reasonably fast and not glitchy. Nothing else comes to mind.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the site to model and store (e.g., News article, Product listing, Weather report, Location/County, Crop/Topic), and what key fields should each entity include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data modeling details. As long as it can store news, products, and local weather tied to a county/region, with basic fields like title/name, date, location, tags/crops, and a short description, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s main navigation to be organized—what top-level sections should appear in the menu (e.g., News, Products, Weather, Saved Filters/Favorites), and should any of them have sub-sections?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact navigation as long as I can get to News, Products, and Weather quickly. A simple top menu with those plus something like Favorites/Saved Filters would be fine.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the top-level menu items (News, Products, Weather, Favorites/Saved Filters), how would you like the content within each of those sections to be structured—for example, should any of them have main overview pages with sub-sections like “Latest,” “By Crop,” or “By Region,” or do you prefer each to be a single, flat listing page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed structure there. An overview page with a simple “Latest” view and basic filters for crop/topic and region is plenty, but a flat listing is fine too.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like news and product items categorized for browsing—should each item be assigned to one or more crop/topic categories (and if so, what category list should we start with)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact category list as long as I can tag items with one or more crops/topics and filter by them. We can start with a basic set like corn, soybeans, wheat, hay/forage, cattle, dairy, pests/disease, equipment, and markets, and adjust later.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content requirements right now. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like for key UI elements (e.g., links, buttons, active filters, highlights)?
conversation.user: Cadet blue would be my preference for the accent/highlight color—use it for links, primary buttons, and active filter states so everything feels consistent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site’s colors (including the cadet blue accent) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG AA or AAA for text and UI elements?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG level. Just make sure text is easy to read and the contrast isn’t too low, especially for links and buttons.

conversation.interviewer: What base colors would you like for the main UI components—such as default button fills, card/panel backgrounds, and the top navigation bar—apart from the cadet blue accent?
conversation.user: I’d like a light cyan as the main page/background color. For cards/panels, use white or a very pale cyan, and for the top nav maybe a slightly darker cyan/teal so it stands out without fighting the cadet blue accents.

conversation.interviewer: Should the light cyan page background apply globally across the entire site (all sections/pages), or only on specific sections like News/Products/Weather?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—global is fine as long as it stays readable and doesn’t make the pages feel too busy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for UI states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your cadet blue accent/teal palette or be separate standard colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a full state color set. Just use sensible standard colors (like green for success, red for error) and keep hover/active states in the same cadet blue/teal family so it feels consistent.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond using cadet blue consistently for links, buttons, and active filters, are there any other specific visual elements (like card styles, navigation bar appearance, or heading text styles) that you want to look and behave the same across all pages and devices?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific visual style rules beyond keeping things clean and consistent. Just make the cards and headings look the same across pages, and keep the nav predictable on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional thematic/brand visual elements (for example subtle farm/agriculture patterns, icons, or imagery style) beyond the cyan/teal palette, or should the design stay purely minimal and color-based?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra branding elements. Keeping it clean and minimal is fine—maybe just a few simple agriculture icons if it helps navigation, but no heavy patterns.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: No, nothing else on style. Let’s move on.

initial_requirements: I want an application that helps me discover food options, including places to eat and recipes, and lets me learn from and share experiences with others.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse restaurants in the application, so that I can see available dining options.
As a user, I want to browse nearby restaurants, so that I can find dining options close to my current location.
As a user, I want to search for specific recipes, so that I can quickly find the dishes I am interested in.
As a user, I want to view other users’ reviews, so that I can understand their experiences with restaurants or recipes.
As a user, I want to view other users’ ratings, so that I can quickly gauge the quality of restaurants or recipes.
As a user, I want to add my own reviews, so that I can share my experiences with other users.
As a user, I want to add my own ratings, so that I can provide a score reflecting my opinion of restaurants or recipes.
As a user, I want the application to display restaurant information, so that I can learn more about each restaurant.
As a user, I want the application to display recipe information, so that I can learn how to prepare specific dishes.
As a user, I want the application’s background colored in lemon chiffon, so that the interface has that specific background appearance.
As a user, I want the application’s component styles set to chocolate, so that the interface elements have that specific visual style.

conversation.interviewer: What search and filtering capabilities should the app provide (e.g., filters like cuisine, dietary restrictions, location radius, price, and whether selected filters should persist across searches)?
conversation.user: I’d like filters for cuisine, dietary needs/allergens, price range, distance from my current location (with a radius slider), and rating. It should also let me sort by distance, popularity, or “open now.” Filters should persist until I clear them, but I want a quick reset button.

conversation.interviewer: Which filtering options and conditions should be available for narrowing lists or data sets (e.g. attributes, ranges, statuses)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra filtering options beyond what I already mentioned—cuisine, dietary/allergens, price, distance, rating, and “open now.”

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a keyword/text search, and which fields should it search (e.g., restaurant/recipe name, ingredients, cuisine tags, location/neighborhood, user reviews)?
conversation.user: Yes, I want a keyword search. It should search restaurant/recipe names and cuisine tags, and for recipes it should also search ingredients (including allergens). Searching within user reviews is optional—not a must for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the search results to be laid out and organized—such as card/list style, key details shown for each item (e.g., name, rating, distance, price), and whether you want options like sorting controls or “quick view” previews directly in the results list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact layout as long as it’s easy to scan. A simple list or cards are both fine, just show the basics like name, rating, distance, price, and whether it’s open, with sorting controls available.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of community features do you want in the app—for example, posting reviews/photos, saving and sharing lists, commenting/liking, following users, or direct messaging?
conversation.user: I’d like to be able to post reviews and photos for places/recipes, and save collections (like “date night” or “quick lunches”) that I can share. Basic likes and comments are enough, plus optional following—no need for direct messaging.

conversation.interviewer: When a user posts a review for a place or recipe, what fields should the submission include (e.g., star rating, written text, photos, tags, date visited/made, and optional pros/cons)?
conversation.user: For places: star rating, short written review, a few photos, and the date visited; optional tags like “great service” or “spicy.” For recipes: rating, notes on how it turned out, photos, and the date made, plus optional tags like difficulty or “kid-friendly.” Pros/cons can be optional but not required.

conversation.interviewer: How should the follow/unfollow feature work in detail—for example, what happens in the feed or notifications when you follow someone, and do you want any prompts or suggestions related to following other users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the follow/unfollow details that much. Just let me follow/unfollow easily, and maybe show new posts from people I follow in my feed—notifications and suggestions are optional.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like community content to be organized—should reviews, photos, and comments mainly live in per-place/per-recipe threads, or would you also want broader topic areas or tags (like “vegan in NYC” or “budget eats”) that group posts across many places/recipes?
conversation.user: I’d like reviews/photos/comments to live primarily on each place/recipe page so it’s easy to judge that specific option. But having optional tags/topics like “vegan in NYC” or “budget eats” to browse across multiple places/recipes would be great too.

conversation.interviewer: What specific moderation and history controls do you want for user-generated content (e.g., the ability to report posts/reviews, hide or block other users, edit or delete your own content, or see your own activity history)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about moderation/history controls in detail. At minimum, I’d want to be able to edit/delete my own posts and report obvious spam or abuse; blocking users would be nice but not essential.

conversation.interviewer: Since you mentioned direct messaging isn’t needed, would you still like any lightweight, non-chat way to contact other users or the app team (for example, a Q&A board or “ask the owner/creator” form), or should all communication stay within reviews, comments, and likes only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra contact features. Keeping communication to reviews/comments/likes is fine, and maybe a simple “contact support” form for app issues.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—one thing: I’d like the app to use a lemon chiffon background throughout the main UI (screens, lists, and detail pages) so it has a consistent look.

conversation.interviewer: For shared collections or topic tags, what ownership and management abilities should the creator have—for example, can they add/remove co-owners, approve/remove contributors, and control who can view or edit the collection?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed ownership/management controls. Just let me keep a collection private or share it via a link, and only I can edit it unless I explicitly invite someone to collaborate.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding any more interaction requirements beyond what we already covered.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main types of things you want the app’s data to be organized around (for example, “places,” “recipes,” “users,” “collections/tags”), and are there any specific categories or groupings (like meal type, occasion, or region) that you definitely want modeled explicitly?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the data model details. As long as it supports places, recipes, users, reviews/photos, and my shareable collections/tags, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main sections of the app to be organized and accessed—for example, what primary tabs or menu items (such as “Discover,” “Nearby,” “Recipes,” “Collections,” “Community”) should appear on the home-level navigation, and how should related content be grouped under them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact tab/menu structure. As long as I can easily get to Discover/search, nearby places, recipes, my saved collections, and a community/feed area, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Let’s move on. The only other content thing I want is solid place details on each restaurant page—address/map, hours, phone/website, menu link if available, photos, and a quick summary of cuisine/price/rating.

conversation.interviewer: What file/media formats should users be able to upload with their reviews (e.g., photos only, or also short videos), and do you want any limits like maximum file size or duration?
conversation.user: Photos are the main thing—JPEG/PNG (and HEIC is fine if it auto-converts). Short videos are optional; if you support them, cap them at ~15–30 seconds and maybe 20–50MB per upload so it stays fast.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific quality or technical requirements for uploaded photos and (if allowed) short videos—such as target resolution, aspect ratio (e.g., square vs. 4:3/16:9), or preferred compression/quality level to balance clarity and fast loading?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific resolution/aspect ratio/compression settings. Just make uploads look decent and load fast, and auto-handle cropping/compression in the background.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like photos (and any optional short videos) to appear on place/recipe pages and in reviews—e.g., a swipeable gallery, a grid of thumbnails, or inline images with tap-to-zoom?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact photo/video layout. A simple swipeable gallery or a thumbnail grid is fine as long as I can tap to zoom and it loads quickly.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
