conversation.user: One more content requirement: recipe pages should have detailed info—clear step-by-step instructions, prep/cook time, servings, ingredient list with amounts, and basic nutrition/allergen notes if available. Otherwise we can move on.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps families publish and manage memorial information, share memories, and interact with others around important family events.
user_stories: As a user, I want to publish funeral arrangements on the website, so that information about services is available.
As a user, I want the website to support multimedia memories, so that I can include photos, videos, or other media with obituaries.
As a user, I want access to a mortuary list, so that I can view information related to mortuaries.
As a user, I want functionality for condolences, so that messages of sympathy can be shared.
As a user, I want to publish my own obituaries, so that I can create memorials for my loved ones.
As a user, I want to manage my own obituaries, so that I can edit or update them as needed.
As a user, I want to publish my own funeral arrangements, so that I can share service details for my loved ones.
As a user, I want to manage my own funeral arrangements, so that I can edit or update service information as needed.
As a user, I want to view others’ obituaries, so that I can read about and remember other individuals.
As a user, I want to leave messages on others’ obituaries, so that I can express condolences or share memories.
As a user, I want the outer layout of the website to use cornsilk, so that the overall page background follows the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the UI blocks of the website to use peru, so that the interface elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What types of user interaction do you want enabled on memorial pages (e.g., comments, photo/video uploads, reactions, guestbook entries, private messaging), and should these be public or limited to invited family members?
conversation.user: I mainly want a guestbook-style space where people can leave condolence messages and share short memories. Photo uploads would be nice too, but I’d like interactions limited to invited family/friends by default, with an option to make it public if the family chooses.

conversation.interviewer: For each condolence message or short memory that someone submits, what specific information do you want them to provide (e.g., name, relationship to the deceased, date, optional email), and should photo uploads be attached directly to these messages or submitted separately?
conversation.user: For messages, I’d want name (or display name), relationship to the deceased (optional), the message itself, and the date auto-added; email should be optional and private (mainly for invite/notifications). Photos can be attached directly to a message, but also allow separate photo uploads to a memorial gallery.

conversation.interviewer: What controls do you want families and site admins to have over guestbook messages and photos—for example, should they be able to approve before publishing, hide or delete posts, see edit/delete history, or allow users to report or block abusive content—and who should have each of these powers?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed moderation tooling like edit/delete history. Basic controls are enough: families should be able to approve posts before they show up (or switch to auto-approve), and hide/delete messages or photos; site admins should be able to remove abusive content if reported.

conversation.interviewer: For each memorial page or family group, who should be considered the “owner” and what specific management powers should they have over the space (e.g., renaming the memorial, assigning/removing co-admins, controlling who can post or invite others, or deleting the memorial entirely)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact “owner” model as long as a family can manage invites and basic settings. Maybe just let the person who creates the memorial be the owner by default and allow them to add a couple co-admins.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like guestbook messages and photo posts to be organized on a memorial page—just a single chronological feed, or grouped into categories/tags/topics (and should each post support threaded replies)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about categories or threaded replies. A simple chronological feed is fine, maybe with basic filtering between “messages” and “photos.”

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific button behaviors or anything like that. Just make it feel simple and not slow on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any engagement actions on guestbook messages/photos (e.g., likes/reactions, sharing, saving), or should interaction be limited to posting and moderation only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about likes/reactions or saving. I’d keep it simple—just posting messages/photos and basic moderation, maybe optional sharing if it’s a public memorial.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding any extra interaction requirements beyond keeping it simple and not slow on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core entities you want the system to model and manage (e.g., Memorial, Person/Deceased profile, Family group, Invitation, Guestbook entry, Photo, Event), and are there any others you need?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super formal with the data model. As long as it covers memorial pages, the deceased profile info, invited family/friends, guestbook messages, photos, and maybe an event/reminder section, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level sections should each memorial page have, and in what order should they appear in the main navigation?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact order. As long as there are tabs for Overview/About, Guestbook, Photos/Gallery, and maybe Events, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: For each main section of a memorial (Overview/About, Guestbook, Photos/Gallery, Events), which parts—if any—should always be public, which should be visible only to invited family/friends, and should you have per-section controls to switch between public and restricted visibility?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fine-grained per-section privacy controls. Default everything to invited family/friends, and just give a simple toggle to make the whole memorial public if the family wants.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the memorial pages themselves, do you imagine any higher-level site structure (like a home/landing page, a list of all memorials, and possibly a separate “My Family Spaces” area), and how should these main pages be arranged in the overall navigation hierarchy?
conversation.user: Yeah, I’d want a simple landing page, plus a way to browse/search public memorials. And when I’m logged in, a “My Memorials” or “My Family Spaces” area where I can see the ones I manage or I’ve been invited to.

conversation.interviewer: What types and formats of files and media do you want the site to support (e.g., photos only, or also videos, PDFs, audio), and should any of these be restricted or avoided for this memorial platform?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting lots of file types. Photos are the main thing, and maybe short videos later, but I’d avoid PDFs/audio for now to keep it simple.

conversation.interviewer: For the photos (and possibly short videos later), do you have any preferences or limits for technical quality—such as maximum file size per upload, target resolution or aspect ratio, and whether the system should automatically compress/resize large files for faster loading on mobile?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific file size or resolution rules. Just have sensible defaults and automatically resize/compress big uploads so pages load fast on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: On each memorial page, how would you like photos to be presented and browsed—primarily as a thumbnail grid/gallery (with tap-to-zoom and swipe), inline alongside messages in the chronological feed, or a combination of both, and which should be the main view?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much as long as it’s simple. A thumbnail grid as the main Photos view is fine, and if a photo is attached to a guestbook message it can show inline there too.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content thing: I’d like the memorial to have a place for a formal obituary and basic funeral/service details (date/time, location, maybe a map link). Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: On the memorial’s Overview/About page, what order should the main blocks appear in (e.g., deceased name/photo, short summary, obituary text, service details/map link, and any key family notes)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact order. As long as the deceased name/photo is prominent near the top and the obituary and service details are easy to find, I’m fine.

conversation.interviewer: Should invited family/friends and the general public see different versions of a memorial page layout/navigation (role-based views), or should everyone see the same structure with only content visibility changing when a memorial is public vs private?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having different layouts for different roles. I’d prefer everyone see the same structure, with access just controlled by whether the memorial is private or made public.

conversation.interviewer: For each photo (and later short video), what information do you want the system to store and potentially show—such as uploader name, upload date, optional caption, tags, or location—or is a simple caption plus upload date enough?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about lots of photo metadata. A caption (optional) and upload date is enough, and maybe show the uploader name if it’s a private memorial.

conversation.interviewer: Which memorial assets should users be able to download or export (e.g., individual photos, the full photo gallery as a ZIP, a CSV export of guestbook messages, an obituary/service-details PDF), and should this be available only to invited members or also when a memorial is public?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about exports/CSVs/PDFs right now. Let people download individual photos if they have access, and keep anything else for a later phase.

task_name: Environmental Weather and Air Quality Monitoring System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me understand and follow changes in weather and environmental conditions.
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to display real-time weather data, so that I can see current environmental conditions.
As a user, I want the website to have a real-time update function, so that the displayed weather and air quality information is always current.
As a user, I want to view the air quality index (AQI) for the past two weeks, so that I can review recent air quality history.
As a user, I want to compare pollution and air quality changes over time, so that I can understand how conditions have varied.
As a user, I want to browse current weather and air quality data including temperature, so that I can know the current temperature conditions.
As a user, I want to browse current weather and air quality data including humidity, so that I can know the current humidity conditions.
As a user, I want to browse current weather and air quality data including gas sensor data, so that I can know the current gas pollution levels.
As a user, I want the website’s primary background to be azure mist, so that the visual appearance matches the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the website’s elements to be dark slate blue, so that the interface styling matches the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main pages you want in the site, and how should users navigate between them (e.g., a top menu, a sidebar, or dashboard tiles)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact page structure or navigation style—whatever’s simplest and easiest to use is fine.

conversation.interviewer: How should users search for weather/environment data—do you want a simple keyword/location search only, or also filters (e.g., date range, parameter like temperature/air quality) that stay applied as they browse?
conversation.user: I definitely want filters, especially a date range, so I can compare conditions across different time periods. Filters like location and parameters (temperature, precipitation, air quality, etc.) should stay applied as I browse and switch views.

conversation.interviewer: When users adjust filters like date range, location, or parameters, should the results update automatically as they change each filter, or only after they click an “Apply” button, and should those exact filter settings persist if they leave the results page and return later in the same session?
conversation.user: I’d prefer the results update automatically as I change filters—no extra Apply button. And yes, the filter settings should persist if I navigate away and come back in the same session.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the filtered results presented—an interactive map, a time-series chart/dashboard, or a table (with sortable columns and pagination)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which format you use—map, charts, or a table are all fine. Just pick whatever’s simplest and makes it easy to compare across dates and parameters.

conversation.interviewer: Besides filters like date and location, do you want a keyword/text search box (for example, to type a city name, station ID, or region name), and if so, what kinds of fields should users be able to search by text?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about keyword/text search—if you include it, just a simple city/region name box is enough. The filters are the main thing for me.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details—just make it feel fast and responsive, especially when filters change.

conversation.interviewer: For lists of results (like stations, days, or readings), should users be able to sort them, and if so, which fields (e.g., date, temperature, precipitation, air quality index) and sort directions (ascending/descending) matter most to you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sorting details. If you include it, sorting by date and by the selected parameter value (e.g., temperature or AQI), both ascending and descending, would be plenty.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more interaction requirements beyond it feeling fast and responsive when filters change.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of analysis or visual comparisons do you want the site to support—for example, comparing two date ranges side by side, seeing daily vs. hourly breakdowns, highlighting extremes (like hottest/coldest or worst air quality), or tracking trends for a specific parameter over time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific analysis features. The main thing is being able to compare different date ranges for the same location/parameter, and a simple trend over time is enough.

conversation.interviewer: What specific types of weather and environmental data do you want the site to store and treat as “first-class” items (for example: locations/stations, daily summaries, hourly readings, long-term climate averages, alerts, or air-quality episodes), and how would you like these to be grouped or related to each other?
conversation.user: I mainly care about air quality index (AQI) data, especially historical readings for at least the past two weeks. Treat locations (city/region or station) as first-class, with AQI readings tied to a location and timestamp, and then roll those up into simple daily summaries so it’s easy to compare date ranges.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want to include any additional core entities beyond Location and AQI Reading (e.g., sensors/stations as separate from a location, daily summaries as separate records, or alerts), and if so how should they relate (one-to-many, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more core entities beyond location and AQI readings. If you need daily summaries as separate records for performance, that’s fine, but I don’t need stations/sensors or alerts modeled separately.

conversation.interviewer: For each Location and each AQI Reading, what specific fields do you want to store (for example, for Location: name, type, coordinates; for AQI Reading: timestamp, AQI value, pollutant type, data source)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact fields as long as the basics are there. For locations, just a name (city/region) and maybe coordinates; for readings, timestamp and AQI value is enough.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content requirements beyond the location basics and AQI readings with timestamps/values. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components like buttons, sliders, and active filter chips (for example, a particular color family or an existing brand color), or should I just choose a simple, high-contrast accent that fits a neutral theme?
conversation.user: Yeah—let’s use a dark slate blue as the main accent color for buttons, sliders, and active filter chips. Just make sure it’s high-contrast and readable against a neutral background.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility standards or targets for color contrast and readability (for example, meeting WCAG AA or AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements), or should I just ensure contrast is generally high and accessible without following a formal standard?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a formal standard like WCAG AA/AAA—just make sure the contrast is clearly readable and feels accessible in practice, especially with that dark slate blue accent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color set for component states (hover, pressed/active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your dark slate blue accent or use separate distinct colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a defined state color set. If you need one, just derive hover/active/disabled from the dark slate blue and use simple standard colors for success/error that still read well.

conversation.interviewer: What overall page and layout background colors would you prefer (e.g., pure white, light gray, very light blue), and should that same background be used across all sections or should some areas (like side panels or headers) use a slightly different background shade?
conversation.user: I’d like an azure mist background overall—something very light and calm. Use that as the main background everywhere, and it’s fine if headers/side panels are just a slightly different shade of it for separation.

conversation.interviewer: For components that sit on top of the azure mist page background—like cards, panels, and the navigation bar—do you want them mostly white/light-neutral with the dark slate blue reserved for accents, or should some of those components (for example, the nav bar) use dark slate blue as their primary fill color?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—whatever keeps things clean and readable is fine. If you need a default, go with light-neutral cards/panels and use the dark slate blue just for accents.

conversation.interviewer: Across all pages and views (desktop and mobile), which specific visual aspects do you most want to keep strictly consistent—such as the exact accent color usage, typography (font and sizes), or spacing around components?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about being strict on typography or spacing. Just keep the dark slate blue accent usage consistent and make sure everything stays clean and readable on desktop and mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional colors or subtle decorative elements (like gradients, background patterns, or icon styles) to reinforce a specific theme or “feel” for the site beyond the azure mist background and dark slate blue accents, or should the design stay very minimal and functional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra colors or decorative elements. I’d rather keep it minimal and functional—no gradients or patterns, just simple, clean icons if needed.

initial_requirements: I want a website where I can read and share health-related content, and interact with others around health topics.
user_stories: As a user, I want to publish health-related articles, so that I can share information about healthy lifestyles.
As a user, I want to post comments on articles, so that I can engage in discussion and share my thoughts.
As a user, I want to search for articles, so that I can quickly find health content relevant to my interests.
As a user, I want articles to be categorized, so that I can browse content by category.
As a user, I want to browse articles, so that I can explore different health-related topics.
As a user, I want to follow specific topics, so that I can keep up to date with new articles related to those topics.
As a user, I want the website to use misty rose as the global background color, so that the overall background appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want all components on the website to use firebrick as their color, so that the components’ appearance matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of user-to-user interactions do you want to support on the site—for example, posting articles, commenting, liking, following people, private messaging, or creating/joining groups—and are there any moderation controls you definitely want or want to avoid?

conversation.interviewer: When a comment is reported or removed, should the original comment remain visible somewhere (e.g., marked “removed” with an audit trail for moderators) or be permanently deleted with no history?

conversation.interviewer: Besides article comments and replies, do you want users to be able to submit their own standalone content (e.g., full articles, personal health stories, questions), and if so, what fields or information should each submission include (such as title, body text, tags, images, or links)?

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: Besides commenting and replies, are there any other interaction options you definitely want available on articles—such as likes/upvotes, saving/bookmarking, or sharing—or would you prefer to keep it strictly to comments only for now?

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s content to be organized and navigated—for example, what main sections or categories should appear in the navigation (e.g., by health topic, article type, or audience), and how deep or simple should the hierarchy be?

conversation.interviewer: Which specific top-level pages (hubs) should the site have, and for each one what immediate child sections should it contain?

conversation.interviewer: On an individual article page, what should the order/layout be for the main elements (e.g., title, author/date, tags, article body, related articles, and the comments section)?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a clearly defined set of state colors for components (like hover, active/pressed, disabled, success, and error states), and if so, should those be just lighter/darker variations of your muted rose/berry palette or introduce distinct colors (e.g., green for success, red for errors)?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Style (e.g. colors, layout, theme). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual rules you want enforced consistently across the whole site (for example, one standard button style, one link style, one heading style, and uniform spacing), or is it enough just to keep using the same firebrick/rose color palette everywhere without strict component/typography guidelines?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the health theme/brand to feel more clinical and trustworthy or more warm and supportive, and should we add any decorative motifs (e.g., subtle health icons/illustrations) to reinforce that theme beyond the firebrick/rose palette?

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to read health-related articles organized by topic so I can easily find information on areas like nutrition, fitness, mental health, and chronic conditions.

Feature2: As a user, I want a flat navigation with top-level health topics, an “All Articles” view, and a simple “Trending/New” area so I can browse content without a deep hierarchy.

Feature3: As a user, I want to add comments directly on articles so I can share my thoughts and experiences about the content.

Feature4: As a user, I want to reply to other users’ comments so I can have discussions and conversations around health topics.

Feature5: As a user, I want removed or moderated comments to be hidden from regular users while still reviewable by moderators so that the public comment space stays clean without losing moderation history.

Feature6: As a user, I want basic moderation tools in place (e.g., reporting comments, deleting spam, blocking users, filters for misinformation) so that discussions stay safe and trustworthy.

Feature7: As a user, I want likes/upvotes on comments to be considered a nice-to-have only, so the core experience stays focused on comments and replies.

Feature8: As a user, I want a prominent search bar that returns results quickly so I can efficiently find articles on specific health topics.

Feature9: As a user, I want to filter search results by topic/tag so I can narrow down articles to the most relevant categories.

Feature10: As a user, I want to sort search results by newest or most relevant so I can choose between timely content and the best-matching content.

Feature11: As a user, I want individual article pages to be easy to read and not cluttered so I can focus on the article content itself.

Feature12: As a user, I want the comments section on an article page to be clearly visible and easy to jump to so I can quickly participate in the discussion.

Feature13: As a user, I want the site’s global background to use a misty rose color so the overall experience feels soft and consistent with my preferred palette.

Feature14: As a user, I want buttons, links, and key components to use a slightly darker muted rose/berry color so interactive elements stand out while still feeling subtle.

Feature15: As a user, I want all website components to use firebrick as the primary color so the interface has a clear, consistent primary accent.

Feature16: As a user, I want hover, active, and disabled component states to be subtle lighter/darker variations of the rose/berry palette so interactions feel coherent and predictable.

Feature17: As a user, I want success and error states to use clearly readable colors with strong contrast so I can easily understand feedback from the system.

Feature18: As a user, I want links and highlights to use the muted rose/berry color with clearly visible focus outlines so I can identify interactive elements and navigate with good accessibility.

Feature19: As a user, I want the site to prioritize good contrast (around WCAG AA) for text and links so content remains readable for different levels of vision.

Feature20: As a user, I want the overall design to be clean, readable, and not cluttered so I can comfortably read and engage with health content.

Feature21: As a user, I want the visual use of firebrick/rose colors to be consistent across the site so the interface feels cohesive even without a strict design system.

Feature22: As a user, I want future user-submitted standalone content (if added later) to be simple, with only a title, body text, a couple of tags, and optional link/image fields (TBD) so contributions remain straightforward.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of interaction and community features do you want around the poems (for example: commenting, likes, sharing, following authors, private messaging, or group discussions), and are there any you specifically do or do not want?
conversation.user: I definitely want commenting on poems, with threaded replies, since that’s my main way of interacting. Likes and following authors would be nice too, and easy sharing links. I don’t really need private messaging or group chats to start.

conversation.interviewer: What types of content should users be able to submit on the site (e.g., new poems, edits, responses/annotations), and what fields should each submission require (such as title, poem text, tags, author name/pen name)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact submission fields right now. As long as people can post poems with a title and the poem text, and maybe optional tags and a pen name, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What tools and controls do you want for moderating poems and comments—for example, should users be able to report content and block others, and should you (as admin) be able to hide, edit, or permanently delete posts and comment history?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the moderation tools details right now. Basic reporting and the ability for an admin to remove spam or abusive comments is enough for me to start.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like a simple search bar that lets me quickly find poems by title, tags, or author/pen name, with results showing instantly as I type or at least very fast.

conversation.interviewer: Could you describe exactly how the follow/unfollow feature should work between users—for example, what happens when you follow a poet, what you see from them afterward, and whether following should be one-way only (no approvals) or require acceptance like a friend request?

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like poems to be clearly categorized by type (like haiku, sonnet, free verse, spoken word), so I can browse by category and filter search results using those categories.

conversation.interviewer: When you use the search bar to find poems by title, tags, author/pen name, and type (haiku, sonnet, etc.), do you want any extra search or filter options—such as filtering by date, popularity/likes, length, or only from poets you follow—or should it stay limited to those basic fields only?

conversation.interviewer: What are the main pages you want in the site’s primary navigation (e.g., Home/feed, Browse by type, Search, Submit a poem, Profile), and how should users move from a list of poems to a poem’s detail page?

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the comment threads on individual poems, do you want any broader structure for organizing discussions—such as separate topic areas (e.g., “writing feedback,” “general discussion,” “haiku enthusiasts”) or tag-based discussion spaces—or should all community conversation stay attached directly to specific poems only?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to support any direct user-to-user communication (like private messages), or should all interaction stay public through poem comments only?

conversation.interviewer: For the admin side of the site, do you want a dedicated admin area/dashboard, and if so, what is the minimum set of things you’d like to manage there (for example, viewing/removing reported content, managing user accounts, or changing basic site settings like categories and tags)?

conversation.interviewer: For the admin dashboard, when you’re managing users and reported poems/comments, which specific actions do you want to be able to perform on those items (for example, just delete/remove, or also temporarily deactivate/suspend, edit, or restore/undo removals)?

conversation.interviewer: When someone is writing or editing a poem, what kind of editing and preview experience do you want—for instance, should they see a live preview that preserves exact line breaks and spacing, be able to format basic text (bold/italic/line breaks only), or just type into a simple plain-text box with a separate “Preview poem” view before publishing?

conversation.interviewer: Which areas and entities should the admin interface include for you to manage (e.g., users, poems, comments, reports/categories)?

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want a simple, personal website that showcases the owner’s work, introduces who they are, and lets me easily contact them.

Feature2: As a user, I want to navigate easily between the main pages (Home, Work, About, Contact) using a simple, clear navigation menu.

Feature3: As a user, I want the site layout and interactions to be clean and responsive so it feels good to use on both mobile and desktop.

Feature4: As a user, I want the Home page to show a featured work section at the top so I can quickly see the most important projects.

Feature5: As a user, I want the Home page to include a project grid so I can quickly browse multiple projects at a glance.

Feature6: As a user, I want a dedicated Work page that lists all projects so I can explore the full portfolio.

Feature7: As a user, I want each project in the Work page to be clickable so I can open a separate project detail page for more information.

Feature8: As a user, I want projects to be presented in a simple grid with categories or filters so I can narrow down the projects I’m interested in.

Feature9: As a user, I want projects to have basic categorization by project type (e.g., Web, Mobile, Branding) so I can filter by type.

Feature10: As a user, I want projects to be tagged with tools/skills so I can understand the technologies or competencies used in each project.

Feature11: As a user, I want each project detail page to show the project title and a quick summary at the top so I immediately understand what the project is about.

Feature12: As a user, I want each project detail page to include key details such as role and tools so I can see how the owner contributed and what was used.

Feature13: As a user, I want each project detail page to show main visuals (e.g., images or screenshots) so I can visually understand the work.

Feature14: As a user, I want each project detail page to include a longer descriptive write-up near the bottom so I can read the full case study or background.

Feature15: As a user, I want each project detail page to provide relevant external links (e.g., live site, GitHub) near the bottom so I can explore the work further.

Feature16: As a user, I want an About page that clearly describes the owner’s background so I can learn who they are.

Feature17: As a user, I want the About page to include a short bio so I can get a concise overview of the owner.

Feature18: As a user, I want the About page to list the owner’s professional experience (roles/clients and key skills) so I can understand their expertise and track record.

Feature19: As a user, I want a Contact page with a simple contact form so I can easily get in touch.

Feature20: As a user, I want the contact form to send my message via email to the site owner so communication is straightforward.

Feature21: As a user, I want clear error states on the contact form so I know when I’ve made a mistake (e.g., missing or invalid fields) and how to fix it.

Feature22: As a user, I want the site’s pages (Home, Work, About, Contact) to share a consistent visual style so the experience feels cohesive.

Feature23: As a user, I want the site to use a light Peach Puff (#FFDAB9) background across all pages so the look and feel is uniform.

Feature24: As a user, I want core UI components like the navigation bar and project cards to use a contrasting light neutral color (e.g., white) against the Peach Puff background so they stand out clearly.

Feature25: As a user, I want interactive elements like links and buttons to use an Indian Red accent (around #CD5C5C) so I can easily recognize clickable items.

Feature26: As a user, I want button styling to be consistent with the Indian Red accent so actions are visually unified across the site.

Feature27: As a user, I want core components like the navigation and project cards to look and behave consistently on every page so the interface is predictable.

Feature28: As a user, I want any additional decorative elements (e.g., line icons, light borders) to be subtle so the overall design remains clean and uncluttered.

Feature29: As a user, I want text and links to have clearly readable contrast against their backgrounds so I can comfortably read the content, even if exact accessibility targets (e.g., WCAG AA) are not strictly enforced.

Feature30: As a user, I want component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error) to be clearly indicated with sensible, subtle visual changes based on the existing color palette so I can understand the status of my interactions.

initial_requirements: I want a website that presents my professional background and experience in a clear and accessible way.

As a user, I want the website to display my work experience, so that visitors can understand my professional background.
As a user, I want the website to display my skills, so that visitors can see what capabilities I have.

As a user, I want the website to display my projects, so that I can showcase personal projects I have worked on.
As a user, I want to be able to browse the CV on the website, so that I can navigate through the different sections of my profile.
As a user, I want to be able to view my work experience on the website, so that I can see detailed information about my job history.
As a user, I want to be able to understand my skills and education background from the website, so that visitors can clearly see my capabilities and qualifications.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages should the site have, and how would you like visitors to navigate between them (e.g., top menu with sections like About, Experience, Projects, Contact)?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple top navigation with About, Experience, Skills, Projects, Education, and Contact. Clicking a section should jump/scroll to it (single-page style), with the option to expand each item for more detail.

conversation.interviewer: When a visitor expands an item (e.g., a job or project) for more detail, should that stay inline on the same page or open a separate dedicated detail page/view for that item?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way—whatever’s simplest. Inline expand/collapse on the same page is fine.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like visitors to browse your items within each section—e.g., as a simple chronological list, grouped by category (like by role/company or project type), or using a different structure?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact structure—whatever’s simplest. A straightforward chronological list is fine for Experience/Education, and a simple list or grid for Projects.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any special interactions—just make it feel fast and responsive, especially on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Will people access this site only as a standard web page in a browser, or do you also need to support other entry points like a mobile app, embedded view in another platform, or kiosk/large-screen mode?
conversation.user: Just a standard website in a browser is fine. I don’t need a mobile app, embedded version, or kiosk mode.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any special interactions beyond keeping it fast and responsive, especially on mobile.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any separate “modules” or “workspaces” (e.g., a public portfolio view vs an admin/editing area), and if so, how should users switch between them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about separate modules—just a public portfolio site is fine. I don’t need an admin/editing area.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any ability to manage multiple pages or views beyond this single scrolling page (for example, adding new pages or organizing sections into a hierarchy), or should the site remain a fixed one-page layout without user-managed page hierarchy?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about managing multiple pages or any page hierarchy. A fixed one-page scrolling layout is totally fine for me.

conversation.interviewer: Will you or your visitors ever need to switch between different “contexts” on the site—such as multiple user accounts, profiles, or separate portfolios—or is everything for a single, fixed profile only?
conversation.user: I don’t care about multiple contexts or accounts. It’s just a single fixed profile/portfolio.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need any ability to edit or preview media on the site (e.g., upload/change a profile photo or embed a video with playback controls), or will all media be fixed/static with no editing or preview features?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about editing or preview features. Static media is fine—maybe just a fixed profile photo and links to videos if needed.

conversation.interviewer: If your site includes downloadable files or embedded media (like PDFs, resumes, or videos), do you have any specific requirements for how those should be handled—for example, whether files should download directly vs open in a new tab, or whether videos should stream from YouTube/Vimeo vs be hosted locally?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specifics there. If I include a resume PDF, opening it in a new tab is fine, and any videos can just be YouTube/Vimeo links rather than hosting them locally.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific file or media types you know you’ll want to use on the site (for example PDF for your resume only, or also images, slide decks, audio, code embeds, etc.), or should I just assume a resume PDF plus standard images?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific media types—assume a resume PDF plus standard images. Maybe a profile photo and a few project screenshots, and I can link out to GitHub or demos if needed.

conversation.interviewer: When a visitor opens a media item (like a project screenshot or linked video), should it display inline on the page, or open in a separate lightbox/viewer?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way—whatever’s simplest to implement is fine. Inline is fine, or a basic lightbox if that’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: When a visitor clicks your resume PDF (or other downloadable file), should it download immediately, or open in a new browser tab with an option to download?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either is fine. Opening in a new tab with an option to download sounds good.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want users to be able to upload multiple files at once, and if so what maximum file size (per file) should be allowed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about uploads—there won’t be any user file upload feature on the site.

conversation.interviewer: Will your site need to handle any large or structured files behind the scenes (for example, processing or validating an uploaded resume or data file), or can I assume there is no special file processing at all beyond simply serving static files like your PDF and images?
conversation.user: No special file processing needed—just serve static files like a PDF resume and images. I’m not doing any uploads or validation.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any search or filtering features on your site (for example, a search box to find specific jobs/projects or filters like by skill or date), or should visitors just scroll and read without any search/filter tools?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about search or filters—visitors can just scroll and read. If it’s super easy to add later, fine, but not necessary.

conversation.interviewer: For any PDFs, images, or other media on the site, is it acceptable to simply let the browser handle caching them normally (no special cache rules or remote proxying), or do you need any specific behavior like forcing fresh fetches after updates or preventing caching altogether?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about special caching behavior—normal browser caching is fine. If I update something, I can just bump the file name or clear cache if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the portfolio to be fully accessible without any login, or should any sections/content require users to sign in (and if so, what kind of accounts)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about having any login—just make everything publicly accessible with no sign-in required.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a contact form that sends you an email message (with spam protection like reCAPTCHA), or should the Contact section only show clickable links (email address/LinkedIn) with no built-in messaging?

initial_requirements: I want a website where I can organize my important links in one place and easily share them with others.
user_stories: As a user, I want to add new links to my link tree, so that I can display the links I want to share.
As a user, I want to edit existing links in my link tree, so that I can update or correct the links I have already added.
As a user, I want to delete unnecessary links from my link tree, so that I can remove links I no longer want to display.
As a user, I want to create my own link tree, so that I can have a personal collection of links.
As a user, I want to share my link tree with others through a shareable link, so that other people can access my collection of links.
As a user, I want the website’s overall background to be papaya whip, so that the site appearance matches the specified background color.
As a user, I want the website’s components to be styled with dark orange, so that the components match the specified styling color.

conversation.interviewer: What pages should the site have, and how should users navigate between them (e.g., a home/list page, individual link-collection pages, and a shareable public profile page)?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple dashboard/home page where I can see and edit my link collections, plus an individual page for each collection. Also a public profile page that’s shareable, with straightforward navigation between dashboard → collection → public view (and a direct share link).

conversation.interviewer: Should users navigate from overviews or lists into dedicated detail views for individual items, and if so what related views should be reachable from those details?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of navigation detail right now. As long as it’s easy to click from my dashboard into a collection and get a shareable public link, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between your major areas (dashboard, a specific collection, and the public profile view)—for example via a persistent sidebar, top tabs, or a dashboard-first flow with back links?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a sidebar or top tabs. I just want it to feel simple—dashboard-first with clear back links is totally fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like your link collections to be grouped and organized on the dashboard (e.g., folders/categories, tags, or a simple flat list sorted by name/last updated)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy grouping right now. A simple flat list is fine, ideally sorted by last updated (or let me toggle name vs last updated).

conversation.interviewer: For each link collection and your public profile, how should visibility work—for example, should collections be private by default with an option to mark specific collections (or the whole profile) as publicly accessible via a shareable link?
conversation.user: Yeah—private by default. Then I can toggle a specific collection to “public” and it generates a shareable link; same idea for my public profile page (off by default, on when I want to share).

conversation.interviewer: On an individual collection page, what order and layout do you want for the main elements (e.g., collection title/description, the list of links, and the share/public toggle/link)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact layout order. Just make it obvious where to edit the title/description, see the links, and find the public toggle + share link.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities do you want the system to model (e.g., user profile, link collection, individual link), and what key fields should each one include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining the full data model right now. At minimum it’s just a user profile, collections, and links (title + URL), plus a public/private toggle and shareable link for collections/profile.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I think that’s basically it for content. Maybe just let each link have an optional short note/label, and allow me to reorder links within a collection. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want different audiences (e.g., yourself as the owner vs people you share links with) to see different structures or versions of the pages, or should everyone see essentially the same layout and content with only privacy controlling what’s visible?

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color should the UI use for highlights and key actions (e.g., buttons and active states)?
conversation.user: Dark orange would be my preference for the primary accent—use it for buttons, highlights, and active states.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast targets the colors must meet (e.g., WCAG AA/AAA contrast for text and UI controls) to ensure readability?

conversation.interviewer: Which specific visual aspects (such as accent color usage, background tones, text styles, and card/button appearance) do you want to be applied consistently across all pages and views, so the interface feels unified everywhere?

conversation.interviewer: For different component states like hover, disabled, success, and error, do you want a clearly defined color set (e.g., specific shades for each), and should those mostly be variations of your dark orange/papaya-whip scheme or can they introduce additional colors (like green for success, red for errors)?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to follow a specific brand/theme (e.g., minimalist, playful, retro, professional), and if so what theme should guide any additional colors or decorative elements beyond papaya-whip + dark orange?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific brand theme. Just keep it clean and minimalist—no extra decorative stuff beyond the papaya-whip background and dark orange accents.

conversation.interviewer: When users change a filter (e.g., date range, category, location) on the Timeline/Events page, should results update instantly as they adjust it, or only after they click an explicit “Apply filters” button?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If it’s simple, instant updates are nice, but an “Apply filters” button is totally fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One interaction thing: the timeline should feel snappy—when I drag/scroll through time or switch between the interactive view and the list, it should update instantly without a full page reload.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to limit or expand what the search looks through (for example, choosing to search only events, only media/gallery items, or everything at once), or is a single “search everything” behavior sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that right now—just a simple “search everything” is fine. As long as it searches event titles/descriptions, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I think we already covered the main interaction thing I care about (a snappy timeline with no full page reloads). Nothing else specific comes to mind right now.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the content about this person’s life to be grouped and labeled in the site’s main structure—for example, by life phases (childhood, career, later years), by themes (family, work, achievements), or in some other hierarchy?
conversation.user: I’d like the main structure grouped by life phases first (early life, education, career, later years), and then within each phase have theme tags like family, work, achievements, and honors. The overview page can highlight the biggest achievements/honors regardless of phase.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the core pages you mentioned, how would you like those pages and life phases to be arranged in the site hierarchy—for example, which items should appear in the main navigation versus as sub-sections under others (like phases under Biography Overview, or Timeline as its own top-level hub)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact hierarchy. Just keep a simple main nav with Overview, Timeline, and Media/Gallery, and let the life phases show up as sections within the Overview and as filters/tabs on the Timeline.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities do you want the site to model and store (e.g., person, life phase, event/chapter, media item, tag/theme, location), and which key fields should each one have?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down the full data model right now. At a high level you can assume Person, Life Phase, Event/Chapter, Media item, Tag/Theme, and maybe Location with basic fields like title/name, dates, description, and links between them.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content requirements right now. Let’s move on.

conversation.interviewer: What color scheme would you like for the main interactive components—such as buttons, timeline controls, and filters (e.g., a specific accent color or light/dark style)—and are there any accessibility or contrast requirements you want to enforce?
conversation.user: I’d prefer a clean light theme with one strong accent color—maybe a deep blue—for buttons and timeline controls. Please make sure contrast meets WCAG AA at least, with clear focus states and keyboard-friendly controls; a dark mode would be nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and if so should those state colors be variations of the deep blue accent or use distinct colors (e.g., green for success, red for errors)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super defined state color system right now. Basic hover/active/disabled variations of the deep blue are fine, and if you need success/error then standard green/red works.

conversation.interviewer: For the primary fill/background color of your key UI components (buttons, cards/panels, top navigation bar), do you want them mostly white/light gray with deep-blue accents, or should any of those components use deep blue as the main fill?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that level of styling detail. Mostly white/light gray with deep-blue accents is fine, and maybe just use deep blue as a primary button fill if you think it looks best.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the overall page background be (e.g., pure white, off‑white, light gray)?
conversation.user: I’d like the overall page background to be a snow/off‑white rather than pure white—something like #FAFAFA or #F9FBFF.

conversation.interviewer: Which visual elements do you want standardized across the entire site to ensure consistent appearance (e.g., typography, spacing scale, button styles, card styles, icon style)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super prescriptive there right now. As long as typography, button styles, and spacing feel consistent across pages, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site’s visual theme to reflect a particular brand or mood (e.g., formal/academic, modern/minimal, warm/human), and if so what specific theme should it align to?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about a specific brand mood. If you need a direction, modern and minimal is fine as long as it stays readable and clean.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want a Biography Overview page that gives me a quick summary of the person’s life and key highlights.

Feature2: As a user, I want a Timeline/Events page where I can explore events from the person’s life.

Feature3: As a user, I want Event/Chapter detail pages so I can read more in-depth information about specific events.

Feature4: As a user, I want a Media/Gallery section so I can browse photos, videos, and other media related to the person’s life.

Feature5: As a user, I want a simple main navigation with Overview, Timeline, and Media/Gallery so I can easily move between the core areas of the site.

Feature6: As a user, I want life phases (e.g., Early Life, Education, Career, Later Years) to be used to organize the content so I can understand the person’s life in clear stages.

Feature7: As a user, I want the Biography Overview page to be structured into sections by life phase so I can scan each phase easily.

Feature8: As a user, I want theme tags (e.g., family, work, achievements, honors) within each life phase so I can understand the context and type of each event.

Feature9: As a user, I want the Overview page to highlight the person’s biggest achievements and honors regardless of life phase so I can quickly see their most important milestones.

Feature10: As a user, I want the Timeline/Events page to default to an interactive timeline view so I can visually explore events over time.

Feature11: As a user, I want the option to switch the Timeline/Events page to a simple chronological list view so I can see events in a straightforward list.

Feature12: As a user, I want to navigate from the overview to the timeline list and then into event detail pages so I can drill down from summary to specifics.

Feature13: As a user, I want a persistent top menu so I can always access main sections (Overview, Timeline, Media/Gallery) from any page.

Feature14: As a user, I want breadcrumbs on event/chapter detail pages so I can easily navigate back to the previous level (e.g., timeline or overview).

Feature15: As a user, I want basic list-to-detail navigation with an obvious way back so I don’t get lost when viewing event details.

Feature16: As a user, I want to search events using a keyword search box on the Timeline/Events page so I can quickly find relevant events.

Feature17: As a user, I want keyword search to look across event titles and descriptions so I can find events even if I only remember partial details.

Feature18: As a user, I want keyword search to include names and places where possible so I can search for people or locations related to the person’s life.

Feature19: As a user, I want filters on the Timeline/Events page (by date range, theme/category, and location) so I can narrow down the events I see.

Feature20: As a user, I want the ability to combine search and filters on the Timeline/Events page so I can find specific groups of related events.

Feature21: As a user, I want the filter state (date range, theme, location) to persist while I remain on the Timeline/Events page so I can adjust and refine my view without losing my settings.

Feature22: As a user, I want the filter state to reset when I leave or refresh the Timeline/Events page so I start fresh in a new visit.

Feature23: As a user, I want an obvious control to switch between the interactive timeline view and the chronological list view so I can choose the presentation I prefer.

Feature24: As a user, I want the timeline to feel snappy and responsive when I drag or scroll through time so I can explore without lag.

Feature25: As a user, I want switching between the interactive timeline and the list view to happen instantly without a full page reload so the experience feels smooth.

Feature26: As a user, I want search and filter interactions on the timeline to update results without a full page reload so the interface feels modern and fast. (TBD: whether updates are instant or require an Apply button)

Feature27: As a user, I want media items (photos, videos, documents) to be associated with relevant events or life phases so I can see context for each media item.

Feature28: As a user, I want the ability to view media items in a dedicated gallery view so I can browse visual content separately from the text timeline.

Feature29: As a user, I want a clean light theme with a snow/off-white page background (e.g., #FAFAFA or #F9FBFF) so the site feels modern and easy to read.

Feature30: As a user, I want a single strong accent color (e.g., deep blue) for key interactive elements (buttons, timeline controls, filters) so it’s clear what I can click or interact with.

Feature31: As a user, I want primary buttons to use the deep blue accent as their main fill so they stand out as primary actions.

Feature32: As a user, I want basic hover, active, and disabled states for buttons and controls using variations of the deep blue accent so I get visual feedback when interacting.

Feature33: As a user, I want standard green and red to be used for success and error messages so I can easily recognize confirmations and problems when they occur.

Feature34: As a user, I want most UI components (cards/panels, navigation bar, content areas) to be primarily white or light gray with blue accents so the layout feels light and uncluttered.

Feature35: As a user, I want the site to maintain at least WCAG AA contrast for text and interactive elements so content is readable and accessible.

Feature36: As a user, I want clear focus states and keyboard-friendly controls so I can navigate the site using a keyboard and understand where I am on the page.

Feature37: As a user, I want consistent typography across all pages so headings, body text, and labels are easy to scan and understand.

Feature38: As a user, I want consistent button styles across the site so actions look predictable and familiar wherever I am.

Feature39: As a user, I want consistent spacing and layout patterns across pages so the interface feels organized and not cluttered.

Feature40: As a user, I want the overall visual style to be modern and minimal so the focus stays on the person’s life content rather than on decorative design.

Feature41: As a user, I want a simple “search everything” behavior (at least across events) so I don’t have to choose between searching different content types.

initial_requirements: I want a webpage that introduces a team, showcases their work, and makes it easy to contact them.
user_stories: As a user, I want to see a team introduction on the webpage, so that I can understand who the team is.
As a user, I want to view a project showcase on the webpage, so that I can see the team’s project cases.
As a user, I want to view a skill showcase on the webpage, so that I can understand the team’s skills.
As a user, I want to see contact information on the webpage, so that I can contact the team.
As a user, I want to be able to browse team information on the webpage, so that I can learn about the team.

As a user, I want to be able to understand the team’s skills from the skill showcase, so that I know their capabilities.

conversation.interviewer: What pages should the site have, and how would you like visitors to navigate between them (e.g., a top menu with links to Team, Work, and Contact, plus any subpages or detail pages for individual projects)?
conversation.user: I’d prefer it as a single scrolling page with a sticky top nav that jumps to sections: Team, Work/Projects, and Contact. For the projects, clicking one can open a modal or expand inline for details instead of going to a separate page.

conversation.interviewer: Should users navigate from overviews or lists into dedicated detail views for individual items, and if so what related views should be reachable from those details?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about dedicated detail pages—I'd rather keep everything on the single page. Project details can just open in a modal or expand inline, with a simple close/back to the list.

conversation.interviewer: Will the site be used only as a standard desktop/mobile web page opened via a URL, or do you also need an alternative entry point or mode (e.g., embedded in an app, kiosk/large-screen display) that requires different navigation behavior?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about alternative modes like kiosk or embedding. Just a standard responsive website people open via a URL on desktop or mobile is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: Yes—keep navigation snappy: when I click a project, the modal/inline details should open instantly (or with a very quick smooth animation), and the sticky nav jump-to-section should smooth-scroll without lag.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between the main sections (Team, Work/Projects, Contact)—only via the sticky top navigation jump links, or do you also want another switcher like tabs or a sidebar?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra switchers like tabs or a sidebar. The sticky top nav jump links (plus normal scrolling) are enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I think we already covered the main interaction stuff (snappy modals and smooth scrolling). Nothing else comes to mind right now.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the single page’s sections and content to be structured and ordered—for example, should it be Hero/intro → Team → Work/Projects → Contact, and within Team/Projects do you want items grouped (by role, discipline, category) or just a flat list?
conversation.user: I’d like it ordered Hero/intro at the top, then Team, then Work/Projects, then Contact. Team can be grouped by role (e.g., Design, Engineering, PM) with short bios, and Projects grouped by category with a simple grid of cards.

conversation.interviewer: What overall hierarchy of pages and sections should structure the site or application (e.g. main hubs, child pages, and sub-sections)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a page hierarchy since I want it as one single scrolling page. Just sections: Hero/Intro, Team (grouped by role), Work/Projects (grouped by category with modals/expand), and Contact.

conversation.interviewer: How should each project’s detail view (modal/inline) be laid out—what information should appear first and in what order (e.g., title, brief summary, images, your role, tech/skills, results, links)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact order. Just make sure the title and a short summary are up top, then a few images, and links (like live site/GitHub) easy to find.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of files and media do you want to include on the page (e.g., images, videos, downloadable PDFs), and are there any rules about their format, size, or how they should be reused across sections?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict rules for formats or sizes. Mostly just images for team headshots and project screenshots, maybe an occasional short embedded video if it makes sense—no need for downloadable PDFs.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like project media (screenshots/videos) presented in the project detail view—e.g., a swipeable image carousel/gallery, a grid of thumbnails you can click to enlarge/lightbox, or embedded inline at full width?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact presentation. Anything simple and clean is fine—maybe a few inline images, and if there are multiple screenshots, a basic carousel or click-to-enlarge works.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific technical standards for images/videos on the site—such as minimum resolution, preferred aspect ratios, maximum file size, and preferred formats (e.g., WebP/JPEG/PNG for images, MP4 for video)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict technical standards for media. Just keep images and videos reasonably optimized so the page loads fast and looks good on desktop and mobile.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t think I have any more content requirements right now—happy to move on.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the site’s accent and component colors (e.g., button and link colors, hover/highlight states), or should we pick a simple, accessible palette that fits your existing brand/logo colors?
conversation.user: Yes—please use a dark cyan as the main accent for buttons, links, and hover/highlight states. Otherwise feel free to pick a simple, accessible palette that works well with that accent and the logo/brand colors.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme—such as meeting WCAG AA or AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements—or is “generally easy to read and accessible” enough as a guideline?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG level like AA vs AAA—just keep it generally easy to read and accessible, with good contrast for text and buttons.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components (like cards, the sticky nav bar, and modal panels) use—e.g., white, light gray, or a dark tone?
conversation.user: Let’s go with a clean whitesmoke base background overall. For cards/nav/modal panels, a white (or very light gray) surface on top of that is perfect, with the dark cyan accent for interactive bits.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of state colors (e.g., success, error, warning, disabled) for components like buttons and form fields, and if so should these be lighter/darker variations of the dark cyan accent or use distinct colors (like green for success, red for errors)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a defined set of state colors. Just use sensible defaults (green for success, red for errors, gray for disabled) and keep it consistent with the dark cyan accent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any brand guidelines or thematic cues (e.g., logo colors, fonts, patterns/illustrations, or “vibe”) that we should reflect in the UI beyond using dark cyan as the accent?
conversation.user: I don’t really have formal brand guidelines beyond the dark cyan accent and keeping things clean and modern. Feel free to pick a simple readable font and a minimal, professional vibe.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should be strictly standardized across the whole site (e.g., button styles, link styles, card styling, typography scale, spacing, modal styling), and are there any elements you’re okay with varying by section?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict standardization rules. Just keep buttons/links/cards/modals looking consistent site-wide, and I’m fine if a section has slightly different layouts as long as it still feels cohesive.

initial_requirements: I want a mini-program that helps me track my fitness activities and understand my progress over time.
user_stories: As a user, I want to record my fitness activities, so that I can manage my fitness activities in the mini-program.
As a user, I want to use a fitness leaderboard, so that I can see rankings related to fitness activities.
As a user, I want to record my exercises, so that my exercise data is saved in the mini-program.
As a user, I want to browse my own exercises, so that I can review the exercises I have performed.
As a user, I want to view the leaderboard, so that I can see how I compare with others.
As a user, I want to have a fitness statistics homepage, so that I can see an overview of my fitness data.
As a user, I want to track my own fitness data, so that I can monitor my fitness progress.
As a user, I want the mini-program’s canvas background to be white, so that the background color is consistent as specified.
As a user, I want all visible components in the mini-program to be navy, so that the component color is consistent as specified.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like to log a fitness activity in the mini-program—what specific fields should the entry form include (e.g., activity type, duration, distance, calories, notes)?
conversation.user: I’d like the form to have date/time, activity type (run/bike/gym etc.), duration, distance (if applicable), intensity/RPE, and optional calories. Also a notes field and maybe tags like indoor/outdoor or location.

conversation.interviewer: For each of those fields (date/time, activity type, duration, distance, intensity/RPE, calories, notes, tags/location), which should be required to save an activity and which should remain optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about strict required vs optional rules—just make it flexible. If anything, date/time and activity type should be required, and everything else can be optional.

conversation.interviewer: What bulk operations (if any) should the activity log support—for example selecting multiple entries to delete at once, edit fields in bulk, or duplicate an entry?
conversation.user: It’d be nice to select multiple entries and delete them at once. Duplicating an entry would be useful too (like repeating a workout), but I don’t really need bulk editing beyond that.

conversation.interviewer: When should progress calculations/insights update—immediately after each activity is saved, on a scheduled basis (e.g., daily/weekly), or only when the user taps a “refresh/analyze” button?
