conversation.user: Required: case title/name, case ID/number, status (open/closed), date opened, and a short summary. Optional: assigned detective/team, priority, location/jurisdiction, suspects/victims/witnesses, related cases, evidence list, notes, and key dates like last update or due date.

conversation.interviewer: For detective cases specifically, which actions do you want to be able to perform in bulk from a list view (for example, closing multiple cases, reassigning them, changing status/priority), and are there any bulk operations you explicitly do not want?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about specific bulk operations right now. The main ones I’d want are close/reopen, change status/priority, and reassign cases; I don’t want any bulk delete unless it’s heavily protected (like admin-only with confirmations).

conversation.interviewer: For actions like closing/reopening cases, changing status/priority, or reassigning, would you prefer these to run immediately when you confirm them, be queued/batched to run on a schedule, or sometimes be triggered automatically based on rules (like “auto-close after 30 days inactive”)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about scheduling/queuing or automation rules right now. I’d prefer bulk actions to run immediately after I confirm them.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re looking through your list of cases, what kinds of search and filtering options do you want (for example, search by text, filter by status/priority/date range/assigned detective), and are there any you consider essential for quickly finding the right cases?
conversation.user: Essential: a global text search (title, case ID, summary/notes) plus filters for status (open/closed), priority, assigned detective/team, and date range (opened/last updated). Tagging or jurisdiction/location filters would be nice too, and I’d like to be able to save a couple common filter views.

conversation.interviewer: Which filtering options and conditions should be available for narrowing lists or data sets (e.g. attributes, ranges, statuses)?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about every possible filter condition beyond the basics. As long as I can filter by status, priority, assigned detective/team, and date ranges (opened/last updated), plus a simple text search, that’s enough for me right now.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re viewing a list of cases, which fields do you want to be able to sort by (for example, date opened, last updated, priority, status, assigned detective/team), and do you need both ascending and descending order for those sorts?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sorting specifics right now. If you include basics like date opened, last updated, priority, and status, that’s fine, and having both ascending/descending would be nice.

conversation.interviewer: When you apply filters to your case list, how would you like them to behave—should they auto-apply as you change options or only after you click an “Apply” button, and should your filter selections persist when you navigate away and come back or reset each time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact filter behavior details. If I had to pick, auto-apply is fine as long as it’s fast, and I’d prefer filters to persist when I come back.

conversation.interviewer: When you run a search on your cases, how would you prefer the results to be displayed and organized—for example, a table-like list with columns you can sort, cards with key details, or something else, and do you need things like pagination or quick detail previews from that results view?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact layout. A simple table/list view is fine, and pagination is okay as long as it stays fast; quick previews would be nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to choose which fields are included in the global search (e.g., title, case ID, summary, notes, evidence), or should it always search a fixed set of fields?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about making that configurable. Just search a sensible default set (title, case ID, summary, notes) and I’m good; maybe add evidence later if it’s not too heavy.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I want the app to feel real-time—when I add or update a case, note, or evidence, it should show up immediately everywhere (lists, search results, and any dashboards) without me needing to refresh.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re moving around the app, how would you like the main navigation and pages to be structured—for example, what top‑level sections (like “Cases”, “Evidence”, “People”, “Reports”, etc.) should exist and how should you get from a case list into a specific case’s details and back again?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation structure right now. As long as there’s an easy way to get to Cases, open a case’s details from the list, and jump back to the list quickly, I’m fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have another interaction requirement right now. As long as it stays fast and updates show up immediately without refreshing, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond cases themselves, which other core entities do you definitely want the app to model as first‑class records (for example, people, evidence items, locations, tasks, documents), and how should they be logically linked to a case (one‑to‑many, many‑to‑many, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about modeling a bunch of extra entities as first-class records right now. If you do anything beyond cases, evidence items and people (suspects/victims/witnesses) would be the most useful, linked many-to-many to cases.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like your case-related information to be grouped and structured within the app—for example, what main sections or tabs should appear inside a case (such as Overview, Evidence, People, Notes, Timeline), and in what order or hierarchy should they appear?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact tab structure right now. As long as there’s an Overview plus easy places for Notes, Evidence, and People, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing major beyond what we covered. Maybe support attaching documents/photos to a case and evidence items, and a simple activity log of updates—otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: For the activity log/change history, what exactly should be recorded for each update (e.g., who made the change, timestamp, and before/after values), and where should users be able to view it (per case only or also a global log)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about super detailed change history. Just record who changed it, when, and a brief “what changed,” and let me view it on each case; a global log would be nice but not necessary.

conversation.interviewer: For each case record, what level of detail should be stored and shown for updates—do you want just the current values, or also metadata like created/last-updated timestamps and who created/last modified the case?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about that level of detail. Having basic created/last-updated timestamps is fine, and who last modified it could be useful, but I don’t need anything super detailed.

conversation.interviewer: Besides individual detective cases themselves, what other kinds of ongoing records do you definitely want the system to store and track over time (for example, standalone evidence items, people profiles, documents, or anything else that should exist as its own record type)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more record types beyond cases right now. If you include anything else, just people profiles and evidence items would be enough, plus basic document/photo attachments.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content requirement: I want to log my work hours per case (date, duration, short description) and have the total hours show up on the case overview, with a simple per-case timesheet view.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me conduct risk assessments and review the results in an organized way.
user_stories: As a user, I want to conduct risk assessments on a website, so that I can evaluate risks and generate corresponding reports.
As a user, I want to select risk assessment items, so that the system can use my selections to perform a risk assessment.
As a user, I want the website to automatically fill in relevant data for my selected risk assessment items from a background database, so that I do not have to enter all data manually.
As a user, I want the website to generate charts based on the risk assessment data, so that I can visualize the assessment results.
As a user, I want the website to create reports based on the risk assessment data, so that I can review and share the assessment outcomes.
As a user, I want a subscription feature on the website, so that I can access the risk assessment tool through a subscription.
As a user, I want the website’s background to be alice blue, so that the overall page background follows this defined color.
As a user, I want the website’s components to be steel blue, so that all components follow this defined color.

conversation.interviewer: How should users enter and update risk assessment data—via step-by-step guided forms, a single multi-section form, or bulk upload/import for many assessments at once?
conversation.user: I’d like step-by-step guided forms where I can explicitly select the relevant risk assessment items up front. Bulk import would be nice as an optional add-on for large batches, but not the main flow.

conversation.interviewer: For a single risk assessment created through the guided flow, what specific fields should the user be able to enter or edit (e.g., assessment title, scope, hazards/risks, likelihood, impact, controls, owner, due dates), and which of those are required versus optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact field list right now—just the basics like title, scope, risks, likelihood/impact, controls, and an owner. We can decide what’s required vs optional later once we see a draft form.

conversation.interviewer: For a single risk assessment, what distinct steps or phases do you want in its lifecycle (for example, draft, under review, approved, scheduled for review, closed), and how should users move an assessment from one step to the next?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a detailed lifecycle right now. A simple draft → review → approved flow is fine to start, and we can refine the steps and permissions later once we see how people use it.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details like button behavior right now. As long as it’s reasonably fast and easy to navigate, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main types of information you want the system to model and organize as first-class items (for example, “risk assessment,” “risk,” “control/mitigation,” “asset,” “business unit”), and how would you like them grouped or related to each other?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a bunch of first-class item types up front. For now, just treat a “risk assessment” as the main thing, with risks and controls inside it, and we can revisit more structure later if it becomes necessary.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level sections should the site have in its main navigation (e.g., Dashboard, Assessments list, Templates, Reports), and what key pages should live under each?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed navigation structure right now. At minimum I’d want an Assessments list and a page to create a new assessment, plus maybe a simple Dashboard and Reports later.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any other content requirements right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What color or colors would you like to use as the primary accent for interactive components such as buttons, links, and highlights in the interface?
conversation.user: I’d like a steel blue accent for buttons, links, and highlights—something in that blue‑gray range. Neutral grays/white for the rest is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility standards or contrast requirements (for example, WCAG AA/AAA levels) that the color choices for text, buttons, and other interactive elements must meet?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG level right now. Just make sure text and buttons have good, readable contrast and we can tighten it up later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from the steel-blue accent or use separate dedicated colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about locking down state colors right now. Just use sensible defaults—hover/active derived from the steel blue is fine, and use standard clear colors for success/error/disabled.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key containers like cards and panels use (e.g., white, light gray, or another neutral)?
conversation.user: For cards and panels, I’d prefer white or a very light gray so they stand out cleanly. The overall page background can be an alice blue.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements (e.g., buttons, form fields, tables, cards, headings) must use the exact same styling across the entire site to ensure a consistent look on every page and device?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specifying exact global styling rules right now. As long as the common stuff like buttons, form fields, tables, and cards looks consistent across pages, that’s good enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Is there an existing brand or thematic concept (e.g., logo, brand colors, industry theme) that the interface should visually align with beyond the steel blue and neutral palette, and if so, what key visual elements from it should be reflected in the UI?
conversation.user: No, there’s no existing brand or theme it needs to match beyond the steel blue + neutral palette. Keep it clean and professional—no specific logo or visual elements to align to.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to view a list of all risk assessments so I can find and open an assessment quickly.  
Feature2: As a user, I want to create a new risk assessment using step-by-step guided forms so I can enter information in an organized way.  
Feature3: As a user, I want to explicitly select the relevant risk assessment items up front during creation so I can focus the assessment on what matters.  
Feature4: As a user, I want to enter and edit basic assessment details (title, scope, risks, likelihood/impact, controls, owner) so I can document the assessment.  
Feature5: As a user, I want risks and controls to be managed within a risk assessment so I can review them in one place.  
Feature6: As a user, I want a simple assessment status flow (draft → review → approved) so I can track progress from creation to approval.  
Feature7: As a user, I want to change an assessment’s status between draft, review, and approved so I can move it through the workflow.  
Feature8: As a user, I want an optional bulk import feature for large batches of assessments so I can add many assessments efficiently. (TBD)  
Feature9: As a user, I want a simple Dashboard so I can get an at-a-glance view of assessments. (TBD)  
Feature10: As a user, I want basic Reports so I can review results in an organized way. (TBD)  
Feature11: As a user, I want the interface to be reasonably fast and easy to navigate so I can work efficiently.  
Feature12: As a user, I want a clean, professional UI with a steel-blue accent and neutral grays/white so the site looks consistent and modern.  
Feature13: As a user, I want the overall page background to be alice blue and cards/panels to be white or very light gray so content is easy to scan.  
Feature14: As a user, I want sensible default component state styling (hover/active derived from steel blue; standard success/error/disabled colors) so interactions are clear.  
Feature15: As a user, I want readable contrast for text and buttons so the interface remains legible and accessible.  
Feature16: As a user, I want consistent styling for common components (buttons, form fields, tables, cards) across the site so the UI feels cohesive.

task_name: Construction Project and Document Management System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me manage construction projects, coordinate my team, and keep track of progress and resources.
user_stories: As a user, I want to manage documents related to construction projects, so that I can organize and access project documentation on the website.
As a user, I want to schedule project timelines, so that I can plan and oversee the timing of construction activities.
As a user, I want to use communication tools within the website, so that I can communicate with team members about project-related matters.
As a user, I want to estimate job and project costs, so that I can understand and manage the financial aspects of construction projects.
As a user, I want to manage resources, so that I can allocate and oversee materials, equipment, and personnel for projects.
As a user, I want to create projects, so that I can start managing new construction jobs on the website.
As a user, I want to manage existing projects, so that I can update and maintain details for ongoing construction jobs.
As a user, I want to track project progress, so that I can monitor the status and advancement of each construction project.
As a user, I want the website to have a light gray background, so that the overall site background appearance matches the specified color.
As a user, I want the UI elements to be dark red, so that the interface components have the specified color.
I expect the system to provide information for estimating and managing job and project costs.

conversation.interviewer: When your team is updating project information (like tasks, materials, or progress), how would you like those workflows to function—do you imagine simple inline edits on lists/tables, more detailed multi-step forms, bulk update/import options (e.g., via Excel), or a combination, and for which types of data specifically?
conversation.user: A combination would be ideal. For day-to-day updates, I want quick inline edits in tables for tasks (status, % complete, hours/time spent) and materials used. For bigger changes, use a more detailed form, and I’d like bulk import/export via Excel for initial task lists, material logs, and resource assignments.

conversation.interviewer: For the detailed “bigger changes” form, which specific fields should be editable for a task, and which of those fields are required vs optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting that granular on required vs optional fields right now. As long as I can edit the basics—name, assignee, dates, status, notes, and attachments—and the app guides us if something important is missing.

conversation.interviewer: For tasks, materials logs, and resource assignments, which bulk actions should the interface support beyond Excel import/export (e.g., bulk edit fields, bulk delete, duplicate/copy, archive/restore)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a bunch of bulk actions beyond Excel import/export. If anything, maybe a simple bulk status/assignee update for tasks and an archive/restore option, but it’s not a priority.

conversation.interviewer: When should actions like recalculating progress and updating resource totals run—automatically as soon as someone edits/imports data, on a scheduled interval (e.g., nightly), or only when a user clicks a “Save/Run update” button?
conversation.user: Ideally it updates automatically right after an edit or import so totals and progress stay accurate in real time. If something is heavy, it can run in the background and show a quick “updating” indicator, but I don’t want people having to click a separate button.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific processes in the system should use a defined multi-step workflow with explicit phases/statuses (e.g., task changes, material requests, resource assignments, change orders), and what phases should each one go through?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about setting up formal multi-step workflows with a bunch of phases right now. For now, simple statuses on tasks (like Not Started/In Progress/Blocked/Done) are enough.

conversation.interviewer: What core pages do you want in the app, and how should users navigate between them (e.g., a left sidebar with Projects → Project Dashboard → Tasks/Materials/Resources, or a top navigation, and should clicking a list item open a full detail page or a side panel)?
conversation.user: I’d like a left sidebar with Projects at the top, then inside a project: Dashboard, Tasks, Materials, Resources, and maybe Team/Files. Clicking an item should open a quick side panel for fast edits, with an option to open a full detail page if you need more info or attachments.

conversation.interviewer: When a user clicks a task/material/resource in a list, should the default detail view be a side panel, a full page, or user-selectable, and from that detail view what other related views should be directly reachable (e.g., attachments, comments, history, linked materials/resources)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much as long as it’s quick. Defaulting to a side panel is fine, with easy access to attachments and comments, and maybe a simple activity/history log.

conversation.interviewer: How should users switch between different projects (workspaces) when they’re in the app—via a project dropdown/search at the top of the sidebar, a dedicated Projects page first, tabs for recent projects, or something else?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact pattern. A simple Projects page plus a quick project switcher dropdown/search in the sidebar is fine.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any extra interaction requirements beyond it feeling fast and responsive. As long as lists load quickly and inline edits save without lag, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: When someone is inside a project and wants to “discover” or just browse what needs attention (tasks, materials issues, resource conflicts), how would you like that structured—primarily as simple sortable/filterable lists, or would you want additional discovery views like grouped-by-category/phase boards, “what’s overdue/at risk” views, or something else?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy discovery views right now. Simple sortable/filterable lists with an easy “overdue/at risk” filter are enough.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding anything beyond it being fast and responsive—quick search and no lag on inline saves is basically it.

conversation.interviewer: Do you expect users to work with more than one company/account or environment (e.g., different clients or business units) in the same session, and if so, how should they switch between those contexts in the interface?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about multi-company/account switching right now. For us it’ll mostly be one company, multiple projects, so project switching is the main thing.

conversation.interviewer: Will people access this mainly via a desktop web app, or do you also expect mobile/tablet or kiosk use, and if so, should navigation feel essentially the same across those (e.g., same left sidebar structure) or be simplified/adjusted on smaller screens?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact device breakdown right now. Desktop web is the main use case, and as long as it works reasonably well on tablets/phones with a simpler layout, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: When an inline edit or Excel import fails (validation error, conflict, or permission issue), what exact options should the user get in the UI—e.g., fix and resubmit immediately, retry, skip the failed rows and continue, download an error report, or contact an admin?
conversation.user: I don’t care about getting super detailed on that. As long as it clearly tells me what failed and why, lets us fix it and retry, and for Excel imports can skip bad rows and download an error report, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: When someone changes configuration/settings (e.g., project settings, user roles/permissions, status lists), should those changes apply immediately when saved, or should they be made as drafts that require review/confirmation (or approval) before going live?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about draft/approval workflows for settings right now. Immediate apply on save is fine, as long as there’s an easy way to undo or revert if someone messes something up.

conversation.interviewer: When users search for tasks/materials/resources, what filters should be available and should those filter selections persist (e.g., per user per project) the next time they open the list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting too detailed on filters. Basic ones like status, assignee, date range, and “overdue/at risk” are enough, and it’d be nice if my last-used filters just stick per user per project.

conversation.interviewer: Within a single project, should users be able to create and organize additional custom pages/views (beyond the default Dashboard/Tasks/Materials/Resources/Team/Files), and if so, how would you want those pages grouped or ordered in the sidebar?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about custom pages/views right now. The default set is fine, and maybe later we can add something like pinned saved filters or reports if it becomes necessary.

conversation.interviewer: When people upload, view, or download files (plans, photos, contracts, reports) in the app, how should that work in detail—for example, should files open in an in-app viewer vs download by default, should there be versioning and simple previews (PDF/images), and are there any rules about where files are stored (e.g., cloud-only, local export options)?
conversation.user: I’d like files to open in an in-app viewer by default (at least PDFs and images), with a clear download button. Simple versioning would be helpful for plans/contracts so we can see the latest and access older versions, plus quick previews/thumbnails. Storage can be cloud-only, but we should be able to export/download files anytime.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond viewing and downloading, which specific file and media management actions do you need in the app (for example, organizing into folders/tags, renaming, deleting/archiving, moving between projects), and which of those should be available to all users versus restricted to certain roles?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super detailed on file management actions or role restrictions right now. Basic stuff like folders/tags, rename, and delete/archive is enough, and moving files between projects can be admin-only if needed.

conversation.interviewer: For media in the in-app viewer (photos, videos, PDFs), what specific viewing/playback controls do you need—e.g., zoom/pan, fullscreen, page thumbnails/search for PDFs, and for videos play/pause/seek/volume/speed?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific on viewer controls. Just the basics: zoom/pan and fullscreen for PDFs/photos, and standard play/pause/seek/volume for videos.

task_name: Medical Journal Publishing and Access System
initial_requirements: I want a website where I can explore and read medical research articles, and manage my involvement with the journal.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use a medical journal website for publishing medical articles and information, so that I can access medical content online.
As a user, I want the website to have a responsive design, so that I can use it easily on different devices and screen sizes.
As a user, I want to be able to search on the website, so that I can quickly find relevant articles and information.
As a user, I want to be able to open articles, so that I can read the full content.
As a user, I want to be able to download article PDFs, so that I can access and keep copies of the articles offline.
As an author user, I want to manage my account by updating my profile information, so that my author account details remain accurate and current.
As a user, I want the website background color to be seashell, so that the site appearance matches the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the website components to use crimson, so that the site appearance matches the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of search and filtering options do you want when looking for medical research articles (for example, by topic, author, journal section, publication date, study type, or your own involvement such as articles you’ve reviewed or authored)?
conversation.user: I’d like a simple keyword search plus filters for topic/keywords, author, publication date range, journal section, and study type. It’d also be really helpful to filter by my involvement—things I’ve authored, reviewed, or bookmarked.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need keyword or text-based search on lists or records, and what basic fields should be searchable?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about text search on other lists or records beyond the articles themselves. For articles, searchable fields should be title, abstract, keywords, author names, and maybe DOI.

conversation.interviewer: When a user changes filters on the article list, should results update automatically or only after clicking an Apply/Search button?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way—automatic updates are fine as long as it’s fast, but an Apply button is also okay.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the article search results to be presented and organized—such as in a list or table, with which key fields visible (e.g., title, authors, journal section, date, study type) and options like sorting, pagination, or quick-preview of the abstract?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the exact layout, as long as it’s easy to scan. A simple list with title, authors, date, and journal section is enough, with sorting by date/relevance and pagination or infinite scroll. A quick abstract preview on hover/click would be nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Which fields should users be able to sort the article search results by, and should each support ascending/descending order?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a lot of sort options. Date (newest/oldest) and relevance are the main ones; if author or journal section sorting is easy, that’s fine too, with ascending/descending where it makes sense.

conversation.interviewer: For article searching, do you want users to be able to choose which set of articles are searched (e.g., all articles vs only their authored/reviewed/bookmarked ones), or should search always run across all available articles by default?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much—defaulting to searching all articles is fine. If it’s easy, having a quick toggle to search only my authored/reviewed/bookmarked articles would be convenient.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to browse and read article abstracts/full text without logging in, or should all access require an authenticated account?
conversation.user: I don’t really care that much. Ideally abstracts are public, and full text could require login if there are permissions/subscription reasons.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond viewing article abstracts, are there any other features or types of content you want visitors to access without logging in (for example, basic search, viewing article metadata, or browsing journal sections)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much beyond abstracts being public. If it’s simple, letting visitors do basic search/browse sections and see article metadata without logging in would be nice, but not a hard requirement.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the main navigation and core pages of the site to be structured—for example, what top-level menu items or sections (such as “Browse Articles,” “My Submissions,” “My Reviews,” “Bookmarks,” “Journal Info,” etc.) should exist and how should users move between the article lists, article details, and their personal/journal management areas?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact navigation structure. As long as there’s an easy way to get to Browse Articles, an article detail page, and a simple “My Account” area for things like submissions/reviews/bookmarks, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: One thing I’d add is that it should be fully responsive—work smoothly on mobile/tablet/desktop with layouts that adapt without feeling cramped, especially the article list and filters.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re managing your involvement with the journal (e.g., submitting articles, updating submission details, logging reviews, or managing bookmarks), what specific workflows or forms do you want—could you describe the key steps and fields you expect in one of these processes (for instance, a new article submission)?
conversation.user: For a new article submission, I’d want a simple wizard: enter title, abstract, keywords, author list/affiliations, journal section, study type, and corresponding author contact, then upload the manuscript PDF and any figures/supplementary files. After submitting, I should see a status timeline (submitted/under review/revisions/accepted), be able to edit metadata until review starts, upload revised versions with a response-to-reviewers note, and manage bookmarks from the article page with a one-click save/unsave.

conversation.interviewer: Besides new article submission, which other journal-related processes (if any) should use a defined multi-step workflow with explicit phases/statuses?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more multi-step workflows beyond submissions. Reviews could have a simple status like “assigned/in progress/submitted,” but it doesn’t need a big phased wizard.

conversation.interviewer: For the new article submission form, which of the fields you listed (title, abstract, keywords, author/affiliations, journal section, study type, corresponding author contact, manuscript PDF, figures/supplements) are required versus optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact required/optional rules, as long as the essentials are required. I’d say title, abstract, author list (with at least one affiliation), journal section, corresponding author contact, and the manuscript PDF should be required; keywords, study type, and figures/supplements can be optional.

conversation.interviewer: What distinct user roles do you envision for the site (e.g., reader, author, reviewer, editor, admin), and do you want their permissions to be very fine-grained per feature (like who can change submission metadata, see reviewer identities, or manage other users) or kept fairly simple and broad?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about very fine-grained roles. Broad roles like reader, author, reviewer, and admin/editor are enough, with simple permissions (authors manage their submissions, reviewers see assigned reviews, admins/editors manage everything).

conversation.interviewer: For key actions like manuscript uploads, revised-version submissions, and bookmarking, should each action take effect immediately when the user clicks/finishes it, or do you want an explicit “Review & Confirm/Submit” step before the system commits the change?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. Immediate save is fine for bookmarking, and for uploads/revised versions either immediate with a clear success message or a simple final “Submit” step—whatever’s simplest and reliable.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding any more interaction requirements beyond it being responsive. As long as the basics feel straightforward and not laggy, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond articles and user accounts, what main types of information do you want the system to explicitly model as separate entities (for example, journal sections, study types, institutions/affiliations, reviewer assignments, submission versions), and which of these should have their own structured records rather than just free-text fields?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the underlying data modeling details. If I had to pick, journal sections, study types, institutions/affiliations, reviewer assignments, and submission versions should probably be structured records so filtering and tracking works cleanly.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level sections should the site have (i.e., the main page/section hierarchy you want users to navigate through)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a detailed hierarchy. Just make it easy to get to Browse Articles, an Article page, and a My Account area (submissions, reviews, bookmarks).

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the medical research articles to be categorized for browsing (e.g., by journal section only, or also by topic/keywords and study type)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how deep the categorization gets. Browsing by journal section is enough, and if topic/keywords and study type come along for free, that’s a nice bonus.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the main manuscript PDF and figures/supplementary files, are there any other specific file or media types (e.g., datasets, code repositories, video abstracts, images) you want the system to support and treat as distinct, reusable content?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting extra media types beyond the manuscript PDF and optional figures/supplementary files. If you can allow a generic “additional files” upload for datasets or code as attachments, that’s fine, but not a requirement.

initial_requirements: I want a website that brings together bands, advertisers, and visitors, allowing bands to showcase their work, advertisers to reach audiences, and users to discover entertainment content.
user_stories: As a band member, I want to register an account, so that I can access band-specific features on the website.
As a band member, I want to log in to my account, so that I can manage and update my band information.
As a band member, I want to input my band bio, so that visitors can read information about my band.
As a band member, I want to provide picture links, so that visitors can see images related to my band.
As a band member, I want to provide audio sample links, so that visitors can listen to my band’s music.
As a band member, I want to provide direct links to YouTube videos, so that visitors can watch my band’s videos.
As an advertiser, I want to register an account, so that I can access advertiser-specific features on the website.
As an advertiser, I want to log in to my account, so that I can manage and update my advertisements.
As an advertiser, I want to upload my ad content, so that my advertisements can be displayed on the website.
As a user, I want to browse band information, so that I can learn about different bands.
As a user, I want to listen to audio samples, so that I can hear the music of different bands.
As a user, I want to watch videos, so that I can view band performances or related video content.
As a user, I want to view advertisements, so that I can see promotional content from advertisers.
As a user, I want the page background to use floral white, so that the website has the specified background color.
As a user, I want the elements to use dark goldenrod, so that the website has the specified element color.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to move around the site—for example, what main menu items or core pages (such as “Bands,” “Advertisers,” “Events,” “Discover,” etc.) do you want in the navigation, and how should visitors browse from lists (of bands, ads, content) to individual detail pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact menu labels right now. As long as it’s easy to browse lists (bands/ads/content) and click through to a clean detail page with media and contact info, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: What types of accounts and permissions do you envision for this site—for example, should bands, advertisers, and regular visitors each have their own login/role with different capabilities (such as publishing content or managing campaigns), and is any real-name or identity verification required for any of them?
conversation.user: Yeah, I’d want role-based accounts: Band accounts to create/edit their profile and upload media, Advertiser accounts to create/manage ads or campaigns, and regular visitors can browse without logging in (optional signup for favorites/messages). No strict real-name verification, but some basic email verification and maybe a manual review for advertisers would be good.

conversation.interviewer: Which user roles are needed and how granular should permissions be across features and data?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about super-granular permissions. Just keep it simple: bands manage their own profiles/media, advertisers manage their own ads/campaigns, visitors browse (optional account for favorites/messages), and an admin role to moderate and handle reviews.

conversation.interviewer: For each account type (band, advertiser, regular visitor), what exact information and steps should the registration flow include—for example, which fields are required, whether email verification is mandatory, and when (if at all) an admin needs to manually approve the account before it becomes active?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact registration fields or step-by-step flow right now. Just do basic required email + password (or OAuth), make email verification mandatory, and only require admin approval for advertiser accounts before they can run campaigns.

conversation.interviewer: Which login methods should the site support for bands/advertisers/optional visitor accounts—email+password only, or also social/OAuth providers (and if so, which ones)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which social providers specifically. Email+password is fine, and if you add OAuth later, just pick the common ones like Google (maybe Facebook/Apple).

conversation.interviewer: How should uploaded and embedded media behave on the site—specifically, should audio/video play in-page with a persistent player (continuing while users navigate), or stop when they leave the detail page?
conversation.user: For band profiles, I’d like audio/video to play in-page, and ideally have a mini persistent player so it can keep playing while they browse other pages. If that’s too complex for v1, it can stop on navigation, but a persistent player would be a nice upgrade.

conversation.interviewer: On band detail pages, what specific playback controls must the in-page audio/video player include at launch (e.g., play/pause, seek/scrub, volume/mute, fullscreen/PiP, playback speed)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the full set of playback controls at launch. Just the basics like play/pause, scrub/seek, and volume/mute are enough for v1.

conversation.interviewer: Which media types and sources should bands be able to add to their profiles in v1—for example, uploaded audio/video files (and which formats like MP3/WAV/MP4), or embedded links from platforms like YouTube, Vimeo, or SoundCloud?
conversation.user: In v1, bands should be able to upload images and audio samples (MP3 is fine to start), and add embedded links for videos—YouTube is the main one, and maybe Vimeo. SoundCloud embeds would also be great if it’s not a lot of extra work.

conversation.interviewer: What file/media management actions should band and advertiser users have after uploading (e.g., delete, replace, rename, reorder/organize into galleries/playlists), and should there be any version/history tracking?
conversation.user: Keep it simple: after upload, bands should be able to delete, replace, and reorder items (like a small gallery/playlist), and maybe edit a title/description. Advertisers should be able to swap creatives and pause/remove them. I don’t need version/history tracking for v1.

conversation.interviewer: What upload limits do you want in v1—for example, the maximum file size per upload and whether users can upload multiple files at once (and if so, how many per batch)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific upload limits for v1. Just pick sensible defaults so it’s smooth—multi-file upload is fine as long as it doesn’t feel clunky.

conversation.interviewer: When a user uploads media, should the site process it immediately and make them wait (showing a progress bar), or upload first and then process in the background (showing a “processing” status until it’s ready)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care as long as it feels fast and clear to the user. A progress bar for upload is good, and if processing takes time, just show a simple “processing” status until it’s ready.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have a specific interaction requirement to add right now. Just keep the UI snappy and straightforward so people can find bands and hit play without friction.

conversation.interviewer: What search and filtering should users have when browsing lists (e.g., bands)—which filters are required in v1, and should selected filters persist as users click into a detail page and back?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific filters in v1—just have a basic search box and maybe one or two simple filters like genre and location. And yeah, it’d be nice if whatever filters they pick stick when they go into a band page and come back.

conversation.interviewer: When users change a filter (e.g., genre/location), should results update immediately (auto-apply) or only after they click an “Apply filters” button?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. Just do whatever feels simplest and fast for users—auto-apply is fine if it stays responsive.

conversation.interviewer: When users use the search box on band or content lists, what should their text query match against—for example, just band name, or also genre, location, and maybe description/bio?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact matching rules right now. Just make it feel intuitive—at least band name, and if it also hits genre/location/bio that’s fine as long as results stay relevant.

conversation.interviewer: When a user performs a search or uses filters on bands or content, how would you like the results list to be presented and organized—for example, a simple card/grid of bands with key info and pagination/infinite scroll, or something more structured like a sortable list?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact layout or pagination style right now. Just make the results easy to scan (cards with image/name/genre/location) and keep it fast—either pagination or infinite scroll is fine.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like user sessions and security to be handled—for example, should logins persist across browser restarts, automatically time out after a certain period of inactivity, or restrict each account to a single active login at a time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specifics there. Just use standard secure sessions—stay logged in by default unless the user logs out, and time out eventually for safety.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have anything specific to add there. Just keep it fast and simple so people can browse and play media without extra clicks.

conversation.interviewer: What core pieces of structured information do you want to track for each main entity in the system (bands, advertisers, ads/campaigns, and content)—for example, which specific fields should every band record have (beyond name/genre/location), and which fields should every advertiser and campaign record have?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about nailing down exact field lists right now. For v1 just capture the basics: for bands a profile + contact + media links/uploads; for advertisers a business profile + billing/contact; and for campaigns simple targeting, budget, dates, creatives, and status.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond bands, advertisers, campaigns, and basic media items, are there any additional core business entities you definitely want modeled in the database (for example, events, venues, user favorites/playlists, or ad impressions/clicks), and how should they relate to bands/advertisers?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more core entities in v1. Maybe just user favorites (bands/content) and basic ad impressions/click tracking for advertisers, but we can keep everything else out for now.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me explore and look up biological information about different species in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse biological information data for different species, so that I can view species-related biological information.
As a user, I want to search for specific biological information data, so that I can quickly find the data I am interested in.
As a user, I want to filter biological information data based on different criteria, so that I can narrow down the data to match my needs.
As a user, I want the website’s base color to be linen, so that the overall background appearance follows this specified color.
As a user, I want all components on the website to use maroon as their color, so that the interface components consistently follow this specified color.

conversation.interviewer: What search and filtering capabilities do you need when looking up species (e.g., keyword search, filters by taxonomy/location/traits, and whether filters should persist as you browse results)?
conversation.user: I definitely need a keyword search (common/scientific name) plus autocomplete. Filters by taxonomy (kingdom→species), location/range, conservation status, and a few basic traits (habitat, size) would be great. Filters should persist while I browse and only reset if I clear them.

conversation.interviewer: Should the filters update results automatically as you change them, or do you want an explicit “Apply filters” button to run the search?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way—whatever’s simplest. If you need a preference, auto-updating as I change filters is nice as long as it stays fast.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need keyword or text-based search on lists or records, and what basic fields should be searchable?
conversation.user: Yes—definitely a keyword search on species lists/records. At minimum it should search common name, scientific name (including synonyms), and maybe higher taxonomy (genus/family) plus basic traits keywords like habitat; if possible, also region/location and conservation status.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the search results to be displayed—e.g., as a list of cards with quick previews or a table with sortable columns?
conversation.user: I don’t really care—either cards or a table is fine. As long as I can quickly see the common/scientific name and a couple key bits like range and conservation status.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to sort the species search results, and if so which fields (e.g., name, conservation status, range) and should sorting support ascending/descending order?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about sorting. If it’s easy to add, sorting by common/scientific name and conservation status (A–Z / Z–A) would be plenty.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really have any specific interaction requirements beyond it feeling fast and not laggy when filters/search update.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core entities (data types) you want the site to model and store besides “Species” (e.g., Taxon, Observation/Occurrence, Region/Range, Trait, ConservationAssessment, Image/Media, Source/Reference)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model details. As long as I can look up a species and see taxonomy, range/region, basic traits, conservation status, and a couple references/images, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s main navigation to be organized—for example, should it be centered around a “Search/Browse species” entry point with separate sections for Species pages, Taxonomy browser, and Regions/Habitats, or some other hierarchy?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation hierarchy. Just make it easy to get to Search/Browse from anywhere, and then into a species page quickly.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I think we’ve covered the content I care about. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like the site to use for interactive elements (e.g., links, buttons, active filters)?
conversation.user: I’d like the accent/highlight color to be maroon for interactive elements like links, buttons, and active filters.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for the color scheme, such as meeting WCAG AA or AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements against their backgrounds?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific WCAG levels—just make sure text and buttons are clearly readable and the maroon doesn’t make links hard to see.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states like hover, active, disabled, success, and error, and if so should those state colors be based on the maroon accent or use distinct colors (e.g., green for success, red for errors)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about having a super-defined state color system. Just use whatever standard distinct colors make sense (green for success, red for errors) and keep them readable with the maroon accent.

conversation.interviewer: What base colors would you like for key UI components (such as buttons, cards, and the top navigation bar)—for example, mostly white/light neutrals with maroon accents, or something darker or more colorful?
conversation.user: I’d prefer a light, neutral look—linen as the main background, white/light cards, and a mostly light top nav. Use maroon for buttons/links/active states, with dark text for readability.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual elements you want explicitly standardized across all pages and views—such as button styles, link appearance, card layout, or heading typography—so they always look and behave the same everywhere?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict visual standardization. Just keep the basics consistent—maroon links/buttons, readable headings, and clean cards—so it feels cohesive.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional colors or decorative visual elements (beyond linen + maroon + standard status colors) to reinforce a specific brand or thematic feel for the site—for example, a subtle nature-related accent or pattern?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra brand/theme elements. If you add anything, keep it super subtle—maybe a muted sage/forest green as a secondary accent, but mostly stick to linen + maroon.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to keyword search for species by common name and scientific name with autocomplete so I can find species quickly.  
Feature2: As a user, I want keyword search to match scientific-name synonyms so I can find species even if I use alternate names.  
Feature3: As a user, I want keyword search to also match higher taxonomy (genus/family) and basic trait keywords (e.g., habitat) so I can discover related species.  
Feature4: As a user, I want to filter species by taxonomy from kingdom → species so I can narrow results precisely.  
Feature5: As a user, I want to filter species by location/range/region so I can find species relevant to an area.  
Feature6: As a user, I want to filter species by conservation status so I can focus on threatened or non-threatened species.  
Feature7: As a user, I want to filter species by basic traits (habitat, size) so I can find species that match simple characteristics.  
Feature8: As a user, I want filters to persist while I browse results and only reset when I clear them so I don’t lose my context.  
Feature9: As a user, I want search results to update automatically as I change search terms/filters (as long as it stays fast) so browsing feels smooth.  
Feature10: As a user, I want search results to show key info at a glance (common name, scientific name, range, conservation status) so I can compare species quickly.  
Feature11: As a user, I want (optional) sorting of results by common name, scientific name, and conservation status (A–Z / Z–A) so I can scan results more easily.  
Feature12: As a user, I want to open a species detail page from results quickly so I can view full information.  
Feature13: As a user, I want each species page to display taxonomy, range/region, basic traits, conservation status, images, and references so I can view essential biological information in one place.  
Feature14: As a user, I want navigation to always provide an easy way to get to Search/Browse from anywhere so I can start a new lookup quickly.  
Feature15: As a user, I want the interface to feel fast and not laggy when search and filters update so exploration is enjoyable.  
Feature16: As a user, I want the site to use maroon for interactive elements (links, buttons, active filters) so the UI feels consistent.  
Feature17: As a user, I want a light, neutral visual style (linen background, white/light cards, mostly light top nav, dark readable text) so content is easy to read.  
Feature18: As a user, I want text and buttons to be clearly readable with sufficient contrast, especially with maroon accents, so links and controls are easy to see.  
Feature19: As a user, I want standard distinct colors for states like success and error (e.g., green/red) that remain readable alongside maroon so feedback is clear.  
Feature20: As a user, I want a cohesive but simple design with consistent basics (maroon links/buttons, readable headings, clean cards) so the site feels unified.  
Feature21: As a user, I want any additional thematic accents (if used) to be very subtle, optionally a muted sage/forest green secondary accent, so the design stays minimal.

task_name: Entrepreneurial Story Publishing and Browsing System
initial_requirements:
I want a mini-program where I can discover and read startup-related content, keep track of articles I’m interested in, and revisit what I’ve read.
我希望有一个小程序，可以让我浏览和阅读创业相关的内容，并记录和管理自己感兴趣或读过的文章。
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse startup articles, so that I can view entrepreneurial experiences and stories.
As a user, I want to browse articles in different categories, so that I can find entrepreneurial content organized by category.
As a user, I want to search for articles of interest, so that I can quickly locate specific entrepreneurial experiences and stories.
As a user, I want to collect (favorite) articles, so that I can save and easily access the articles I like.
As a user, I want to share articles on other platforms, so that I can forward entrepreneurial experiences and stories to others.
As a user, I want to register an account, so that I can have a personal profile in the mini-program.
As a user, I want to log in to my account, so that I can access and manage my personal data in the mini-program.
As a user, I want to manage my collections, so that I can view and organize the articles I have favorited.
As a user, I want to view and manage my reading history, so that I can track and revisit articles I have read.
As a user, I want the mini-program layout to use an old lace background, so that the visual style matches the specified design.
As a user, I want the mini-program interface to use rosy brown, so that the interface color scheme matches the specified design.

conversation.interviewer: 在小程序的页面结构和导航方式上，你更希望怎么组织？例如：是从一个「首页推荐/发现页」进入文章列表，再点进文章详情，然后有「我的收藏/历史记录」这样的独立入口，还是有其他你更偏好的页面和导航路径设计？
conversation.user: 我希望用底部 Tab 来组织：发现/分类、收藏、历史、我的。发现页里先给推荐和热门，但我更想有清晰的分类入口（比如融资、增长、产品、运营），点分类进列表，再进文章详情；收藏和历史作为独立 Tab 方便随时回看。

conversation.interviewer: How should users browse and discover available items or content (e.g. via categories, lists, feeds, galleries, or specialized views by type)?
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意具体用列表、信息流还是卡片，只要发现页里分类入口清晰、能按分类快速筛选，然后点进去看详情就行。

conversation.interviewer: 从分类/列表进入文章详情页后，你希望详情页里还能直接跳转到哪些相关页面或操作入口（例如作者页、同分类更多、相关推荐、收藏/取消收藏、分享、上一/下一篇等）？
conversation.user: 详情页我希望有：收藏/取消收藏、分享（能直接转发到微信好友/群、生成海报或链接）、相关推荐/同分类更多。上一/下一篇也可以有，但不是必须；作者页我可有可无。

conversation.interviewer: 用户从哪些入口进入小程序时，你希望默认落到哪个页面（例如微信搜索/扫码/分享卡片进入默认到发现页，或从分享文章进入直接打开该文章详情并可返回发现页）？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意默认落到哪页，按常规就行：正常进入就到发现页；如果是从分享文章进来就直接打开文章详情，返回能回到发现页/列表即可。

conversation.interviewer: 在内容检索方面，你希望小程序提供哪些搜索和筛选能力？例如是否需要按关键词搜索文章标题/正文、按分类或标签多选过滤、按时间或热门程度排序，以及是否要记住上次的筛选条件并支持一键清空？
conversation.user: 我希望有关键词搜索，至少能搜标题+正文，方便快速找某个案例/经历。筛选上按分类/标签（最好支持多选）就够了，排序给个最新/最热即可；筛选条件可以记住上次的，但也要有一键清空。

conversation.interviewer: Which filtering options and conditions should be available for narrowing lists or data sets (e.g. attributes, ranges, statuses)?
conversation.user: 这个我其实不太在意更细的过滤条件了，分类/标签（可多选）+ 最新/最热 + 关键词搜索就够用。其他像区间、状态这些不必做得太复杂。

conversation.interviewer: 筛选条件在界面上你希望是“选择后立即自动生效”，还是需要点一个“应用/确定”按钮才生效？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意，哪种都行。要是按多选筛选比较多的话，有个“应用/确定”也可以，避免我点来点去一直刷新。

conversation.interviewer: 在这个小程序里，用户是否需要自己创建或管理额外的「页面/视图」（比如自定义一个“稍后阅读”页或自建分类页），并能对这些自定义页面进行分组或排序，还是所有页面结构都由你预设固定，不提供这类多页层级管理能力？
conversation.user: 我不太在意让用户自建页面/分类这些能力，感觉会变复杂。先把页面结构固定好就行，最多提供一个“稍后阅读/收藏”就够了。

conversation.interviewer: 在用户输入关键词或使用筛选后，搜索结果列表你更希望以怎样的形式呈现和组织？比如是按时间/热度排序的普通纵向列表（每项显示标题+摘要+标签），还是需要额外的分组（如按分类分段展示）或特定的结果布局？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意结果列表的具体组织形式，普通纵向列表就行（标题+摘要+标签，按最新/最热切换）。不需要再按分类分组得太复杂。

conversation.interviewer: 搜索时你希望用户能否选择搜索范围（例如只搜“全部/当前分类/收藏/历史”，以及是否只搜标题或同时搜正文），还是固定为默认范围与字段？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意，先按默认固定范围就行：默认搜全部、搜标题+正文。要是后面要加的话，最多加个“只搜收藏/历史”的切换也可以。

conversation.interviewer: 这个小程序需要用户登录吗：是否允许游客匿名浏览/阅读，只有收藏和历史等功能才要求微信一键登录？
conversation.user: 我希望支持游客先匿名浏览/阅读，但一旦要用收藏、历史、稍后阅读这些就提示微信一键登录。登录后把数据同步到账号，换设备也能保留。

conversation.interviewer: 用户用微信一键登录后，收藏/历史等账号数据和登录态需要在不同设备（同一微信号的手机/平板）之间自动同步并保持登录吗？
conversation.user: 这个我其实不太在意具体怎么同步和保持登录，按微信小程序常规做就行。只要我换设备还能看到同一账号的收藏/历史就可以。

conversation.interviewer: 除了微信一键登录之外，你还希望支持其他登录方式吗（例如手机号验证码登录、邮箱登录、或在已登录后用指纹/面容进行快速解锁）？
conversation.user: 我不太在意支持其他登录方式，先微信一键登录就够了。指纹/面容这种快速解锁也不是必须。

conversation.interviewer: 在用户首次进行微信一键登录时，你希望除了获取微信基础头像昵称外，还需要他们额外填写或确认哪些信息（例如邮箱、公司/职位、行业方向等），还是完全不做额外注册表单，直接完成登录即可？
conversation.user: 我不太在意让用户额外填信息，最好别搞注册表单，微信一键登录拿头像昵称就直接用就行。最多可选填公司/职位，但别强制。

conversation.interviewer: 用户登录后会话需要如何管理：你希望登录态默认保持多久（例如一直保持直到手动退出，还是如 7/30 天未使用自动失效并需重新登录）？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意，按小程序常规体验就行。最好是默认长期保持登录，除非我手动退出或微信侧失效再让我重新登录。

conversation.interviewer: 在这个小程序里，你是否只需要一种统一的普通用户角色（所有登录用户权限相同），还是希望区分出更细的角色（例如内容管理员可以发布/下架文章、运营可以查看数据等），并对不同角色在哪些功能和数据上做权限区分？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意，先只做一种普通用户角色就行。后台如果需要内容管理、运营权限，你们按内部管理端常规设计就好，不用在小程序里区分。

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意，没有特别指定的交互要求。整体顺滑、加载别太慢、操作别卡就行。

conversation.interviewer: 在各个页面内部（比如发现页、分类列表页、文章详情页），你有没有特别希望怎么分块和分层信息结构？例如哪些内容一定要放在最上面或单独成区、哪些可以折叠在次级区域里？
conversation.user: 这个我不太在意具体怎么分块分层，按常见的内容阅读类小程序做就行。只要分类入口、搜索/筛选和收藏按钮这些关键操作好找、别藏太深就可以。

conversation.interviewer: 你希望文章的分类体系具体怎么定：请给出你想要的一级分类名称列表（例如“融资/增长/产品/运营”之外还需要哪些），以及是否需要二级子分类（有的话各一级分类下分别是什么）？
conversation.user: 这个我其实不太在意要不要把分类体系定得很细，先有一级分类就够了：融资、增长、产品、运营、市场/品牌、团队/管理、工具/方法、案例复盘、行业洞察。二级子分类暂时不需要，后面数据多了再补也行。

conversation.interviewer: 在每个底部 Tab（发现/分类、收藏、历史、我的）内部，你希望页面的一级区块从上到下按什么顺序排列（例如发现页是“搜索栏→分类入口→推荐→热门”，收藏页是“筛选/搜索→列表”，等）？
conversation.user: 这个顺序我其实不太在意，按常见阅读类小程序的默认布局就行。只要搜索/筛选、分类入口、以及收藏/历史列表这些关键入口放得显眼、别太深就可以。

task_name: Social Networking and Content Sharing Platform
initial_requirements: I want a social website where I can connect with others, share content, and keep track of my own activities.
user_stories: As a user, I want to create an account on the website, so that I can become a registered user.
As a user, I want to log in to the website, so that I can access my registered account.
As a user, I want to invite friends to join the website, so that my friends can also use the site.
As a user, I want to make friends on the website, so that I can connect with other users.
As a user, I want to vote on content, so that I can express my opinion on what is shared.
As a user, I want to upload pictures, so that I can share my images on the website.
As a user, I want to earn points when I use features such as uploading pictures, so that I can accumulate points on the website.
As a user, I want a personal homepage that displays my user information, so that I can see my profile details.
As a user, I want a personal homepage that displays my updates, so that I can see my recent activity.
As a user, I want the website’s default background to be light cyan, so that the site appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the website’s components to be styled in cadet blue, so that the component styling matches the specified color.

conversation.interviewer: What specific ways do you want users to interact and communicate around content (e.g., comments, likes/reactions, direct messages, group chats), and are there any moderation or history controls (like editing/deleting posts, reporting, blocking) that you consider essential?
conversation.user: I definitely want voting on posts (up/down) as the main way to react, plus basic comments. Essentials for me are being able to edit/delete my own posts, block users, and report content; DMs are nice-to-have but not required.

conversation.interviewer: What moderation and history controls are required for user-generated content and messages (e.g. reporting, blocking, removal, visibility and deletion of history)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about anything beyond the basics I mentioned: users can edit/delete their own posts, block people, and report content. Anything more advanced is optional.

conversation.interviewer: What types of content should users be able to create or submit (e.g., text posts, links, images, videos), and what fields should each post include (title, body, tags, categories)?
conversation.user: I mainly want image posts—uploading pictures is the primary thing. Each post should have a title, an image, an optional caption/body, and optional tags; links/text-only posts can be allowed but aren’t the focus.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want content organized—should posts live in specific communities/categories (like subforums/channels) each with its own feed, or should everything be in a single global feed with tags for filtering?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way—global feed with tags is fine, but communities/categories would also work. If you need a default, just do a global feed with tag filtering.

conversation.interviewer: What kind of social relationships do you want between users—should it be a follow/unfollow model, mutual friends, or something else, and are there any specific actions or prompts you want to happen when someone starts following or befriending another user?
conversation.user: I’d prefer a mutual friends model—people send a friend request and it’s only connected once accepted. When someone requests/accepts, just send a notification; no other prompts needed.

conversation.interviewer: Do users need to be logged in to view posts and profiles, or should anonymous visitors be able to browse content before creating an account?
conversation.user: I’d like browsing to be allowed without logging in (view posts and public profiles), but you should need an account to vote, comment, post, or send friend requests.

conversation.interviewer: For image posts, should users be able to download/export the original image file (and if so, should it be the original upload or a resized/compressed version)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about that—either is fine. If you need a default, let people download the original upload.

conversation.interviewer: What exact information and verification/approval steps should be required when a new user registers (e.g., email/username/password only, email verification, phone verification, admin approval, minimum age confirmation)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about heavy verification. Just username/email/password with an email verification link is enough—no phone verification or admin approval.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any specific UI interaction requirements beyond it feeling reasonably fast and easy to navigate.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond user-uploaded images in posts, do you want the site to support any additional file or media types (such as videos, audio, documents, or reusable image libraries/templates), or should it be strictly limited to image files only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about supporting other media types. If you need a default, keep it limited to images for now and maybe add video later if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Should the site’s primary navigation be organized around a global “Home” feed plus tag-based browsing, or do you want separate top-level sections/pages (e.g., Home, Explore/Tags, Friends, Profile, Notifications)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how the primary nav is organized. If you need a default, do Home + Explore/Tags + Friends + Profile + Notifications.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else major on content. Just make sure image uploads are smooth, and include basic stuff like alt text plus sorting the feed by newest/top (with a time range for top). Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Besides users, posts, and tags, are there any other core entities or structured data you definitely want modeled in the system’s database (for example, named collections/albums of images, friend lists as separate objects, or saved/bookmarked posts)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more core entities right now. If you want one nice-to-have, saved/bookmarked posts would be useful, but it’s not essential.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: Nothing else on content from my side. As long as posts support title + image + optional caption/tags + alt text, and the feed can sort by newest/top with a time range, we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components like buttons, links, and vote controls (for example, a particular color family or brand color), or should we just choose a clean, accessible default?
conversation.user: Yeah—please use a cadet blue accent color for buttons, links, and the vote controls. Just make sure it stays accessible with good contrast in light/dark modes.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond “reasonably accessible,” do you have any explicit accessibility standards or targets for color contrast and readability (for example, meeting at least WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements in both light and dark modes)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific standard like AA vs AAA. Just aim for good contrast and readability in both light and dark mode, and don’t ship anything obviously hard to see.

conversation.interviewer: Apart from the cadet blue accent, do you have any preferences for the base (non-accent) colors of key UI components like cards, panels, and navigation bars—for example, mostly white/light gray, darker surfaces, or any specific color family?
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like the default look to be light and airy with a light cyan background. Cards/panels can be white or very light gray, and the nav can be a slightly deeper cyan/teal so it stands out without fighting the cadet blue accent.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from the cadet blue accent or chosen as separate fixed colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a full state color system right now. If you need a default, derive hover/active from the cadet blue accent, keep disabled as neutral gray, and use standard red/green for error/success.

conversation.interviewer: Are there any specific visual rules you want consistently enforced across all pages and device sizes (for example, a single shared style for cards, buttons, and navigation bars), or should the design system just aim for general consistency without strict, documented standards?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict, documented visual rules. Just keep things generally consistent across pages and make sure it looks good and usable on mobile and desktop.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the UI to convey a specific brand/theme (e.g., playful, professional, minimalist, retro), or should we keep it neutral with just the cadet blue + cyan palette?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific brand theme. Keeping it neutral/minimal with the cadet blue + cyan palette is fine.

task_name: Matrimonial Partner Search and Matching System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me find a suitable life partner by browsing profiles, connecting with others, and getting to know them online.
user_stories: As a user, I want to register an account on the matrimonial website, so that I can create my own profile and use the platform to find partners.
As a user, I want to log in to the matrimonial website, so that I can securely access my account and manage my profile.
As a user, I want to create and maintain a profile including uploading photos, so that others can see my images when viewing my profile.
As a user, I want to fill out personal information in my profile, so that potential partners can learn relevant details about me.
As a user, I want filtering options in search results, so that I can narrow down potential partners according to specific criteria.
As a user, I want messaging functionality, so that I can send and receive messages with other users on the website.
As a user, I want the site to use lemon chiffon as the background color, so that the visual appearance matches the specified design.
As a user, I want the site’s content blocks to use chocolate as their color, so that the content areas follow the specified design.
