conversation.interviewer: What kinds of interactions and community features do you want users to have around profiles (for example, private messaging only, or also comments/likes on profiles, group chats, forums, etc.), and are there any you explicitly do not want?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about community stuff like forums or group chats. Private messaging and maybe a simple like/favorite is enough—I'd rather avoid public comments on profiles to keep it respectful.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic private messaging between two users, do you want any specific messaging capabilities or controls (such as the ability to block or report users, limit who can message whom, or receive email/app notifications for new messages)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy messaging features. Basic ability to block/report someone is fine, and simple notifications for new messages would be helpful.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the interface details like button behavior or navigation quirks right now—just make it simple and easy to use.

conversation.interviewer: What information fields should each user profile include (e.g., age, location, religion, education, occupation, lifestyle, interests, photos, “about me” text)?
conversation.user: Each profile should have basic info like age, location, religion, education, occupation, and marital status, plus lifestyle details (smoking/drinking, kids, etc.). Also interests/hobbies, a short “about me” section, and a few photos.

conversation.interviewer: Besides user profiles, are there any other core entity types you want the system to store (such as messages, matches, or likes), and for one of them, what specific fields or attributes should it include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra entity types beyond the basics. If you need one, store messages with fields like sender, receiver, timestamp, and the message text (and maybe read/unread).

conversation.interviewer: Besides user profiles and messages, do you want the system to explicitly model “matches” (or likes/favorites) as a separate entity in the data—so you can track who liked whom and mutual matches—or is that not important for your needs?
conversation.user: I don’t really care if matches are modeled as a separate thing. As long as users can like/favorite and you can show when it’s mutual, whatever’s simplest is fine.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I think we’ve covered most of it. Just make sure profiles support uploading a few clear photos (with a main profile photo) and a basic way to flag/report inappropriate images.

conversation.interviewer: For a user’s detailed profile page, which exact fields do you want displayed (e.g., age, location, religion, education, occupation, marital status, lifestyle items, interests, about-me text, main photo and gallery)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact detailed-page field list as long as it shows the basics (age, location, religion, education, occupation, marital status), lifestyle items, interests, about-me, and the main photo plus a small gallery.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really care to add more content requirements right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What color scheme would you like for the main interactive components (such as buttons and links)—for example, a specific primary accent color and a general light or dark style?

initial_requirements:
I want a platform where I can share my skills, find people with relevant expertise, and connect with them for learning or collaboration.

As a user, I want to use a search feature that finds other users based on their skills, so that I can locate people with particular skill sets.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like users to interact and communicate around shared skills on the platform—for example, should they be able to comment on profiles/posts, send direct messages, join topic-based groups, or something else?

conversation.interviewer: How would you like groups/channels to be organized—by topics with tags, by categories, or as per-project/per-skill threads?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact structure—as long as it’s easy to find and join the right discussions. If I had to pick, topics with tags plus optional per-project/per-skill threads sounds fine.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of content do you want users to be able to create or submit (for example, skill posts, project showcases, learning resources), and what specific fields or details should each of those content types include?

Skill posts should include skill name, level, what they can teach/need, tags, and examples; projects should have a short description, role, tech stack/skills used, links (GitHub/demo), and what kind of help/collab they want; resources just need title, link/file, tags, and a brief summary.

As a user, I want to be able to share ideas on the website, so that others can see and be inspired by my contributions.
As a user, I want to be able to participate in discussions, so that I can discuss creative topics with others.
As a user, I want to be able to interact with other users, so that I can engage socially around imaginative content.

conversation.interviewer: What community features do you want for “World of Imagination” (e.g., comments/likes, user profiles/following, direct messages, groups/forums), and are there any moderation or reporting controls you need?
conversation.user: I’d like user profiles, the ability to follow creators, and comments + likes on posts so we can give feedback. A forum-style discussion area for topics/challenges would be great, and basic direct messages are fine. For moderation, I want report/block tools, spam filtering, and admin controls to remove posts or suspend accounts.

conversation.interviewer: For reported content or users, what specific moderation workflow and history controls do you want (e.g., admin review queue, audit log of actions, visibility of past violations, or retention period for deleted posts/messages)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super formal workflow—just a simple admin review queue for reports and a basic log of moderator actions. Keeping a short history of violations on a user profile would be helpful, but I’m not picky about exact retention periods.

conversation.interviewer: For following creators in “World of Imagination,” how should that relationship work in detail—for example, should following be one-way and public by default, and do you want any special actions or prompts when a user follows or unfollows someone?
conversation.user: I don’t care much about the exact follow mechanics. One-way following that’s public by default is fine, and a simple notification to the creator when someone follows them would be enough—no special prompts needed.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of creative content should users be able to create or submit on “World of Imagination” (for example, written stories, artwork, photos, videos, audio, prompts/challenges, or external links), and what key details should each submission include (such as title, description, tags/genres, age rating, collaboration credits)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific here. As long as people can post common stuff like writing, images, and maybe video/audio with a title, short description, and tags, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: Besides likes and comments, are there any other ways you want users to interact with posts on “World of Imagination” (such as saving/favoriting, sharing, star ratings, or polls), or should it stay limited to likes and comments only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding extra interaction types right now. Likes and comments are enough to start, and we can add saving or sharing later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond individual posts, do you want any shared media libraries or reusable content features (for example, users reusing/uploading shared assets like images, templates, or audio clips), or should files and media only exist inside each post itself?

conversation.interviewer: What main site sections and navigation hierarchy do you want for “World of Imagination” (e.g., Home, Explore/Feed, Forums/Challenges, Create/Upload, Messages, Profile), and how should creative posts be grouped for browsing (by tags, categories, or both)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation hierarchy. At a high level, Home, Explore/Feed, Forums/Challenges, Create/Upload, Messages, and Profile is fine, and browsing can be by both tags and a few simple categories.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?

conversation.user: I’d like a dark slate blue as the main accent/highlight color for links, buttons, and active states so everything feels consistent.

conversation.interviewer: What overall background color scheme do you want for the “World of Imagination” pages (e.g., light, dark, or a specific color), and should that main background be consistent across all sections or differ between areas like Home, Explore, and Forums?

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional brand-themed decorative elements (e.g., subtle whimsical illustrations, star/sparkle motifs, or creative textures) integrated into the UI to reinforce the “World of Imagination” theme, or should it stay mostly minimal and clean?

task_name: Wild Animal Detection and SMS Alert System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me identify wild animals, keep records of what has been detected, and get notified when animals of interest appear. 我希望有一个网站，可以帮我识别野生动物、记录相关信息，并在我关注的动物出现时提醒我。
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to recognize wild animals, so that the system can detect when specific animals are present.
As a user, I want the website to assign different color codes to each animal type, so that I can visually differentiate between animals.
As a user, I want to be able to set alert conditions, so that I can control when alerts are triggered based on animal detections.
As a user, I want the system to automatically send an SMS alert when a specific animal is detected, so that I am notified without manual checking.
As a user, I want to browse detection records, so that I can review past animal detections.
As a user, I want to view animal information, so that I can learn more about the animals that are detected.
As a user, I want to set personalized alerts, so that the notifications I receive match my individual preferences for animal detections.
As a user, I want the website body background to be misty rose, so that the page appearance matches the specified background color.
As a user, I want the UI to use firebrick, so that the interface elements match the specified UI color.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site to notify you when animals of interest are detected (for example, email, SMS, in-browser notifications, or something else), and are there any notification channels you explicitly do or do not want?
conversation.user: I’d like proactive SMS alerts when an animal I’ve marked as “of interest” is detected. Email is okay as a backup, but I don’t really want in-browser notifications.

conversation.interviewer: What specific events should trigger a notification (e.g., a new detection of an “of interest” animal, repeated detections within a time window, or entry into a geofenced area)?
conversation.user: Notify me when there’s a new detection of an animal I’ve marked “of interest.” I’d also like to set my own rules, like only alert if it’s detected X times within Y minutes, or if it shows up in a specific location/geofenced area.

conversation.interviewer: When your alert conditions are met, do you want notifications sent immediately for each qualifying detection, or would you prefer them batched (for example, a summary every X minutes), and should there be any limits or quiet hours to control how frequently alerts are sent?
conversation.user: I prefer immediate SMS for qualifying detections, but with rate limits so it doesn’t spam me—like max 1 alert per animal per location per 10–15 minutes, then a brief summary if there are more. Quiet hours would be great (e.g., 10pm–7am) where it only sends urgent alerts and queues the rest for a morning digest.

conversation.interviewer: How important is real-time reliability for your alerts—for example, do SMS and email notifications need guaranteed delivery within a specific time frame and visible delivery/read status, or is best-effort delivery without status indicators sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about guaranteed delivery times or read receipts. As long as it’s generally fast and I can see whether a message was sent/failed, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond alert rules, what kinds of settings would you like to be able to configure yourself in the website (for example, your own detection/alert rule templates, tagging schemes, geofence lists, or workflows for reviewing and approving new detections), and which of these should be reserved for an admin role instead of every user?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about admin vs user role separation right now. I mainly just want to be able to set my own alert rules, manage my “animals of interest” list, and edit geofences myself.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of your personal profile and preferences should you be able to edit on the site (e.g., phone number/email for alerts, timezone and quiet hours, preferred language, notification preferences)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a full personal profile. I just need to edit my phone number and backup email for alerts, my timezone/quiet hours, preferred language (English/中文), and notification preferences like rate limits.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond configuring alert rules themselves, are there any broader detection or review workflows you’d like to customize (for example, steps for validating new detections before they’re recorded, auto-tagging or classification rules, or scheduled review/cleanup routines), and if so, which ones?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about complex review or validation workflows right now. Just record detections automatically, and let me manually tag/edit or delete entries later if something looks wrong.

conversation.interviewer: When you’re recording or editing detections and your “animals of interest” list, what specific data fields do you want to be able to enter or change (for example, species, time, location, confidence, notes, tags), and do you need any bulk actions like editing or deleting multiple records at once?
conversation.user: For each detection, I want species/common name, timestamp, location (map + GPS coords), confidence score, photo/video if available, and my own notes + tags, plus a flag like “of interest.” For the animals-of-interest list, just species/name, optional nickname, alert rules, and maybe preferred geofences. Bulk actions would be helpful: delete/archive, add/remove tags, and mark multiple detections as reviewed/not reviewed.

conversation.interviewer: For detections and for your animals-of-interest list, which bulk operations do you want available (e.g., bulk edit fields, bulk delete vs archive, bulk mark reviewed/unreviewed, bulk apply alert rules), and are there any bulk actions you explicitly want to prevent?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about preventing specific bulk actions. The main bulk ops I’d use are archive/delete, add/remove tags, and mark reviewed/unreviewed; bulk applying an alert rule to multiple animals would also be nice.

conversation.interviewer: When you change settings like alert rules, geofences, or notification preferences, do you want those changes to apply immediately as you edit them, or would you prefer a more guided flow where you review and confirm all changes (or save them as a draft) before they take effect?
conversation.user: I don’t really care that much about the exact flow. Immediate apply is fine as long as there’s a clear save/undo and maybe a quick confirmation for bigger changes like geofences or quiet hours.

conversation.interviewer: What filters and query options do you need when searching your detection records (e.g., species, date/time range, location/geofence, confidence threshold, tags, reviewed status), and should those filters persist between visits?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about fancy search right now. Basic filters like species, date/time range, geofence/location, confidence, tags, and reviewed status are enough, and it’d be nice if it remembered my last-used filters between visits.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction details like button behavior right now. Just keep the site snappy and simple to navigate.

conversation.interviewer: When a new photo/video is uploaded for identification, should the system run detection and record the result automatically right away, or only after you manually click a “process/identify” action (or on a schedule)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about that—either is fine. If you pick one, automatic processing right after upload would be more convenient.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific interaction requirements beyond keeping it simple and fast—nothing else to add right now.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond detections and your animals-of-interest list, are there any other core data types you want the system to model explicitly (for example, “locations/geofences” as first-class entities with their own fields, “devices/cameras,” or “species profiles”), and how would you like those main entities to be organized or related?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about adding more core data types beyond detections and my animals-of-interest list. If you need one extra, geofences/locations as a simple first-class thing makes sense, but I don’t need devices or species profiles right now.

conversation.interviewer: For your detection records and animals-of-interest list, how would you like the system to handle history and retention—for example, do you need a visible change/audit history for each item and long-term archiving vs permanent deletion, and should you (or others) be able to view who changed what and when?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed audit history or who-changed-what right now. Basic timestamps like created/updated and a simple archive vs delete option is enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: One more content requirement: each animal/species should have a unique color code that shows up consistently in the records (and on the map/tags) so I can differentiate them quickly. Otherwise we can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What file/media types and formats should the site accept and store for uploads and detections (e.g., JPG/PNG photos, MP4 videos), and are there any size/length limits you want?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific formats or limits right now. Just support common ones like JPG/PNG for photos and MP4 for video, and pick reasonable size limits so uploads don’t get too slow.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several more questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items) since you last added something. Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any more content requirements right now—let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the site’s primary accent/highlight color be (e.g., for buttons, links, and active states)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a firebrick color as the primary accent/highlight (buttons, links, active states).

task_name: Ringtone and Wallpaper Download Management System
initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me find and download ringtones and wallpapers, and keep track of my favorites.
user_stories: As a user, I want to download ringtones, so that I can obtain ringtone files from the website.
As a user, I want to download wallpapers, so that I can obtain wallpaper files from the website.
As a user, I want to browse ringtones, so that I can explore available ringtone content.
As a user, I want to browse wallpapers, so that I can explore available wallpaper content.
As a user, I want to search for ringtones, so that I can quickly find specific ringtone content I need.
As a user, I want to search for wallpapers, so that I can quickly find specific wallpaper content I need.
As a user, I want to navigate to my user profile, so that I can view my download history.
As a user, I want to view my download history in my user profile, so that I can see the ringtones and wallpapers I have previously downloaded.
As a user, I want to add ringtones to a collection, so that I can refer to them in the future.
As a user, I want to categorize content by selecting a category from a menu, so that I can organize and view ringtones and wallpapers by category.
As a user, I want categorization functions for ringtones and wallpapers, so that I can quickly find the content I need.
As a user, I want search functions for ringtones and wallpapers, so that I can quickly locate the content I need.
As a user, I want all pages of the website to be styled with a light goldenrod background and olive drab components, so that the site has a consistent visual appearance.

conversation.interviewer: When a user downloads a ringtone or wallpaper, should it be saved directly to their device (with a “Save to Files/Downloads” prompt), or stored in an in-app library with an optional export/share button?
conversation.user: I’d rather have an in-app library where downloads are saved to my personal collection so I can find them again easily. An export/share button to save to Files/Downloads when I want would be great.

conversation.interviewer: For ringtones and wallpapers, should media be previewed inline on the listing page or in a separate dedicated viewer/player page with playback controls?
conversation.user: Inline previews on the listing page would be best for quick browsing—like a short audio preview button for ringtones and a thumbnail/quick view for wallpapers. But I’d also like a dedicated detail page with full playback/zoom and download/favorite controls when I tap into an item.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific ringtone and wallpaper formats and sources do you want to support—for example, audio types (like MP3, M4R, OGG), image types (like JPG, PNG, GIF), and whether users can upload their own files, only use files you provide, or also import from external sources like cloud storage or URLs?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact formats or sources as long as it works smoothly on most phones. Start with common ones (MP3 for audio, JPG/PNG for images) and we can expand later; user uploads/imports aren’t a priority for me.

conversation.interviewer: What file/media management actions should users be able to perform on items in their in-app library (e.g., organize into folders/collections, rename, delete, move, or bulk-manage)?
conversation.user: I’d like to be able to favorite/unfavorite, delete items, and maybe organize them into a few collections (like folders or tags). Bulk actions like select-multiple to delete or add to a collection would be really helpful. Renaming isn’t that important unless it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: What search and filtering options should users have when browsing ringtones and wallpapers (e.g., keyword search plus filters like category/genre, duration, popularity/newest, resolution/orientation), and should chosen filters persist between sessions?
conversation.user: Definitely keyword search, plus basic filters like category/genre, newest vs popular, and for wallpapers orientation (portrait/landscape) and maybe resolution. For ringtones, filter by genre and maybe duration. And yes, it’d be nice if my last-used filters/sort order persisted between sessions, with a quick “reset filters” button.

conversation.interviewer: When users change search filters (like genre, popularity, orientation), do you want those filters to auto-apply immediately as they’re toggled, or only update results after the user taps an “Apply” button—and should the current filter selections remain active as they navigate between listing pages until they explicitly reset them?
conversation.user: I don’t really care which approach you pick there—just make it feel fast and not confusing. If you do auto-apply, a clear reset option is important.

conversation.interviewer: Besides newest vs popular, what additional sort options (if any) do you want for ringtones and wallpapers—for example, alphabetical by title, shortest/longest duration for ringtones, or lowest/highest resolution for wallpapers?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra sort options beyond newest and popular. If it’s easy, alphabetical could be nice, and maybe shortest/longest for ringtones, but not a must.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about any one special interaction requirement. Just make it feel quick and straightforward, especially when previewing and saving to my library.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to offer only ringtones and wallpapers you provide/curate, or should it also allow users to add their own content (upload or import via URL/cloud)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about user uploads/importing right now. I’m fine starting with ringtones and wallpapers you curate, and we can consider adding uploads later if needed.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities (and key fields on each) do you want the app to model—for example items like Ringtone, Wallpaper, User, Favorite, and Collection/Tag—and what metadata should each media item store (title, category/genre, duration, resolution/orientation, preview URL, download URL, etc.)?
conversation.user: At minimum: User, MediaItem (with a type = ringtone or wallpaper), Favorite, and Collection/Tag. MediaItem should have id, title, category/genre, tags, thumbnail/preview URL, full download URL, and created/added date; plus duration for ringtones and resolution + orientation for wallpapers. Favorites and Collections just need userId + itemIds (and maybe a name for collections).

conversation.interviewer: For user accounts specifically, are there any additional fields you want to store beyond an ID and basic login info (such as username/email)—for example, display name, avatar image URL, language/region preferences, or anything else important to you?
conversation.user: Nothing fancy—just email/username, maybe a display name, and a basic preference for language/region. Avatar is optional, not important to me.

conversation.interviewer: For organizing media into collections, do you imagine a simple folder-like structure (each item in one collection) or a more flexible tag/label system where an item can belong to multiple named collections—and how many levels of hierarchy, if any, do you want?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about hierarchy details. If I had to pick, a simple tag/label system where an item can be in multiple collections is fine, and I don’t need nested levels.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t have any other content requirements right now. We can move on.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like the site to use for primary actions (e.g., the Download and Favorite buttons)?
conversation.user: Olive drab would be my preference for the primary action buttons (Download/Favorite). A neutral gray/white background with that accent would be perfect.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the olive-drab buttons and other UI colors to meet a specific accessibility contrast target (e.g., WCAG AA) for text and icons?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG target. Just make sure the buttons and text are easy to read and don’t look low-contrast.

conversation.interviewer: Apart from the olive-drab primary action buttons, what base colors would you like for other main UI components such as cards/panels and the top navigation bar (e.g., light gray, white, or something else)?
conversation.user: For the base UI, I’d like a light goldenrod background across the site. Cards/panels can be white (or a very pale cream) so they stand out, and the top nav can be a slightly darker goldenrod/tan to separate it from the page.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined set of colors for UI component states (hover, active/pressed, disabled, success, error), and should those state colors be derived from your olive-drab accent or specified separately?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining all those state colors up front. Just pick sensible defaults derived from the olive-drab accent and make sure hover/disabled/success/error are clearly distinguishable.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should follow a strict shared design system across the site (e.g., button styles, typography, card layouts, spacing), versus being allowed to vary by page?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict design-system rules. Just keep the main stuff consistent—buttons, typography, cards, and spacing—so it feels cohesive across pages.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any additional thematic/brand styling beyond your goldenrod + olive-drab palette (e.g., a nature/“outdoors” vibe with subtle textures or icons), or should the UI stay clean and minimal with flat colors only?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra theming—keep it clean and minimal with flat colors. If you add anything, just keep it very subtle so it doesn’t feel busy.

conversation.interviewer:
I have gathered enough information. The user requirements list is as follows:

Feature1: As a user, I want to browse curated ringtones and wallpapers provided by the site so I don’t have to upload or manage my own files initially.

Feature2: As a user, I want to see ringtones and wallpapers listed with inline previews (audio play button for ringtones, thumbnail/quick view for wallpapers) so I can quickly browse without leaving the listing page.

Feature3: As a user, I want to open a dedicated detail page for a ringtone or wallpaper with full preview (playback/zoom) and clear Download and Favorite controls so I can focus on a single item.

Feature4: As a user, I want downloaded ringtones and wallpapers to be saved into my in-app personal library so I can easily find and reuse them later.

Feature5: As a user, I want an export/share action from my in-app library to save items to my device’s Files/Downloads or share them externally when I choose.

Feature6: As a user, I want to mark items as favorite or unfavorite so I can quickly access the media I like the most.

Feature7: As a user, I want to delete items from my in-app library so I can remove content I no longer want.

Feature8: As a user, I want to organize items into collections or tags where an item can belong to multiple collections so I can group related ringtones and wallpapers flexibly.

Feature9: As a user, I want basic bulk actions (like select multiple items to delete or add to a collection) so I can manage my library efficiently.

Feature10: As a user, I want simple keyword search across ringtones and wallpapers so I can find content by title or tags.

Feature11: As a user, I want to filter ringtones by category/genre so I can browse the type of sounds I’m interested in.

Feature12: As a user, I want to filter ringtones by duration (e.g., shorter vs longer) so I can choose tones that fit my preference.

Feature13: As a user, I want to filter wallpapers by category/genre so I can browse visual themes I like.

Feature14: As a user, I want to filter wallpapers by orientation (portrait/landscape) so I can find images that fit my device’s screen.

Feature15: As a user, I want to filter wallpapers by resolution so I can choose images that look good on my device.

Feature16: As a user, I want to sort media by newest so I can see the latest content first.

Feature17: As a user, I want to sort media by popularity so I can see the most commonly used or liked content.

Feature18: As a user, I want my last-used filters and sort order to persist between sessions so I don’t have to reapply them every time I return.

Feature19: As a user, I want a clear “reset filters” option so I can quickly return to the default browsing view.

Feature20: As a user, I want search filters to feel fast and responsive (auto-applying or applying quickly after changes) so the browsing experience is not confusing or sluggish.

Feature21: As a user, I want keyword search and filters to remain active as I navigate between listing pages until I explicitly reset them so I don’t lose my current browsing context.

Feature22: As a user, I want media items to support common audio and image formats (e.g., MP3 for ringtones, JPG/PNG for wallpapers) so they work smoothly on most phones.

Feature23: As a user, I want each media item to display useful metadata (title, category/genre, tags, added date, and for ringtones duration; for wallpapers resolution and orientation) so I can make informed choices before downloading.

Feature24: As a user, I want user accounts with basic login using email/username so I can have a personal, persistent library and favorites across devices.

Feature25: As a user, I want to set a display name for my account so my profile feels a bit more personal.

Feature26: As a user, I want to set a language/region preference so the site can respect my locale where relevant.

Feature27: As a user, I want the interface to feel quick and straightforward, especially when previewing and saving to my library, so using the site doesn’t feel slow or complicated.

Feature28: As a user, I want the main UI to have a light goldenrod background, white or very pale cream cards/panels, and a slightly darker goldenrod/tan top navigation bar so the site feels visually cohesive.

Feature29: As a user, I want primary actions like Download and Favorite to use an olive-drab accent color so key buttons stand out clearly against the background.

Feature30: As a user, I want button and text colors with sufficient contrast so that labels and icons are easy to read and don’t look washed out.

Feature31: As a user, I want hover, active, disabled, success, and error states to be visually distinct (derived from the olive-drab accent and related tones) so I can understand the status of actions at a glance.

Feature32: As a user, I want consistent styling for key UI elements (buttons, typography, cards, and spacing) across the site so the experience feels cohesive and predictable.

Feature33: As a user, I want the site’s visual style to be clean and minimal with flat colors and only very subtle extra theming so the interface doesn’t feel busy or distracting.

Feature34: As a user, I would like optional additional sort options like alphabetical for media titles (TBD).

Feature35: As a user, I would like optional additional sort options like shortest-to-longest or longest-to-shortest for ringtones (TBD).

Feature36: As a user, I would like the future possibility of uploading or importing my own ringtones and wallpapers (from device, cloud, or URL) if needed later (TBD).

Feature37: As a user, I might like an optional avatar image for my profile (TBD).

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me arrange my trips by finding and booking transportation and accommodation, and keeping track of my bookings.
user_stories: As a user, I want to search for train tickets, so that I can find suitable train travel options.
As a user, I want to search for air tickets, so that I can find suitable flight options.
As a user, I want to search for hotels, so that I can find suitable accommodation options.
As a user, I want to book train tickets, so that I can reserve my selected train travel.
As a user, I want to book air tickets, so that I can reserve my selected flights.
As a user, I want to book hotels, so that I can reserve my selected accommodation.
As a user, I want to make online payments for my bookings, so that I can complete my purchases through the website.
As a user, I want to view the status of my orders, so that I can track and manage my bookings.
As a user, I want the website background layer to use a peach puff color, so that the site appearance matches the specified background design.
As a user, I want the component layer to use an indian red color, so that the interface components match the specified design.

conversation.interviewer: How should users manage a booking after it’s made—do you want features like viewing details, modifying dates/passengers, cancelling, and requesting refunds within the site?
conversation.user: Yes—after booking I want a “My Trips” area where I can view all reservation details and status, and ideally change dates/passengers when the provider allows. Cancellation should be handled in the site too, with clear refund eligibility and the ability to submit a refund request if applicable.

conversation.interviewer: What payment options and overall flow do you want at checkout—for example, which payment methods (cards, PayPal, wallets, etc.), when payment is collected (immediately vs. on confirmation), and whether you need things like 3‑D Secure, saved cards, or partial payments for bookings?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specific payment methods or advanced stuff like saved cards and partial payments right now. As long as checkout is straightforward and secure, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: How should users actually make their bookings on the site—do you want them to add transportation and accommodation to a cart and then book together in one checkout, or book each item directly one by one?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s a cart or one-by-one, as long as it’s simple and clear. If you can make it one smooth flow, that’d be ideal.

conversation.interviewer: Is there one specific interaction requirement you'd like to add—for example, how the interface should feel (e.g. speed, responsiveness), how search or navigation should work, or how buttons/controls should behave? Please describe just one, or say if you have none.
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific interaction requirement right now—just make it feel fast and straightforward to use.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core entities and fields you want the system to store for each trip (e.g., trip name, dates, destinations, travelers, booked items, confirmation numbers, costs, status)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about defining a detailed data model right now. At minimum I just need trips to show destination, dates, booked items (flight/hotel), confirmation numbers, total cost, and current status.

conversation.interviewer: For each booking item (flight or hotel) in “My Trips,” which exact fields should be shown on the detail page (e.g., provider name, itinerary/room details, traveler/guest names, check-in/out or departure/arrival times, fare/room type, taxes/fees breakdown, cancellation policy, contact info)?
conversation.user: I don’t care about an exact list of fields right now. Just show the essentials: provider, dates/times, location, traveler/guest names, confirmation number, total price, and cancellation/refund policy, plus a way to contact support or the provider.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond trips and individual bookings, are there any additional core entities you want the system to store (for example, users/travelers or saved payment profiles), and if so, what specific fields do you need for those entities?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra entities like saved payment profiles right now. Just basic user accounts so people can log in and see their trips—name, email, and maybe a phone number is enough.

conversation.interviewer: We have asked several questions about Content (e.g. data fields, report content, display items). Do you have any other requirements in this area, or shall we move on to other topics?
conversation.user: I don’t really have any more content requirements right now. Let’s move on to other topics.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color would you like UI components such as buttons, links, and highlights to use across the site?
conversation.user: I’d like the primary accent color to be Indian red for buttons, links, and key highlights across the site.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors (including Indian red accents) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard—e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA (minimum 4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG contrast target right now. Just make sure the colors are readable and don’t strain the eyes.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want a defined color system for component states (hover, active, disabled, success, error), and should these state colors be derived from your Indian red accent or set as separate specific colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a fully defined color system right now. If you can derive sensible hover/active/disabled states from the Indian red and use standard green/red for success/error, that’s fine—just keep it clear and readable.

conversation.interviewer: What base colors (for example, white, light gray, dark, or another specific color) do you want for the main UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar backgrounds, assuming buttons use Indian red as the accent?
conversation.user: For the main backgrounds (cards/panels/nav), I’d like a peach puff base rather than plain white or gray. You can use slightly lighter/darker peach-tinted shades for contrast, as long as the text stays easy to read.

conversation.interviewer: What color should the overall page background (outside cards/panels/nav) be—should it also use peach puff, or a different base color?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much—using a very light peach puff tint for the overall page background is fine, just keep enough contrast so the content areas stand out.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements do you want strictly standardized across the entire site to ensure cross-page consistency (for example, typography styles, spacing scale, button/input styles, card layouts, or icon style)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super strict on a design system. Just keep the typography, buttons/inputs, and card layouts consistent across pages so it feels cohesive.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have a specific brand theme or mood you want the peach‑puff + Indian‑red palette to convey (e.g., modern minimal, premium, playful, “travel/adventure”), or should we keep it neutral?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific brand mood—keeping it pretty neutral and clean is fine. Just make it feel travel-friendly and easy to scan.
